description:
I like their style of sandwich. You get plenty of korean(?) style meet, some veggies and herbs and it all goes together pretty well. 

Pricing wise they're not cheap but I think 10$ for a sandwich is pretty much a standard in SF these days. 

All in all I have enjoyed this place. Be careful if you're looking to grab a quick bite during lunch time though. The queue to order moves fast but then you need to wait around 10-15 minutes to get your order.
author: Michał K.

description:
I love the Lemongrass Pork Sandwich, great flavor, and quick to come out.  I regularly get the fries as well, despite my better judgement, always expecting them to be better than the previous time.  Frequently they are soggy after the top layer or two, but there was one time the fries were crispy all the way down.  Jalapeño fries sound so good, but the implementation is severely inconsistent.

If you come here before 11:45 am you'll have a good takeout or eat-in experience, but if you try to grab lunch at noon you're going to be stacked up against all of the delivery services ordering massive bags of food for nearby companies.  I've had to wait more than 20 minutes to pick up a simple sandwich before.
author: Matt U.

description:
A very nice place to get Bun Me in the center of downtown San Francisco. I've never tried anything but sandwitches to be honest. 

Sloppy Bun Sandwich is very juicy, a bit spicy to my taste, but not too much. Bread is crispy, but thanks to added sauces and mayo it is not dry. Overall it is a juicy sandwich with a bit spicy flavor - I'd recommend taking some drink to it, helps to prevent hiccups if you can't handle spices (like me).

Belly Bun Sandwich is crunchy, not spicy with a lot of sour carrot flavor. It is a really good combo by itself so I never added a hardboiled egg on top of it, but if you need more calories it may be a good idea.

Overall it is a nice place to get Bun Me for a lunch, but be aware - the line at noon can be long, so you'll have to wait 10-15 minutes to get your sandwich, stuff is friendly, and preparation time for food is short. They also have several tables outside, at noon you can get some free tint while eating :)
author: Dmytro Z.

description:
I was walking around and saw this place, I walked in as I was looking at the menu for about 10 minutes the girl at the counter finally told me they open at 11 and it was like 10:40. First of all, why do they have the door open anyways? Second, the workers saw me walk in and barely tells me right when I was about to order? why couldn't they have told me right when i entered? they wasted my time, looking at the menu. but whatever I left and went to a cafe nearby then i eventually came back at 11. 

I was hungry and didn't really know where else to eat, and I haven't tired this place so I said why not? I went straight to the counter since I already knew what I wanted. tell me why the lady who told me they were closed still earlier was giving me attitude? and even after I tipped them, rude! I'm a nice person and I even came back after my previous experienced. also while I was waiting for my order, she treated the customer after me better than me, gave him this and that, which she did not even ask me. I was pissed at the point and asked her if I can have my food to go. I refuse to sit and eat my food after being treated unfairly. 

The food itself was good, I'm a bit surprised since it looks like an americanized vietnamese restaurant in the city. I got the Bun Bowl, and gotta say it has its flavor right on. although the vermicilli noodle is a bit different from what i'm used to, it's more thicker. I didn't have a problem since it was fulfilling and has lots of flavor to enjoy on a nice day out. Just weird how after eating, I felt really gassy the whole day. I know TMI but hey just a heads up, my stomach is a bit sensitive so probably that's why. ha ha. 

If it wasn't for the rudeness of their customer service, their rating would've been better but for now it'll be a 3 star because they really made me upset to even sit down to eat there and like I said, I'm not even the type of customer that will make a fuss about it. I'd probably give it a try the next time just because their food is good.
author: Deneb T.

description:
I was really sad about my banh mi because it tasted like a regular sandwich. 

I ordered the combo thinking that it would be the most authentic. The lemongrass pork did not have much flavor and lacked that nice fattiness and chew that you only get with a cheaper cut. Since the pickles were shredded, they blended into the sandwich instead of adding texture. Saddest of all, the pate was not noticeable next to the mayo. 

While I totally understand elevating a dish, I think Bun Mee goes too far to the point of losing the nostalgic goodness of the banh mi. If you grew up eating banh mi, I would avoid this spot.
author: Marie S.

description:
WHEN: Mon @3pm

There's nobody else here.  I came to pick up my MealPal lunch so it's probably the only reason why I'd ever come here:

BUN MEE COMBO - $7.50
Grilled lemongrass kurobuta pork, paté de campagne, mortadella, garlic mayo, shaved onion, pickled carrot & daikon, cucumber, jalapenos, cilantro.

I just refuse to pay $7.25 for a banh mi sandwich, and even doesn't even have that stink! I get it, this place is catered to Americanized hipsters of SF who will only eat at places with a nice brand with cool decor.  It's hard enough as is for a business to thrive in this city with lots of other hip foodery around.

I don't get why this place is spelled "Bun Mee" cuz if it's for branding reasons, it's not even trademarked. I'm just so sick of people phonetically spelling out Viet words, or pronouncing it wrong just to make it easier for non Asian speakers.  Greg branding though--logo, decor, packaging, etc. 

Okay, back to the food. It was good--good amount of mayo and the pork was nicely grilled and marinated.  There's way too much picketed carrots for my taste, and I wish there was more pate. Maybe that's where it didn't have that stank.

All in all the sandwich was good. I scraped the roof my mouth cuz I can't seem to eat a banh mi correctly. This place it nice and clean--and very hip with the heavily inspired Shepard Fairey art style.

I'll prolly come back, but only via MealPal :)
author: Tu-Anh N.

description: Nothing special, but nothing really wrong with it either. I just came here for the first time recently because people will come back to the office with it because it's really close to work so I decided to give it a shot after happy hour the other day.  I wanted to grab a to-go bite before I headed home. I got the chicken and it was decent. Bread was slightly too much on the hard side. I wish there was more chicken in it but it was mainly just the pickled vegetables. Definitely filling, but I've had banh mis from super divey places and they've all tasted better than this. I wouldn't strongly recommend even though I'm sure I'll eventually come back one day.
author: Jessica F.

description:
Bun Mee: 
This was a good last minute go to while one of us was at work. A Vietnamese sandwich, meat was real easy to chew &' affordable! 
5 Spice chicken Sandwich- $8
author: Couple E.

description:
I stopped to eat here before going to an event nearby. I had a lemongrass pork sandwich. I recommend adding the fried egg for $1 and extra meat for $1. The meat and sandwich itself were good but the meat to bun ratio could've been better. The bread is a bit too hard as well. The bun bowl with pork is decent. 

Nice atmosphere, good service. Mon-Fri Happy hour is 3-6PM. Decent deals.
author: Rebecca L.

description:
Super tasty sandwiches! We stopped here after touring the museum of ice cream. 
Great selection of sandwhiches. The steak sandwich was loaded with tender juicy steak. The meat melts in your mouth. Bread was fresh and nice crunch. Veggies also fresh and crispy.
We also had a beer of happy hour from tap and fresh squeezed lemonade. Cant go wrong with a sammy and a crisp beer!
The fries were amazing! Grilled onions and jalapenos on top of perfectly crunchy fries. 
I craved this place the rest of my trip and was sad I didn't have time to stop again.
author: Pilar J.

description:
I want to like it, but it's definitely not the best banh mi option in the area considering flavor, price, or service. I seem to keep forgetting this, returning, and then being mildly disappointed every time.

On my last visit, despite ordering well ahead, there was such confusion and significant delay even after checking in that I finally let them know I had to leave and they could cancel the order. Thankfully they just made it on the spot but it's just not worth that hassle. I'd return, but only if it's my dining companion's turn to pick.
author: Cristina S.

description:
Not authentic at all, but their Happy Hour is pretty good. Mondays-Fridays from 3-6PM their 5 spice chicken and crispy tofu is $5 with beer for $3.50 and wine for $5. 

A casual, fun and modern spot with lots of seating and no lines when you want a quick bite around Montgomery or Powell. 

 The 5 spice chicken was a bit dry and needed a sauce, but the bread was crispy and the pickled vegetables were on point.
author: Patty B.

description: Ordered online for pickup and arrived to find a closed sign. All the chairs and tables are stacked up in front of the window/storefront. Looks like it's permanently closed.
author: Andrea V.

description:
We walked by Bun Mee on our way back to the hotel after dinner a few blocks away. I noted it with interested and decided to visit the next day for lunch. It's probably a good thing that I didn't check Yelp reviews before visiting because they're not too flattering.

The combo sandwich that I received was pretty good - and I'm used to really good banh mi's at home in NYC. The price was about what I would expect to pay for a sandwich in the area. Counter staff was nice and my sandwich came out really quickly.
author: Michelle T.

description:
Since discovering this place iv been eating here a few times a week. Its a little more pricy then hole in the wall banh mi spots but still only 5-10 bucks a meal usually and in exchange you get a nice atmosphere and quality ingredients like kurobuta pork. 

They have an extensive menu of mostly banh mi sandwiches and rice/noodle with meat and veggie bowls of which iv tried almost everything. They have a killer happy hour thats dine in only but has 5 buck banh mis, loaded fries, and one of my favorite dishes the fried catfish. 

Everything here is always on point but my favorites would have to be the hawker bowl, the fried catfish, and the kurobuta pork belly banh mi. The fries all make for tasty sides be it chilli loaded, pepper onion seasoned, or sweet potato and the homemade cookies are a light treat to finish the meal. Just be warned a bowl or sandwich alone is filling. 

All around love this place so I dont get some of the hater reviews on here. Service is always great the young dude at the checkouts cool and since my first visit hes always remembered me. The menu has alot of interesting options, everythings high quality and filling, and the prices are cheap. Definitely check it out if you work in the financial district its right by the Montgomery BART.
author: Sean G.

description:
Sometimes you have a great manager who takes customer service as well as Yelp seriously.

Hats off to Austin, who I'm not sure if he's the owner or District Manager, but he should be the owner of all these chains for his excellent follow-up.

He contacted me, and wanted to make my experience right.

In fact, he made it better than right.

He gave me hot fries (totally delicious and by far my favorite with light traces of jalapeno heat and onions), a fresh spring roll, and a meat (thank you so much for listening to me on non-vegetarian) bun mee sandwich.

I was so thankful he took the time to address the issues in my first review, and do a 180 turn to fix them

Hats off to you Austin--you deserve a raise, your own stores, and you have my overall thanks for making this right!
author: Jack R.

description:
Surprisingly decent.

Given the trendy decor and prime location, I expected a crappy experience tbh. But it was not.

Healthy portions, tasty food and a pretty standard menu.  

A side note: I'm not really sure why people be going on and on about "authenticity" here though. I mean, look at this place: aesthetically, everything points to some fusion-type situation.

Anyways, can't speak for the other items but the sandwiches and fries were pretty awesome. Even the tofu sandwich was darn good. 

Do yourself a favour and get the salt and pepper fries. Mind blown. 

Fast service is just the icing on the cake.
author: Andrew C.

description:
I've only been here twice and it's always very busy! Which is a good sign for good food and service. Today I ordered the happy hour (dine-in-only) Chilli Fries - sloppy beef over garlic s/p grilled jalapeños, cilantro and spicy mayo. If you like spicy  food you'd enjoy this treat. 

Happy hour is from 3-6 and they also have a few options for beer $4-$5 and $13 draft. 

Friendly staff and very casual environment.
author: Martha S.

description:
3.5 stars- rounding up to 4. Stopped by here with my hubby while in SF. We were hungry but couldn't decide on what to eat. Thought we would give it a try, esp since there was a decent amount of diners sitting inside and outside. 

Oddly enough, we both ordered the Belly bun (can't go wrong with pork belly right???) but my hubby added hard boiled egg. He claims the egg did nothing for the sandwich and literally fell out trying to take a bite. But we both agree that there are GENEROUS portions of pork belly that were surprisingly good and juicy. The bread felt a bit hard but I understood why...it's gotta hold up that sandwich with all that pork belly!

Although I wish there was more daikon and cucumber, and cilantro (plenty of carrot!!, needs a little bit of proportion) it still was a pretty good sandwich. We added a side of salt and pepper fries- great pairing!! I couldn't stop eating it. Perfect crunch and seasoning. It came with some ketchup but I liked it by itself. Our sandwiches were $8-$9 (add egg) each, most of your local Vietnamese restaurants charge under $5 but you're in the city...expect to pay extra. There is seating outside and inside a few tables along with a community table. Service was not an issue, they were friendly and patient while we ordered and our food was brought to us fairly quickly.
author: Viclaire S.

description: I love their crispy tofu banh mi and this is a regular spot for me BUT today I found surprise fish in my vegetarian lunch. That should be a fairly easy thing to avoid.
author: Pierre-Luc B.

description:
Located on market street, I wouldn't say this place is a food trap...but I have had better bahn mi's in other places, for a lot cheaper. Obviously, based on location, you should already know that the prices will be a little higher. 

I would say the overall experience with their bahn mi is about average. Not the best, but not the worst. My wife and I each ordered a pork belly bahn mi, but I paid extra for an added hard boiled egg. FYI, don't waste your money on adding a hard boiled egg. Didn't make any difference to the bahn mi. I will say that I was pleasantly surprised with their salt n pepper garlic fries. They were very tasty, and I couldn't help but keep eating them. 

I don't know if we'll ever be back to Bun Mee, but it was a decent experience for the one time we've been there.
author: Joven S.

description: I ordered the Grilled Lemongrass Pork for $8.  As per stated in the menu it consisted of grilled lemongrass Kurobuta pork, garlic mayo, shaved onion, pickled carrot & daikon, cucumber, jalapenos, and cilantro.  It was good, I would not have a problem returning at a future date.  Fairly clean facility located at a high traffic area on Market St. between Geary and Montgomery St.   Tourists can enjoy free entertainment while they eat by the window and watch all the Market St drama transient through.
author: Jeff W.

description:
Hungry but not starving and wandering around during the holidays... how would we ever find a place for a snack? Yelp to the rescue.

Saw reviews and that it was only a few blocks away.

We headed over anxious to grab a quick snack before leaving to head back to San Jose. We weren't hungry enough to tackle one sandwich each, so we opted to share. The cashier suggested the Lemongrass Pork when I asked for an opinion between that and another option. Also, I asked that anything spicy be left off the sandwich which they easily accommodated.

The seating was plentiful, even during a busy Saturday afternoon, and the restaurant and restroom were super clean. 

The staff was polite and helpful and delivered our sandwich promptly.

Though I agree with the recommendation that the pork was delicious, the veggies stole the show. The crispness and pickled flavoring was perfect and complimented the pork perfectly. I wish I was hungry enough to have tackled a whole sandwich so we could have tried two different ones. I will add this to my list of stops when I crave a snack, or meal, nearby.
author: Sabrina B.

description: Definitely not the best or heartiest bahn mi in town, but not bad, either. I like that they're fast and open after lunch, which many places downtown are not. The single biggest reason they get 4 stars rather than 3 is the 3pm-6pm happy hour, making for one of the most affordable late lunches around.
author: Nathan P.

description:
I'm usually one to think that most of the food I get a chance to try is pretty good. 

That's where the Bun Bowl from Bun Mee comes in. It was a standard-looking vermicelli bowl (which I absolutely love), except something was very wrong.

It's fascinating how one element can ruin an entire dish so easily, but the fish sauce was -awful-. 

Without it, the noodles were completely void of flavor, and with it, the entire dish became inedible to me. 

If you come here, the Hawker Bowl seems like the way to go, I didn't have it, but since it is rice based, it can't possibly have the same problem.
author: Jatin N.

description: 8 dollars for a banh mi? You can definitely get a better one at some hole in the wall for half the price. Bun mee had no flavor in their sandwiches. The place looks nice... but the food is flavorless. Pickled vegetables dont even taste pickled.  Bread is hard and tough. If you are looking for a traditional banh mi taste you will not find it here.
author: Tyson P.

description:
Bun don't. Thoughtful menu, cute space, but poor service and mediocre food.

We walked in around 6:15 and there was one other customer already seated.  The staff seemed busy fulfilling take out orders. We waited four minutes for someone to walk over and act annoyed about taking our order.  Half the things on their online menu weren't available.

We ordered a couple of dishes and before we could add drinks to our order, the surly female cashier gave us our total. She might as well have said, "f*ck off, I don't want to be here."

The food arrived pretty quickly. The salt and pepper fries were good.
The tofu bahn mi was bad, the only okay thing was the bread.
My husband ordered a bun bowl.  Tonight was the first time I witnessed him NOT finishing a bun bowl.  When I asked him what was wrong,  he said: it made his stomach hurt - almost instantly, the nuoc cham tasted like apple cider vinegar, and the noodles were overcooked.  

We won't be returning.
author: Jennifer D.

description:
Don't know why I never came here to try their banh mi as much as I love Vietnamese sandwiches. Perhaps looks too Americanized and would not taste authentic or delicious. Nevertheless, this is on my way back to my office from the gym and I decided to try it out. 

To my surprise, I was quite happy with their combo sandwich. It is a good size with bbq pork, Vietnamese pate, pickled carrot and jalapeno. The baguette was toasted perfectly and their gave you a good amount of protein. The pickled red carrot is sweet but probably could have been sweeter. Overall, it is a solid sandwich and I am now curious to try other flavors!
author: Athena C.

description: Do you want to argue about whether it is 'authentic' or do you want to discuss whether it tastes good?   I really enjoyed the Lemongrass Pork sandwich.   It contained a nice portion of pork and vegetables (I did ask for extra cilantro), it was flavorful, and it was fresh.     Arriving at 11:45 on a Monday, the wait was 5-10 minutes.  Would I return?   Absolutely.
author: Diane W.

description:
This Bun Mee is located on Market St. Prime location for foot traffic. Located near Bart & Muni. 

Parking would be rough I recommend walking. If your driving park on O Farrel and Ellis it is much cheaper then other garages. You can try and park at a meter on 2nd/Kearny. 

The eatery was clean inside and decorated nicely. I also like this place because it's under $10. The cashier was nice and the food came out quickly.

I got the tofu spring rolls and salt and pepper garlic fries.

The tofu rolls were very bland. The dipping sauce was just peanut butter. The dipping sauce had no flavor or spice. I honestly wanted to throw it out after the first bite. But I like to eat all my food to be fair when I give reviews. 

The fries were warm, crispy and delicious. I didn't really see or taste any garlic but who can go wrong with fries.

Next time I will try the Banh Mi!
author: Kam H.

description: This place is amazing. Food is cooked fresh once you place your order. I am addicted to the steak sandwich and the garlic fries. I have also tried the fish sandwich and it was mouthwatering as well. I stop in and grab my lunch from here when working in San Francisco.
author: Asha L.

description: I really enjoyed my tofu Bahn mi and tofu summer roll. Absolutely delicious. Service was decent. Really glad we made it in before the rush at lunch hour. Seating was clean and spacious.
author: Katie K.

description: They have great lemongrass pork sandwiches. Great vibe and friendly staff. They have seating both inside and outside and a good variety of menu items.
author: Gisele M.

description:
I'm not a huge fan of Vietnamese sandwiches and Bun Mee did not do much to change my opinion. It is located in a busy area on Market Street but was relatively quiet when almost 30 of us walked into the place at 11.45 am on a Wednesday afternoon. 

The ordering process itself was pretty seamless and I ended up ordering the Five Spice Chicken sandwich with jalapeños. It was only after I had ordered did I notice the sign above the cashier that read something on the lines of  'Order your sandwich minus the jalapeños .. if you're a sissy".

Honestly, I was pretty excited about the sandwich at this point because I love spicy food and was really looking forward to tasting the jalapeños. And it's really because of this that it was such a big shame that they forgot to put the jalapeños in my sandwich! :(

The sandwich was a good size and made me feel full by the end of it. One thing I always judge sandwich and pita pocket places by is how they prepare the sandwich and Bun Mee really disappointed me. All of the meat was packed on to the inner side of the 6" roll and the veggies were on the outer side which made it pretty difficult to get a good serving of both in a single bite. 

Decent experience. 3 stars. 

PS - I dint try the fries here but had a little look around at the other table's orders and they looked delicious!
author: Gaurav K.

description:
Are you in the mood for Vietnamese? Do you love banh mi?! DO NOT EAT here if you said yes to either of those q's because this place is actually pretty subpar bastardized Vietnamese food, and I am relatively lenient on my vietnamese "fusion" standards, but not lenient on lame food. First of all, the horrible bastardized name should've been the first clue, bunmee is not even how you pronounce "banh mi" and so it's not even a good corny pun. We got a "pork belly" sandwich: 
- pork was basically poorly seasoned jerky. When you can't tell if it's beef or pork, and Trader Joe's jerky in a bag is more supple, you got probs. 
- bread was not a French baguette, cardinal sin my brother and sisters!!!!! It was an Italian sub that was too soft and allowed for maximum sogginess. Eh eh. 
- onions and carrots were not even pickled, who wants to eat raw carrots and onions?! 

I would be shocked and ashamed if my vietnamese brethren actually owned this place. To call it even a distant cousin of Vietnamese banh mi is FAKE NEWS!!!
author: Liz T.

description:
Bun Mee was just eh. I had a huge craving for a banh mi and I remembered that I have not gotten a chance to try Bun Mee yet, so off to Bun Mee I went.

First Impression: Very hipster shop, there was a bit of a line for ordering and also for waiting. Service was friendly and efficient. I think I waited about 5 minutes for my food which wasn't that bad.

Food: I ordered the Belly Bun and a side of sweet potato fries. Sweet potato fries were delicious. They were hot and super crispy. I was worried it was going to be salty (because it looked oversalted), but it ended working out because the saltiness brought out the sweetness of the sweet potatoes. The accompanying red curry mayo was a huge disappointment. It didn't compliment the fries at all and just tasted weird with it. Maybe it's personal preference, but it taste way better with just sriracha.

The belly bun banh mi was just ok. I liked how the pork was super tender. The baguette was nicely toasted and crunchy. The one thing that really irked me about the sandwich was the pickled carrots barely tasted pickled at all. And there were cut so small that it kept falling out of my sandwich. I'm glad they were generous with the carrots, but at one point, it felt like I was eating a carrot sandwich.

I don't see myself as a returning customer at Bun Mee. I still had a huge craving for banh mi at the end of my meal. I'm sure some people would love Bun Mee if they weren't particular with their banh mis, but with all the wonderful options in SF, I highly recommend to go elsewhere.
author: Eva L.

description:
I had the Crispy Tofu Sandwich ($5 during Happy Hour 3 - 6 pm M-F). I found the tofu to be kind of plain and not very crunchy. I do like carrots but found that there were too many carrots in my sandwich. A lot of the carrot pieces ended up falling out of the sandwich right when I took a bite out of it. The carrots were really small while the onion pieces were much larger. I was able to taste the onion pieces clearly. The bread was very crunchy and the sauce was very light.

Even though I was able to get my sandwich for $5, I found the general menu prices to be kind of expensive. The original price of the Crispy Tofu Sandwich would have been $8, which I find high for a banh mi sandwich. 

I do like how this place opens later than most restaurants in the financial district. In general, the sandwich tasted ok.
author: Kristina M.

description: First negative review on yelp ever. It really pains me to write one actually, but I couldn't keep quiet. No flavor at all in the Bun Bowl. I was shocked that it was so flavorless. I'm not a picky eater at all, and have had my fair share of Vietnamese inspired foods, but this was a total disaster. The garlic fries were on the bizarre side, but tasted alright. For 20 dollars/ a person, you can do far better than this in SF. No clue if this was just an aberration or if this is the quality of food being served at this establishment. I might have just picked the wrong dish. But if your name is on the dish, it should at least have some flavor. My friend had the same thing and the same feedback. Not telling anyone to stay away from the restaurant, because it wasn't disgusting or anything, but your money may be better spent elsewhere.  2 stars is generous.
author: A.C. R.

description:
So I found a worm in my fried fish today. The cook tried to tell me that it was a "fish nerve" but I know worms and I know nerves and it was not a nerve. If I'm to be completely fair I know that worms are naturally occurring in fish so at the very least it was unsightly but I definitely lost my appetite after I found it and felt a bit queasy.  I was also irritated that the cook tried to cover it up to avoid my posting about it, at the expense of my health. 

This review would be my second time eating at Bun Mee. The first time I purchased my food during happy hour so the price was great. The fried fish tastes good but the banh mi itself is found desiring more. Its flavor is a bit lifeless in comparison to the banh mi I get at Vietnamese mom and pop shops. But I think it's where I'd go if I was looking for something simple and easy.

Original score: 3.25, lost a star for the worm
author: Eugene Y.

description:
I've been here a handful of times now. There doesn't seem to be a standard, as one of the cashiers has asked if I want jalapenos one time, whereas the next time, they didn't (its a good thing I wanted them).

I'm pretty pleased at their portion size! I've gotten their banh mi's as well as their bowls. I have yet to order their fries (interesting) as I keep forgetting its a separate component. But honestly, their sandwiches are big enough that you don't need anything else.

So, the second time I went they got my order wrong. I asked for the bun mee bowl with the peanut sauce. They gave me the rice instead though, and they got my meat wrong. I just wanted noodles :(

I tried again and got the right thing this time haha. Their noodles weren't totally what I was expecting (from having rolls and pho) but it wasn't bad.

Their Vietnamese coffee will KICK YOUR ASS lol. It (as it should be) was extremely strong, but not too sweet. 

It's pretty much always busy though so be prepared to stand in line!
author: Rachel W.

description: Cute spot but definitely overhyped and overpriced. The bread was cooked too hard making it hard to enjoy the overpriced sandwich.
author: Linda L.

description: I'm gonna bump to 4 stars, simply because it's the best deal on sweet potato fries that I've seen in this city so far and they do a fine job on these. Always fresh and crispy, always plenty (I either share or just have them as my main dish) and for $3.50, they are doing so many things right. Sandwiches are a hit or miss for me, but I find myself stopping by every so often, if I need a quick and easy snack.
author: Katja S.

description:
3.5...rounding up! 

Better than I expected. When a friend suggested this place, I was a bit hesitant as I was expecting overpriced/Americanized Vietnamese food. And while it is a bit on the pricey side compared to the banh mis in the TL (Tenderloin neighborhood), the ingredients were fresh and tasty. Instead of the two slices of meat you get from Lee's Sandwiches, the five spice chicken banh mi I ordered was packed to the brim with meat and topped with a heaping pile of veggies. 

Clean restaurant with plenty of seating in and outdoors. I'd suggest this place to get your Vietnamese cravings satisfied if you aren't able to go to the TL.
author: Michelle C.

description:
I really enjoy everything curry here. I always get the sloppy bun sandwich and if I am there during happy hour, the fries with the curry is pretty great. 

The line goes pretty fast even at peak lunch hour.

The environment is delightfully modern and clean, with outdoor seating available.
author: Cameron C.

description:
Man after walking 6 miles around San Fran, I was so hungry for anything other than Chinese, and I happen to fall into a Vietnamese sammich joint.. well be it.. 

I got the Sloppy Bun, which is a spin-off of Sloppy Joe, only where the seasoning is a Curry based which was an awesome twist.. Def will eat here again, but next time, No Jalapeno's.. they seemed excessively "ripe" or HOT.... might have just been the walking that made me weak..
author: Mike H.

description: Ok so I went in here, passing through and well it looked decent. I asked what's the most popular dish here and she responded with the 5 spice chicken without cilantro bc like no. Anyway, it's overfilled with carrots and very little chicken. Overall, it was extremely extremely average. I mean the idea of it being pickled was interesting but it just tasted so average so ya I wouldn't go again. I gave it a 3 because the inside decor is cool and that should count for something
author: Sarah H.

description: Good Bahn Mi sandwiches. Fresh rolls were okay too. Peanut sauce was basically peanut butter and I spread it on my sandwich. Spice whimps BEWARE. Fresh jalapenos in all the Bahn Mi. It's one of my mom's favorite lunch spots but I'm not impressed. Softer bread would be a good start.
author: Allison M.

description:
I was in FiDi and needed something quick and cheap before I headed to the airport to avoid paying for overprice and non-edible airport food. It wasn't cheap and though I didn't have to wait super long, it took them longer to make my sandwich than I anticipated considering there wasn't too many people there. 

I thought I'd try something new and go for the Sloppy Bun which has red curry ground beef, garlic mayo, onions, basil and jalapenos.  I was a little disappointed as there was barely any curry flavor which I was really hoping for and the ground beef was just whatever. The bread was just alright. Usually I'll cut the sandwich some slack if the bread is really good, but it was alright.

Overall, expect to pay nearly $10 for a modernized bahn mi.
author: Sophia Y.

description:
I'm glad that I came here with some of my best friends because things that would generally annoy me, made me laugh instead. When I arrived, it was around 6:30. My friends had gotten there just a few minutes before, and they said the cashier gave them discounted beers because of happy hour. Then I quickly went to order, and the cashier told me that happy hour was over. What? I knew it was, but why the uneven pricing? So dumb. Beer is still cheap anyways, though they ran out of the one I originally requested.

When it came time to ordering food, I had my eye on the tasty-sounding Hawker Bowl, with fried egg, spicy cucumbers, vietnamese herbs, bok choy, pickled carrots and daikon, cilantro, spicy mayo, and fried shallots over garlic rice. Apparently jalapeños are extra, but it's a generous amount. My friend ordered some chili fries to share at the table. Holy crap, the food here is spicy! Eventually we caved in and couldn't eat the jalapeños, but everything was filling and delicious.

There's a decent amount of space inside the restaurant, though I can imagine it gets busy in the middle of a weekday. They have an extensive menu, and I'd like to try more of it someday. Surprisingly, I find myself giving Bun Mee four stars, even though I absolutely hated the service here. Totally lifeless and confused. But I guess it's an evening in FiDi so who wouldn't be? Anyways, as my friend says, this place is totally underrated, and I agree! Hope to come here again soon.
author: Stefanie C.

description:
Bun Mee is about as formulaic of a modern-SF-quick-serve place as you can get, complete with Edison bulbs and exposed "building structure" (that may well be fake) and lunch trays. Granted, it's been there since 2011, so maybe that was newer and more unique when it opened, but by now I'm sure you've seen plenty of places that are a lot like this.

This particular version of the techie hipster quick serve (hipserve?) trope is Vietnamese. Here's the rundown!
Good:
-The Atmosphere (Hey, it may not be unique anymore, but it works!!)
-Fast service
-Stubborn Soda
-MASSIVE servings with very generous helpings of your choice of meat, and plenty of fresh and tasty vegetables
-A really great looking happy hour

Bad: 
-Nothing stood out. 
-It's within a mile of 7 Mission
-Prices still too high for bahn mi

I need to come back for happy hour, cause that's when the prices go from "nearly two Yelp dollar signs for a food item that is known for being super cheap" to "a very good deal for the neighborhood". 

I got a pork "Saigon peanut" bowl, and it was seriously one of the largest servings of any type of food I've had in a long time. I ate way too much and enjoyed every moment.

Notably, none of the flavors were notable - they weren't awesome or remarkable, just solidly good. It was tasty enough I wanted to keep eating, but not enough that it registered as delicious. And I ended up putting a ton of Sriracha on it.

If it's not happy hour, I'd probably hop a bus or uber pool to 7 Mission, which I think is the best Viet place in SOMA (and one of the best in the city). But this is a solid option in its own right, especially if you're looking for convenience or happy hour.
author: Chris S.

description:
I'm an individual that needs lots of flavors in my food. I tried the Five Spice Chicken Sandwich. It wasn't as spice as I thought it was going to be. It's a decent place to try, but I'm not a big fan. I could get better fries somewhere else. You aren't missing much if you don't go there. 

It does get really crowded there, so beware what time you go.
author: Anisha S.

description:
Nice food, the sandwich I took was very nice (fish sandwich). Was quick tasty, it was just a little dry.
The baguette bread was quite nice.
The decor inside is nice and welcoming. The personal friendly and takes time to explain the different options.
I would go again and try sometime different
author: Rachida I.

description: I tried this place for the first time. As it was free as part of our offsite so I thought it's worth taking the risk . I ordered a chicken sandwich with jalapeños. First the service is slow, these people seem slightly unhappy with their jobs. Secondly I don't think they can handle large orders. I think most of us didn't get our orders right and it was as simple as asking people's names and writing them on the packets. Three stars because food itself was good but service definitely needs a lot of improvement.
author: Qasim Z.

description:
Slightly below average

The place looked real good from the outside--brightly lit, good nice clean renovations. But once you go in you realize the items are really over-priced ($12 for noodles). 

The quality/taste was not that good--we got the peanut butter noodles, and it felt like they just took a Lot of peanut butter and dumped it onto the noodles--any 5-year-old can do that. It felt like they didn't really put any cooking effort into it, and still charged a high price just for the renovations and location.

The portions are really large, so at least you get a lot of food for the money. But not a lot of good food unfortunately.

Overall, try to steer clear of this place.
author: Henry L.

description: Got a chicken bun bowl to go. Chicken with rice noodles, an egg roll, veggies (cucumber, carrots, sprouts, lettuce) and sauce on the side. It was the first and only item I've had here, and I really enjoyed it! The chicken was seasoned with a delicious spice. Good amount of noodles. Lost a star because it was a bit overpriced in my opinion. However, I would definitely get this again. Great lunch.
author: Rebecca T.

description: Went hunting for nearby Vietnamese sandwich shop. This place was pretty disappointing. The staff doesn't seem to be Vietnamese (cook staff), the sandwich is not filling and is pretty bland. The pickled carrots don't even taste pickled. There's no pate spread, the lemongrass pork was just whatever and not enough cilantro. Obviously this is so Americanized. Not authentic, no flavors and missing a few prime ingredients. Must find a better spot!
author: Marie D.

description: Ordered a crispy catfish sandwich today. It did not have enough catfish. One half had a pathetic amount of catfish. Bun Mee, why so cheap? The catfish was not that good. Lacked taste. Note to self: Stop getting the catfish sandwich.
author: Denise C.

description: A nice and convenient place for lunch. Usually get one of their sandwich which is flavorful and full of goodies inside. They also have a happy hour for those looking for a quick bite and a drink after work.
author: Nancy P.

description:
I really enjoy Vietnamese food in general, which I discovered when I spent my first 7 years after college working in Silicon Valley. My biggest complaint about SF is that they are lacking in good Vietnamese options. 

Bun Mee is pretty good, but 1) it's more expensive and 2) definitely not the same as hitting up a pho spot or getting a rice place from one of the many places off Capitol in SJ.

Standouts:
- grilled lemongrass pork sandwich
- chocolate coconut cookies
author: Aivy C.

description: 5 Spice Chicken - Simple and Fresh! Warm, crispy, toasty, tasty with some kick! :0) Yum!
author: Aaa T.

description:
Tried the crispy tofu sandwich. Delicious! 
Sandwiches don't come with sides. Love the interior decoration.
Staff was off putting.
author: Vince D.

description:
There is a certain sense of finality that one gets when you try a restaurant for the first time and know that you are never going to come back again. This is one of those experiences. 

Pre-lunch rush, I ordered a lemongrass pork sandwich. After waiting about 25-30 minutes (now into the full lunch rush), during which several people who ordered after me had received their food, someone from the kitchen looks over at me realizing how long I've been waiting and asks for my name and what I ordered. After supplying that information, the person who asked conferred with someone else, only to come tell me that they didn't have my order. Oops. By now, the lunch rush is in full swing and I don't have time to wait for them to make me a sandwich considering over a dozen people are waiting for their food and there is a line of at least 20 people waiting to order. Got my money back and went elsewhere for lunch.

Giving two stars instead of one because the manager (?) came over and gave me a coupon for a free lunch, but I don't intend to use it given the poor service here. Overall, the place seems very frantic and disorganized (even before the lunch rush), so I'd give it a pass except maybe during a very slow time period.
author: Marat M.

description:
Great place to stop for a TSA-friendly, Happy Hour bahn mi sandwich right before you head off to Oakland Airport!

The only catch is that you have to order to dine in. No problem! Eat one half and take the other with you! I'm sure all the other passengers won't mind the smell of pickled veggies and pork. Screw 'em!

Sometimes the Happy Hour sandwiches kinda suck. Like that Sloppy Joe sandwich described as including meat and mayo. Or that tofu sandwich that isn't as good as the one at Bunn Mi Cafe in the Richmond. 

Just try and get that pork belly sandwich. It's good. Also, they have a very fancy soda fountain with all these interesting drinks. Fun!
author: Aren A.

description:
3 star is quite appropriate... nothing that stood out and nothing to hate about 
I was excited to see the hawker bowl on the menu, as I had such fun experience eating street hawker food in Singapore... oh well, Bun Mee just tries too hard ... Hawker food should NOT be this creamy and overly spicy! How much mayonaise did they put in that thing?? Or did someone dropped a bottle in there by accident? 
Yeah there's a happy hour Mon-Fri, but the day I went the crowd there were not in it for happy hour like you'd imagine at a bar/restaurant place ...
author: Chloe Z.

description: Friendly and quick staff. I've tried two of their sandwiches (lemongrass & belly bun) and they have both satisfied my cravings for $8. It's a good place to come for lunch since they'll usually have you're order prepared in under 6ish minutes (medium customer traffic). The ice coffee is a little on the sweeter side for Vietnamese ice coffee (which doesn't necessarily mean bad), I usually drink my coffee black, but it still has me going strong till I'm off work. Good work y'all keep up the hard work
author: Jon L.

description:
I came in here for a last minute lunch on the way to run errands. I  ordered the chicken banh mi and a soft drink. The sandwich was great and savory. 

The soft drink, I think I would pass up the next time. The soda machine has experimental flavors, but no classic sprite etc. I felt the price was high for the size of the sandwich. 

Overall, the taste was fine, but with cheaper options in the area, I'm not sure if I'd come back.
author: Lupita D.

description: I ordered the Saigon Peanut Bowl. The peanuts and peanut sauce are not fresh and taste stale. The pickled carrots taste funny too.  Great location on Market Street in the heart of the financial district, nice decor, but I won't come back!
author: Mirana Y.

description:
Banh mi aka Vietnamese sandwiches are the bomb when you're sick of plain old sandwiches and salads.  I'm glad that FiDi has a place like this.  For less than $10 you can get a banh mi sandwich.  It's not that huge (you'll be eating the entire thing in one sitting), but you'll be satisfied.  So overall, this place is an ok deal.  

I ordered the combo (pork) with egg to go.  Egg is an extra $1.  Much to my dismay I took my wrapped banh mi back to the office and found that I had a tofu sandwich...with no egg.  I really wish that there was a number system to pick up your order or that the person calling your name confirmed your order because the entire sandwich was wrapped in foil and there was no way I could've noticed the mistake.  Luckily, my wonderful friend shared her half of the combo with me.  My advice is to go for the combo.  The meat had way better taste than the tofu.
author: Shannon L.

description:
I love a great banh mi and have been wanting to try Bun Mee for a while. I had a chance to grab a few sandwiches for a lunch date and was glad to try it. 

Location is definitely convenient with prices that aren't as steep as I expected them to be. Very friendly staff. I decided to order a curry catfish banh mi while he ordered the pork belly banh mi. 

I'm usually a fan of curry and catfish respectively, but I did not like this combination in my banh mi. The flavor was strong but not what I expected. Tangy? I would never get this again. 

The pork belly banh mi was the best of the two and not because the other one was so bad. The pork belly has a good seasoning, caramelized well, and juicy in the best and worst ways. I would get this again and would recommend this to others. 

Overall, disappointed with one order but really dug the other one. I'll try it again but will opt for five-spice chicken or the steak banh mi next time!
author: Sofia R.

description:
Very yummy !  I got a Belly Bun -- Mmmm so tasty! Loved it.  Everything was flavored well, loved the pickled carrots and bread was just perfect.  I'll be returning for sure!

Very convenient because I just ordered it online, walked down from my office and it was ready when I got there. I'll be a returning customer for sure!!!!
author: Mimi G.

description:
Things only 90's kids remember: the analogies section on the SATs

PF Chang: Chinese food -- _______ : Banh Mi

The sandwiches here are disgusting. Bread is never crisp and fresh. If you want to pay $8 for a piece of garbage that barely resembles banh mi, then go here.
author: Jack L.

description:
When Bun Mee showed up on Market Street's ever-changing selection of eateries, I thought, cool, a new place to try for lunch. I kept putting it off because their lines deterred me. Initially I thought that must be a good sign, but then again, any half-decent place in the area has a line around lunchtime. When I gave it a try, it looked like a breath of fresh air compared to most banh mi shops. It was clean and organized. Obviously, they put a lot of effort into the graphic art theme. 
The prices do seem high compared to banh mi shops in the TL or upper FiDi and other banh mi carts roaming around SoMa. But when you take into consideration their location and overhead costs, their prices aren't so bad. Plus, when you compare the price of one of their banh mi to the price of any other random sandwich in the area, it may even be a bargain. 

$7.50 Combo w/ grilled pork, mortadella, pate, mayo, pickled carrots & daikon, cucumber, cilantro: 
All the ingredients of a good sandwich. When it comes to banh mi, I always go with the one with pate. I opted to go without the jalapenos. I would have preferred if the bread was toasted, because it was pretty chewy. The slivers of pickled carrots, daikon, and cucumber were nicely acidic and crunchy. The grilled pork was tasty, but also chewy. The best part was the sandwich had a good amount of meat. In this area, I didn't mind the price and it did fill me up. 

As a sandwich, it was quite good. For a banh mi, it didn't quite hit the spot. I think I just needed more crunch, and a little more pate. It was good to try, but I do not feel inclined to wait in that line again. Perhaps I'll try one of the other sandwiches if I need to satiate a sandwich craving when they don't have a line.
author: Joy W.

description: Today I will be  saying good by to my fav spot. I have been buying the salt and pepper fries almost everyday and like the menu says it's a 1.00$ add on for meat, avocado, etc. today I was told it is now 2 dollars to add meat. Honestly I have a short lunch so I need to eat but my fries were smaller and had less meat.  Then normal.  The manager said  the other co workers rung me up wrong but how so if it was not the same worker? how if I have ordered it for a couple weeks with the same thing. I don't like how people feel like they can just change the prices whenever. Atleast put it on the board that's its 2 dollars or prices have change. I hate to say it but I will not refer anymore people here and today will be my last lunch at bunmee. You get one star for poor service and inconvenience.
author: Teyanna J.

description:
If you are a frequent night owl in FiDi, you start running out of restaurants to get delivery from pretty quickly. Bun Mee seemed like a good change of pace from the usual suspects of poke, bland salads, and over-priced Nick's Crispy Tacos.

For my main criteria triangle: price, quality, and quantity, you usually get to choose 2 and that signifies a very decent meal to me. This place unfortunately hits none of those notes particularly well. 

Quality:
Ordered a Tofu Noodle Bowl (it's dry with a side of sauce). Not a bad dish with your standard but fresh cilantro, pickled carrots, and jalapeños. However, one of my grilled tofu pieces was spoiled/rancid - blech.

Quantity:
I understand the tradeoff that is sometimes necessary between quality and quantity, but damn I wasn't even hungry and it was way too easy to polish this off.

Price:
11+ dollars for a Tofu Noodle Bowl was definitely not worth it given the above. 

Overall:
Located in a busy location and with decent delivery hours, I doubt this place is going anywhere soon. But if you do a little more Yelp digging, there are much better places than Bun Mee. Maybe their sandwiches are better, but wouldn't give this place a second chance.

Delivery Note:
When I do delivery, I usually try not to weight the delivery process too heavily, because it can be a much different experience over dining in-house. I will note it took them over half an hour to make one tofu noodle bowl (I'd also ordered a Banh Mi, but they later cancelled stating that bread was no longer available). The courier apologized with the late order and mentioned that he'd been waiting in the restaurant while the employees were texting instead of prepping the food - sigh - .
author: Willa P.

description: This place is over price for garbage food.  Beside the convenient location, nothing else stands out.  I guess people who love the sammies here, never really had an authentic Vietnamese sammie.  This place is an insult to Vietnamese cuisine.  I guess its great for tourists ~_~
author: Daniel M.

description:
Wondered in as I was walking by.  Selected the peanut bowl with pork.  Holy delicious.  I loved it! 
I'd give the inside ambiance a 3 for fast casual appearance and vibe. Got mine to go....delightful! Quick too! 
Peanut bowl had the following 
Brown rice peanut sauce jalapeño delicious pork - sweet and savory.
author: Ashley B.

description:
Wasn't the most incredible Vietnamese food I've ever had, but it was great for a quick, affordable lunch, near the office, especially considering average SF prices.

The egg roll on the rice noodle bowl I got was already soggy by the time it got to me, and the sweet potato fries were a bit too salty for my taste. The rice noodle bowl was also a little bit too greasy, but the flavor was good. I did really enjoy the Thai Iced Tea - the chia seeds are a nice touch. My friend got a sandwich with a fried egg on top and really enjoyed it!

I would come back due to convenience, but would probably get a sandwich instead of a bowl!
author: Katie S.

description:
Man, you San Franciscans are tough. Bun Mee is better than 3 stars. A quick glance through the Yelp reviews finds criticisms related primarily to 1) Authenticity, 2) Cost and 3) Decor. I think the counter to the the first two digs is that this isn't intended to be your typical $3 traditional Vietnamese sandwich - I thought the ingredients tasted of much higher quality than the prolific cheap run-of-the-mill banh mi (which are always delicious in their own right). And the pricing is still inexpensive relative to the other options in the area. These guys have their own take on the banh mi - I think what they are doing is great. 

My wife and I split The Combo, with grilled lemongrass Kurobuta pork, paté, mortadella, garlic mayo, onion, pickled carrot & daikon, cucumber, jalapeños and cilantro.  We thought the sandwich was fantastic. The garlic mayo really brought the sandwich together. Big props. 

Was the experience perfect?  Of course not. The chalkboard menu had misspellings, I wanted a smaller side but nothing caught my eye, and the drinks selection was lacking. 

Still, great place - I wish we had a location in the South Bay where we live.
author: Michael S.

description: Not bad considering not a real Vietnamese place the pork was ok at best and not enough jalepenos. Had the sweet potato fries which were good with the sauce.Although the people who work there are very nice and keep the place clean and good service.
author: Jay A.

description:
I hate writing 3-star reviews for businesses. On one hand, the lunch I ordered today wasn't bad. But on the other hand, it wasn't really worth writing/Yelping home about either. 

I really have no one to blame but myself for ordering the wrong thing. When you go to a place called Bun Mee, you should probably stick with their namesake dish. But instead of ordering a Bahn Mi sandwich, I decided to be healthy and order the 5-spice chicken salad. In my mind, I'd be getting all the good stuff you find in their sandwich, but without the bread/carbs/guilt.

Unfortunately, the salad was both overwhelming in size and underwhelming in flavor. It literally could've fed 3 people with this salad. But size isn't everything. It was difficult to pick up the various veggies and chicken bits with my fork under that giant bed of lettuce & wonton chips. And I was actually kind of surprised by the quality of the chicken. It was a bit gamey and stringy, and not all appetizing looking. It just didn't look or taste like chicken fresh off the grill. Fortunately, the tangy dressing was the saving grace. 

That being said, the salad was certainly filling and a good value for the price. But the next time I return to Bun Mee, I'm sticking with the sandwich.
author: Kevin B.

description:
Let me start by saying this: if they have corn, you need to get the corn! I haven't had corn this juicy or tender in such a long time. Whoever they're using as their supplier - my hat is off to you! 

Moving on, I had the pork barn mi - I'd eat it again in a heartbeat. The meat was flavorful and soft, the vegetables crisp and vinegary and the buns they're using were a top notch mix of crunch and soft. I would come back for the corn and the bahn mi. I also tried the mom's fried rolls - skip those. Might've got them on an off day but they came out cold and not that good. Their lychee lemonade was good but what's up with 3.50 for drinks in this area? I'm spoiled, it's whatever.
author: Aleks K.

description:
I randomly stumbled into this place when walking down Market towards the Westfield from Montgomery Station, and I'm am extremely glad I did! This is the perfect place for a cheap and fast meal that is both filling and delicious!

The interior is very clean and spacious, and the service is fast and friendly. We came during the lunch rush, but we were still able to get seats and served fast.  

I ordered their 5-spice chicken Bahn Mi, and while it was not as authentically flavorful as a mom and pop Vietnamese sandwich place, it did the deed of filling me up for a good price. I also ordered their garlic fries, (which is a surpringly spicy must-try!!) and their Vietnamese Coffee (which was not my favorite, do not recommend because it did not taste fresh and was just served from a large open container). 

Overall, I love the atmosphere of this place, and this is the perfect place to go if you do not know where to eat along Market, as it is right across from the Montgomery Station! I know I'll be coming back to try more sandwiches and sides, especially their strawberry lychee drink! Bun Mee? Bun Yippee! :)
author: Kyrie S.

description:
A Vietnamese sandwich joint that dares to be creative and deviate from the standard litany of flavors.  The meat feels a little bit higher quality than the cheaper options around town.  No need to complain about "authenticity" because they're trying to do their own thing anyway.

Mama Tran's Crispy Egg Rolls: It's no Tu Lan, but most places aren't.  Still decent though.  Perfectly crispy with good meaty filling.  Could have been thicker.  The dipping sauce didn't taste particularly fishy though, too bad.

Sloppy Bun: Not your typical Vietnamese sandwich.  Ground beef covered in a thick coconut curry sauce.  Kinda reminded me of that Cambodian ground pork dip, Prahok Ktiss.  Very rich.  Felt like a less protein than other sandwiches though.

Combo: Much higher quality pate and "fancy ham" than typical cheap Vietnamese combo sandwiches.  It didn't have that low quality processed meat taste I can only describe as funky.  Tons of grilled lemongrass kurobuta pork flooded the sandwich.  Only a slice or two of thin mortadella; would have liked to see more.

Strawberry Lychee Agua Fresca: Super sweet and refreshing.  Tasted like they might have used lychee syrup straight from a can of lychees.  Worked really well to offset the saltiness of everything else.
author: Adam B.

description:
This is my new place to go for a quick lunch sandwich 
Located on market street not too far from Kearny street. I went on a Saturday and walked straight up to the counter ( I'm sure during the week it's busy )  I ordered the combo which is absolutely delicious comes with pork and pate crunchy carrots jalapeños and more. Bread is super fresh. Staff friendly and for around $8 you can't beat it. My sandwich was ready in less than 5 minutes ! Looking forward to trying other items on the menu. I got mine to go but there is seating as well . Clean and bright this is going to be one of my go to's for lunch !!
author: lyn m.

description: I had put in a catering order through eat24 and DoorDash (different times) and the restaurant was 45 mins late with my orders, both times. I was really upset, called and complained to eat24, and DoorDash and then they called Bun Mee to complain for me. I was super mad but didn't yell at the restaurant workers.
author: Jenny L.

description:
I guess everyone is super spoiled here in SF judging by the reviews for this place.
I absolutely enjoyed my combo sandwich, the venue and service. My sandwich was not cheap ($7,5napproximately)but it was fresh and tasty. The service was quick and friendly. The venue is lofty and trendy... I will definetly be back ... Unlike other reviewers I realize that the rent on Market street is a little bit higher than on Larkin street or in Little Saigon area and it does not make sense to compare Moms and Pops Places in TL with this spot...So if you work in the area it is a reasonable spot for lunch...
author: George B.

description:
I feel like Bun Mee is the ugly stepsister of Spice Kit, Dragon Eats and Eatsa.

- Chicken Bowl ($11.75): the quantity of meat was low and the food quality wasn't outstanding. Bowl did not have a lot of greens, and chicken was not white meat. 
- Sweet potato fries were good, though there wasn't anything notable about them

Overall, bang for buck for the bowl is low. Maybe the Bun Mees are the better bet.

Tip: outdoor seating is available.
author: Kristie C.

description:
Well "Bun Mee" does the trick. Working here in FIDI, its hard to find a place that serves good bun mee. Of course its not comparable to my favorite Vietnamese sandwich in the tenderloin but it really does the trick. 

I love the decor of the restaurant and the fast service. They're also pretty friendly as well. I wish they put more pate or mayo into the sandwiches. Sometimes I think its just a bit to dry. 

I love their sweet potato fries as well as their salt and pepper fries. YUM! Its more pricey than a standard bun mee but its consider a cheap sandwich in the FIDI.
author: Sandy B.

description:
I got the juicy steak sandwich and probably won't be returning.

They really need to work on the sandwich assembly.  I don't want a mouth full of steak followed by a mouth full of carrots.

Also the bread was rock hard and, frankly, sort of painful to eat.
author: Jason F.

description:
Solid food. If you're looking for clean and good quality Vietnamese food you have to pay. $35 ($40 after tip) for spring rolls, chicken bun, banh mi 5 spice with pate, and Vietnamese iced coffee. I felt that the prices are inconsistent, for some items I felt were ok priced then the main stuff like bun and banh mi were kind of expensive. $7-10 for a banh mi is overpriced when normally you can get it as low at $2.50-3.50 at an authentic place. 

Now the food:
-ice coffee: good and strong
-spring rolls: I didn't like it. There was something sweet about it. The peanut dipping sauce was not memorable or added any flavor to the spring rolls.
-chicken bun: friend tried it said it was good
-banh mi: very tasty! I love everything about it. The bread was very crispy. 

I want to try more items on the menu!
author: Van N.

description:
They have great items on their menu...my favorite which I tried for the first time the other day was the Caramel Citrus bowl: garlic rice, avocado, mango, jalapenos, grapefruit slices-add chicken and siracha....soooo good. I will definitely come back for that! :)

Friendly staff. Reasonable prices. 

Love it :)
author: Mel P.

description: The food is DELICIOUS! The coffee is to die for as well. The seating is limited and it can get crowded but if you want food on the go, this is a good place to go. The portion sizes seem to be larger if you eat there. There is outside seating but the flies and no outside umbrellas make it so that the outdoor area is not as desirable as you would think it should be (Market Street in the middle of the financial district with the historic F train roaring by). Stick with ordering to go and you will be pleased.
author: Rita A.

description: Ehhhh. It's ok. Crispy tofu sandwich has tofu that's not crispy at all. Tasted barely marinated in anything. Sweet potato fries aren't too bad. Nothing special though. $4 banh mi from the TL are much better. Too bad they're so far away.
author: Ari C.

description:
My boyfriend took me here on a Saturday for lunch because he wanted to show me the places he discovered on his work lunches in SF. Bun Mee is a trendy little Vietnamese sandwich place that is modern and hip in every way, from the store name's riff on the Vietnamese sandwich banh mi to the decor of hanging lightbulbs and metal 

I ordered the grilled five spice chicken sandwich ($8) with a fried egg. +1 point for having the option of adding that fried egg! I got it over easy because everything is better with an over easy egg. The flavors were great (if not slightly muted on the pickled carrots but I mean, this is a trendy eatery rather than an authentic restaurant, so no expectations dashed there) and the sandwich bread was just the right combo of crispy and soft. My boyfriend also highly recommends the Belly Bun ($8). We also got the salt and paper garlic fries ($3.50) which were highly seasoned. It can get a bit salty but I was craving salt that day.

The prices are higher than what you usually see, but given its location in SF and the trendiness of this place, I wasn't really surprised or taken off guard.
author: Judith C.

description:
The decor is hip and industrial looking when stepping in.  It's a breath of fresh air and a new take on Vietnamese sandwich shops. 

Pretty pricey for the bowl entrees, but the sammies at about $7, is a deal.  I usually dislike baguettes because it's either too dry or crunchy, or both.  However, their baguette is nicely warm, lightly crisp and not too much of a bread-ful - especially on the ends.

You can Bun Mee anytime!
author: Tiffany D.

description:
Another branch of the Bun Mee eatery.

I really like the food here,

Tasty Lemon grass pork bun mee: great bread and good veggies.

Great crispy salt and pepper fries.

prices are not as cheap as other places but it is a legit place and a great place to have lunch...perhaps be prepared for a few crazy people ( half clothed and hallucinating) to check you out...just the local color.

Definetly check out for lunch!
author: David G.

description: The crispy tofu sandwich, which I've ordered a few times from here, would more accurately be called the crispy, tofu sandwich--there's a few little onion crispies in there, and then there's tofu that's just as spongy and nontextured (not in a bad way!) as the tofu you find everywhere else. Golden-brown and crunchy and mouthfeely crispy tofu is hard to come by. Vegetarians know this to be the truth. Still, the sandwich tastes good. Get the jalapeños.
author: Terry O.

description:
I really really wish I hadn't been feeling overly full and uncomfortable still from my breakfast when I walked into Bun Mee for lunch during my recent business trip to SF.

I really love the decor and the vibe of this place. To describe its a mix of traditional street style Viet/Thai paired with that indie/hipster aesthetic and a little industrial. Very cool!

I went with one of their bowls and topped it with their 5 spiced chicken. The flavours were outstanding. Sadly, I only managed through about a quarter of my lunch dish before I could no longer eat anymore. I wish I could have taken it to go but being here on business I didn't want to leave this in my hotel room. Ah well, I'm just really happy I got to try it.

Next time I'm back in SFO I'm coming back for sure and bringing my regular appetite so I can give Bun Mee the attention and respect they deserve.

Eatcrest Out
author: Kris U.

description:
Quick and tasty, and when you're looking for lunch in SOMA, that combination is worth its weight in gold. Every other lunch I had all week included a 30 minute wait in line, and I walked right up to the counter at Bun Mee. Yes, please!

They bill themselves as a Vietnamese sandwich eatery. Sure, that's true, but everybody in my party went with either rice bowls or salads. In that sense, it seems similar to Chipotle. There's no assembly line, but it does have a sense of "pick a protein, and we'll prep it up in one of our three categories". Whatever, that's not a complaint. I love me some Chipotle. But as that concept is hardly authentic Mexican, I wouldn't visit Bun Mee expecting authentic Vietnamese. 

Specifically, I ordered the Caramel Citrus Rice Bowl with pork. A good portion, it featured pickled papaya, citrus segments, avocado and jalapeños, with a house caramel sauce. You get your choice of garlic white or brown rice, and I went with the former. It was a delicious meal, with a touch of heat but nothing unreasonable. 

Bun Mee is super polished, and I really enjoy the design. If's very graphic, conveying "OBEY meets Chairman Mao". I love the mural. I love the lighting. Whomever is their designer deserves a high five.
author: Matt E.

description:
I wanted to like this. I really did. Tried it once a long while ago and it didn't appeal to me but thought I would try it again.A friend raved. 
Counter people were very nice and helpful. Ordering goes quickly. Then you choose an available spot to sit and wait for your food.  Since the counters were full and the one in the front was streaming sunlight I took a table that wasn't clean with the thought that certainly someone would grab those dirty bowls...Cody the food runner (and nothing else ever damnit!!!) passed by with orders no less that 5 times by my count (and I was counting, trust me) but never once deigned to bus. I understand the ole "it's not my job" but the person whose job it was never left the bus stand as though every good girl and boy actually cleaned their table.  We're not asking you to bus ALL the tables but just the dirty ones when people do not. It's not mandatory for guests to do it, just understood. I cleaned my shit but I didn't bother doing anyone else's. After all. It's not my job. I envision that table still full of crap, moldering away because no one bothered to care. 
Food was ok. The bread was so hard through and through it hurt the roof of my mouth and the $2 worth of catfish did not a good $8 sandwich make.  Doubt I'll go back and wonder why this is so popular.
author: Sherry W.

description:
We had just arrived in the city and feeling a little hungry. We needed a casual eating joint and there we were standing outside Bun Mee.  So in we went......

We decided to have the pork lemongrass sandwich......and it was really good. The roll/sandwich it came in was perfect, warm with just a mild crunch on the crust. Dressing was very tasty, pork flavours just right, pickled cucumber and carrot with jalapeños made for a great combination. 

When in the city and looking for a 'meal on the go' this is an ideal destination.........
author: Mick A.

description:
Pretty cool looking business from the outside - that's what brought us in, that and the fact that there wasn't a huge queue for lunch (around 12:15). 

I ordered the 5 Chicken Sandwich with extra jalepenos, unfortunately I think they missed/overlooked my order and my lunch buddies got there lunch about 10 minutes before me even though I ordered first. The fantastic waitress could tell I was getting tetchy and double checked my order. Once it finally came she delivered me a free drink to make up for the wait - I thought that was a classy touch and it definitely made up for the wait.

The sandwich itself was great - really moist chicken in a soft bun topped with fresh, crunchy salad! I kind of wished that it lasted me longer than it did.

Good spot for lunch, cool interior and a nice amount of seating - no queues and nice staff - give it a go!
author: Stevie M.

description: Yeah, these are some decent banh mi. Nothing extraordinary, but I'd be fine with going there again if I found myself in the area. I kinda feel bad about saying so little, but I guess that speaks to the neutrality I feel towards this place.
author: Shawn W.

description: The pork belly is amazing and filling! I am not clear what these bad ratings are. It's on market Street so expect fusion and higher price. But your get what you pay for. Don't expect $5 banh mi here
author: Helen C.

description:
Love me some bun mee! Sweet potato fries are so yummy when then are crispy (sometimes they're not) I love the hawker bowl with steak and I always get mine with a runny egg on top. Garlic rice is delicious, although most times over cooked. 

The flavors here are super spot on. Modern SF Vietnamese food. YUM!!!
author: Catie C.

description: Great Vietnamese food. Fast courteous service, nice contemporary ambiance. The bowls have the jalapeño kick even without the jalapeños. I had the Hawker bowl which always delicious. This will be one of my go to places in the City.
author: Ken A.

description:
I stand corrected.  Bun Mee has officially won me over.  We live and learn, and sometimes we live to learn how to better assess the value of what something has to offer.

I've had a bunch of sandwiches here now.  I would say that only the first was a little disappointing.  I wrote my review about that visit.  Since that time, the rest have been good.  They have been getting increasingly better, too.  And, I have learned to really appreciate the value of the space.  This is a beautiful spot, and while I've never taken them up on it, they have outdoor seating on Market Street across the street from the Palace Hotel.  They are also a good Saturday option, which increases its value in my book.

Sandwiches:

Steak Bun - It was great.  I added avocado.  It was topped by roasted garlic (secret weapon) and was substantial.  

Chicken - Good quality ingredients.  Won't upset you a bit.  Won't knock your socks off.  Safe choice.

Sloppy Bun -  Actually, I like it.  I know other people who love it.  I know people who hate it.  I topped mine with an egg.  I might not get it again because there are so many great choices, but I would happily have it again.  It would be great for breakfast.

Lemongrass Pork - Comes with julienned carrots and cucumber.  Some sort of aioli.  If you want grilled pork, you should get the:

Combo - The Combo is awesome.  I had it for the first time and it made me take the time to upgrade my review.  Grilled Pork, Mortadella and Pâté.  It was excellent.  Very rich and dripping with flavor.  Much more like some of the mom/pop places.  Well balanced, and I didn't feel any urge to season it.  Mmmmmmm....

The price is more than in the TL.  Fine.  You get a beautiful fast casual experience.  You can see by the photos that this is a great space.  It is not as down home as in the TL, but they have good options.  And, I still don't see the need for fries.  But, I do like that they also have some non-sandwich offerings.  

It's a good formula.  I will be returning from time to time.  This place earned a re-review.
author: Adam S.

description:
After the hot water incident, the GM of Bun Mee, Austin, reached out and apologized -- Explaining to me that the bad service was due to most of their front staff plus a cook being out sick that day. Although it doesn't excuse the specific employee's behavior, I can understand that everyone on the team was on edge that day.

Austin offered a meal on the house for me + a friend and it was greatly appreciated! To go above and beyond to make up for such a negative experience is definitely what brings customers back, especially when they love the food! Our company has come by for another team lunch since the incident, thanks to Austin's sweet effort.

Thanks again!
author: Angie S.

description:
235. This place is the more upscale, Americanized version of the Vietnamese joints in the Tenderloin.  Ordered the grilled five spice chicken without jalapeños.  But they still added jalapeños... spent the first five minutes picking them out like a trash collector.  Still crispy and flavorful.  I liked the garlic fries more though.

Nothing special otherwise, but it's a convenient option.  If you're in the area, this is a good place for a quick lunch break.
author: Katherine C.

description: A good choice is need to grab something quick @ Market Street. The place is clean, service is fast and friendly. I opted for the grilled pork Bun Mee and my friend had the fresh spring rolls with toffu which she really loved. The grilled pork was tasty but maybe i'm not just a Bun Mee person as I didn't find the sandwich that great to come back for it. But overall experience was nice. The seating area inside is pretty cute. They shut at 2:30 sharp!
author: Heliana M.

description: They screwed up my order giving me tofu spring rolls instead of pork and shrimp.  Those spring rolls were tasteless and dry.  The pork sandwich was also very dry.
author: Pasha G.

description: This is far from an authentic vietnamese "Banh Mi". The catfish sandwich I ordered was quite bland and in general it lacked a lot of flavors. The "Banh Mi" MUST always have fishsauce (Maybe no fishsauce in this store because the locals dont like it...). It's also rather expensive, but IMO you can give it a try. My critique could be quite harsh because I'm a  vietnamese and we know how our Ban Mi should taste!
author: Duy-Nam B.

description: I really like the friendly staff.  I love to pop in for the Happy Hour when they have discount sandwiches.   Yummy
author: Rob O.

description:
Headed into the city and landed starving.  I saw Bun Mee across the street and wondered.  What a great sandwich option!  I tried the Lemongrass Pork but next time want to try the Juicy Steak.  Note they automatically put jalapenos which will make me into road kill so I had to ask them not to put them in, but if you like japapeno peppers it is a condiment of theirs.  

The flavors of the pork with pickled veggies of cucumber, carrot and I think jimaca were crunchy good with the lemongrass pork.   

It was interesting that they had coconut to offer as it was there in the display.   If hunting for bite such as a sandwich give this one a try as it was a tasty change from the usual sandwich option.
author: Denise L.

description:
Bun Mee is an okay place if you're on break and just want a meal, but look elsewhere if you want to enjoy your lunch.

To me, this place is part of the growing number of trendy yet casual/clean businesses that offer a modern take on ethnic foods. Menu items consist of rice bowls, salads, sandwiches, sides, and drinks. I opted for a bowl while my friend ordered a sandwich. 

I opted for the tofu caramel citrus rice bowl. For $11 you get pickled papaya, citrus segments, avocado, jalapeños, crispy shallots, house caramel sauce over garlic or brown rice. You could choose to have pork or chicken instead of organic tofu but an extra $2 will give you steak or shrimp. Anyway, I really was't feeling the flavors. Specifically, the slices of orange and grape fruit really didn't work well with the other ingredients. Moisture was really lacking but I don't think squirts of sriracha would help.  The tofu had some sort of marinade on it and it didn't taste bad at all but I would've liked a crispier texture. Also, what's up with the whole cilantro? just pick off the leaves and toss it in my bowl. The fried shallots were a nice touch though. 

My friend had the grilled five spice chicken banh mi and I had a few bites. It came with caramel mayo, shaved onion, pickled carrot & daikon, cucumber, jalapenos, and cilantro. I thought it was also missing moisture. Turns out that was because the sauce was only on one side of the sandwich. The chicken was flavorful but the daikon/carrots didn't have that bright pickled flavor I like. Bread was decent. 

Keffir limeade was delicious and had a great balance between sweet and tart. 

Still, I'm not in a hurry to come back...
author: John B.

description:
When you see "Bun Mee" on some random hipster's blog titled "Best Banh Mi in the City!!!!," you know:

1) Not to trust the blog

2) There is a real problem with San Francisco not having enough authentic Banh Mi shops.
