Anyway, Bun Mee is one of those places I kind of poke fun at every time I pass by it. They can't possibly have delicious Banh Mi here. But like FreshRolls, I wanted to be proven wrong, and I really have no right to make fun of them until I try it.

I stopped by here after not wanting to find another place to eat. I see that they have 2 vegetarian options. The Crispy Tofu, and the Eggplant one. Eggplant in Banh Mi is really weird and very American, but I get that this is a 'modern' take on Vietnamese street food.

I got the Crispy Tofu and it is vegan friendly with their soy mayo.
It's about $7, which again, overpriced for a "Banh Mi," but I'm paying for a clean place to sit, open atmosphere, routine health inspections, and these college student's tuition.

My overall impression of the sandwich is that it was surprisingly good! Soft, but crispy bread, lots of pickled carrots and daikon, and the soy mayo and spread is actually pretty tasty. They literally only put 3 leaves of cilantro on my sandwich; they treat it as more of a 'garnish' than an ingredient-which really annoyed me. People either really love or hate cilantro. I love it. So I asked for more cilantro and they hooked it up with a small bowl of it.

As I finished my sandwich, I noticed that I was still....hungry.
I even had a snack about an hour before so I wasn't starving or anything. I don't think anyone can get full off of these sandwiches. I'm guessing meat might fill you up more, but the portions are still small. You'd have to go for the twice-as-expensive bowl to fill up.

In the end, I really liked the taste of the sandwich, but the price & portion size means I probably won't be back for a while.
author: Lanie L.

description:
Having spent most of the day exploring SFMOMA, I needed a substantial late lunch before returning to my hotel. Not far from the Montgomery Muni I found Bun Me, and was impressed by the quality of my bahn mi - grilled Kurobuta pork, apparently the best kind, I have since learned, with pate, mortadella, garlic mayo, carrot, onion, cucumber, jalapeño, and cilantro. I never order fries at fast food places, but these sounded so good -salt and pepper garlic fries, tossed with sliced onion, garlic and jalapeño.  Every bit as tasty as they sounded. 

Overall, what could have been a mediocre fast food experience became a really nice lunch.
author: Ken W.

description: Everything rocks here, except the cookies. Great tasting coffee, awesome sandwiches and salads, plus two kinds of fries!
author: C C.

description:
I went there on a Monday evening at 5:30 for the first time. Loved it! Very clean and easy to get to. 

They have happy hours from 3 to 6 on weekdays with beer and wine. 

I ordered Saigon Peanut Rice Bowl with Tofu. It was delicious. You have a choice of brown rice or garlic rice. I highly recommend garlic rice. This bowl is very spicy because of the jalapenos. You can ask them to hold it if you can't do spicy. 

They have free wi-fi too.
author: Hiral P.

description: One of the only spots to grab a quality meal downtown for under $10. The banh mis are fresh, generously sized, and delicious!
author: Nick B.

description: Bun Mee is a quick fast-food joint located on Market St, but this is nowhere near the greatest Vietnamese sandwich I've had, especially for the price (upwards of $7-8 for a pretty small sandwich). I ordered the smoky eggplant and added avocado on top; the two slices of avocado were not worth the extra dollar. The pickled daikon/carrot combination didn't have very much flavor, nor did the curry mayo or eggplant. The bread was also too thick, and the filling to bread ratio was not enough at all. To be fair, having only tried one item, perhaps I simply didn't have the best experience, so I would consider returning to try some of their non-sandwich options as well.
author: David K.

description:
I would give this place a solid 3 stars. The lady taking my order through the phone couldn't really hear me, but she was kind enough to try and get my order correctly. Thank you for that effort. 

The sandwhich: we ordered 2 crispy tofus and they put a good amount of tofu and carrots, I was
Looking for the cilantro... sadly there wasn't any. I'm not sure if they purposely don't put it in their sandwiches but for a Vietnamese sandwich, cilantro is a big part of the experience. The sauce tasted different from any kind of bahn mi I have ever had. I didn't strongly dislike it nor did I strongly enjoy it. It satisfied the craving. I'm not sure if I'll be going there again for a traditional tofu bahn mi. But nice effort
author: Reese E.

description:
5 spice chicken sandwich is not to shabby, good portion lots of veggies semi sweet with the sauce they pour in. Price for this and a bottled water was right under the $10 mark

5 spice chicken was juicy and tender, kinda didn't get the gist of the 5 spices that is meant to be on the chicken. There was a heavy presence of fresh veggies, needle sliced carrots, jalapenos thin sliced, cucumbers were thick cut, all on an oval type bun toasted, If you are looking to have something to fill you up, and is semi healthy, this place is good when in the area

food *** 5 spice not to shabby decent portion, 
price $ bottled water and sandwich under $10
service **** the staff was attentive, order was quick and painless
ambiance **** small from the outside, fairly high ceilings gives you the impression the place is large, tight front door/exit small seating primarily 2 at most per table, if not single seating along the bar in the back (not an alcoholic bar just a bar to eat), and another bar in front where the sun beams in. few tables outside covered by umbrellas
author: Clarence A.

description: The food was really good!!!! It was filling and had a lot of substance. I enjoyed my stay and  I do like this place a lot. It has a fun concept.
author: Abigail S.

description:
Who loves pork belly? I do!

My favorite here is most definitely the Belly Bun: braised Kurobuta pork belly, salted radish relish, shaved onion, pickled carrot and daikon, cucumber, jalapenos, cilantro. The pork belly has the right amount of fat and meaty goodness. They also don't give flimsy slices, which is great. Although, one thing that kinda bugs me about the layout of the sandwich is the fact that the veggies and meat are on either sides the banh mi... Why can't they mix it so the flavor is more balanced? I end up just mixing it up myself. lol

The line can get long around lunch time, but it moves quickly. The interior of this place is no ordinary banh mi place. I love how modern the decor is. This is my go-to place if I'm ever craving banh mi sandwiches in SF :)
author: Jenny H.

description: Great Sandwhich, quick, fast, and yummy. Great place for lunch or dinner. Parking kinda sucks on the weekend but weekday is great!
author: Casey S.

description:
Although there seems to be huge changes in personnel, the food has been consistent for the several years we'be been dropping in here, and the consistency is excellent, especially the sandwiches.

It's the best restaurant on the block!
author: Icono C.

description: Yummy sandwich, very quick for take out, and priced right. Not traditional or anything, but this American take on the bahn mi did just fine in a pinch when I was hungry for lunch and on the go.
author: Simone L.

description:
Original store is on Fillmore but never seem to be down there looking for lunch, but with my new office downtown I've been looking for reasonable places to get a sandwich.  

I saw the chairs out on Market St and as soon as I saw it was Bun Mee I knew I found a new "go-to" place for lunch!  Although I was taking out, there was plenty of open counter seating available.

The line was about 12 people deep, but before I could check in on Yelp, take a couple photos, and look over the menu, i was ordering the lemongrass pork sandwich and sweet potato fries.

I stood on the side and took a few more photos and as fast as you could say "Sriracha" or "big mac" my order was ready.  They threw in my vietnamese mayo and they had to-go packets of Sriracha!

The sandwich was perfect!  Meat was tender and bread was nice and soft!  Sweet potato fries come in a Chinese take out container.

Ps - i had the jalapenos!
author: Erik H.

description: totally reasonable three stars. love the eggplant and tofu banh mee and also the chicken. very well priced, especially on Market so close to Union Square. table seating or to-go. service is friendly. each sandwich is made to order to there can be a little bit of a wait, but that's better than getting a stale sandwich
author: Bob U.

description: This place is OK. Like when I can't find shit else to eat in #fidi cuz it's noon and everything is packed I'll come here and get a chicken banh mi with jalapeño fries. Will I enjoy it? Meh. The sandwich is average at best and the fries are actually pretty good. But I can't have everything. And that's fine I'm ok with that. I am used to the exquisite offerings at legit Vietnamese places where you get an authentic banh mi for 3.75$ or less. But this place will do, I guess. It's OK *shrug*.  It's clean inside and service is quick
author: A C.

description:
Beautiful modern industrial decor with Obey inspired prints, love the concept, the vision and story behind it and the cute cafe dumonde coffee cans for their cutlery but this Vietnamese Banh mi hype is definitely not real.

Not your authentic Vietnamese Banh mi.  I'm all for modern twist to make everything improved and better to attract a diversity, but the chicken and pork sandwhich lacked some true authentic Vietnamese flavor.  In a crazy carb and bread, noodle and rice lova but this bread is way too thick and hard.

Way too much carrot/veggies ratio to the meat as well.

1 star for great concept, decor and vision and story and that they came up
1 star for yummy sweet potato on point fries, and yummy jalapeño fries, I'm just a fries lovaaa
1 star for great service and fast online ordering 

Sorrrrry I really wanted to love it and never waste food but I just couldn't finish it. If you want yummy authentic Vietnamese Banh mi, your regular mom and pop small hole in the wall is still your go to.
author: Jennie D.

description:
The combo Banh Mi that I had recently was terrific. 
The garlicky pate they spread on liberally makes the sandwich moist and delicious. The bread is perfect and the crunchy veggies give a nice contrast. I only wish there were more jalapenos.
I wish these guys would open a restaurant in Seattle. 
I would be a regular customer for sure.
author: Matt R.

description: Good quick spot for lunch. They even have a happy hour. Great service. I  Had the eggplant sandwich. They have all natural sodas on tap.
author: Lei S.

description:
Some things are on point with their Banh mi. What's deducting 3 stars is how we ordered the "spicy chicken" and it wasn't spicy at all! It should be called "herb chicken," lol. 

Then the sandwich was $7. Are you serious? I'm not coming back.
author: Linh L.

description: Chicken was moist, bread was extremely fresh, and the side salad was delicious! My only complaint was that there was not more sauce on the bread and more cilantro on the sandwich. They should also step up the pickled carrots/radishes. Overall was pretty tasty though and I'll def be back soon.
author: Roff S.

description: Go here for lunch for the majority of my work week. It's always pretty packed but the service is awesome and you actually get your food pretty fast. Sandwich wise, the belly bun or the lemongrass pork is the way to go. Hawker bowl is super tasty but pretty spicy at times. Chicken salad is also a go to of mine. Definitely recommend as a downtown lunch spot.
author: Michael A.

description:
Stopped in to pick up a couple sandwiches.

Combo Sandwich.  Made with Pate, Mortadella, Grilled Pork, and their house mayo. This is the classic banh mi sandwich...though theirs is ok. Probably better to try other sandwiches.

Smokey Eggplant Sandwich. Eggplant, Cauliflower, and choice of Red Curry or Soyu Mayo. This is a great vegetarian option (can also be made vegan).  Will definitely get this again.

Overall they're a really good fusion version with unique flavors and real options. Good quality...so that's a plus. Isn't where I'd go if I'm craving a banh mi, but will be back for the quality Vietnamese style sandwich. Not as good as what you'd find in the TL. 

Bonus... they serve beer, so you can get a pint while waiting for your sandwich
author: Zoran L.

description: THE WORST.  I didn't think a flavorless banh mi was possible, but here it is.
author: Peggy R.

description:
I was excited to try this place because bahn mi is the bomb dot com. It was quite busy when I went but the service was super fast so that was great. I got the Belly Bun and a coke that came out to $8.10 so pricing was decent. 

The bahn mi itself was okay. The bread was my favorite part. Crispy and buttery on the outside and soft in the inside. I didn't end up finishing everything because the pork belly was quite salty. Also found it weird that the jalapeños were placed on the outside of the sandwich instead of inside. 

I would go again to try the grilled pork and because the service was good.
author: Andrea R.

description: Hawker bowl with steak. The best bowl possible ever!!! Can you guys open more stores, specially at the bay area so I can eat there more often?
author: Marco F.

description:
This place is just okay.

Like many places in SF they've taken a popular eating concept (mom-and-pop Vietnamese sandwich spot) and made it have a Chipotle/The Melt type feel. 

The sandwiches are slightly more expensive then your normal mom and pop too, but taste roughly the same. 

The only advantages of coming here is that they take American Express (if you're a business traveler and don't want to manually expense things) and the sandwiches come in a fancy wrapping paper that does a great job trapping in heat.

If you're vegetarian get the crispy tofu sandwich. It's pretty decent!
author: Nishad J.

description: Large portion, fair price. Nowhere near the tastiest banh mi in the city, even within a few blocks' radius, but still fine.
author: Barack O.

description: I've been here twice. Both times I've had the catfish Banh Mi. I have yet to find a place in Chicago that sells this particular sandwich so I' m always excited to get it when i head to San Fran. it probably has something to do with my Southern roots and love for catfish. It's not as well seasoned as the catfish back home or my own but the sandwich is still pretty tasty. The sweet potato fries are good, but the garlic jalapeno fries were meh.
author: Lekecia B.

description:
I came here for an early lunch (around 11:30) and got the 5 spice chicken Banh Mi.  There was only one other person in line ahead of us, and there were plenty of seats, but that may have been because we came before the noon rush.  

The bread was good, crispy, but nothing amazing.  The chicken was pretty bland.  Definitely not worthy of the name "5 spice".  

The price was fine, better than a usual sandwich in this area, but still more than what you want to pay for a banh mi.
author: Denis S.

description:
Inexpensive, but unimpressive, bahn mi and salads in the FiDi.

Sleek wood and steel provide an elegant backdrop for Vietnamese-influenced cheap eats. The menu boasts various bahn mi and salads, ranging from the usual suspects to the truly innovative.

With shaved onion, pickled carrot and daikon, cucumber, jalapeños, and cilantro, the grilled "five spice chicken bun" ($6.95) is topped with an interesting caramel mayonnaise--not quite traditional, but still quite good. Served on a crusty baguette, the chicken thighs were a little dry and the carrot and daikon, the most important part of a bahn mi, were barely pickled. Juicy and delicious, the "juicy steak bun" ($8.49) is topped with lotus root relish, shaved onion, pickled carrot and daikon, cucumber, jalapeños, cilantro, and crispy shallots and slathered with lime pepper mayonnaise. Unfortunately not sloppy at all, the "sloppy bun" ($6.95) with red curry ground beef, garlic mayonnaise, shaved onion, thai basil, and jalapeños was rather dry. Topped with sauteed red onions, garlic, and jalapeños, the salt and pepper garlic fries ($3.50) were a little too greasy.

Staff is super friendly and upbeat. There's beer by the bottle and a variety of soft drinks, including an awesome house-made kaffir limeade ($2.95) that has just the right balance of sweet and tart.

For a quick, relatively inexpensive lunch, Bun Mee is an OK option.
author: CJ G.

description:
Bun Mee gets an A1 review! I love the decor, kind of hipster. The place is clean and the staff is friendly. 

I recommend you try the 5 spice chicken, pepper fries, paired with anyone of their rare, fair trade, fountain drinks. 

The only trade off is that I was told by the staff that they did not serve hot drinks; funny they still had hot drinks on the menu!
author: Abraham A.

description: Good, fresh vegetarian sandwich options, generous portions and a fun little outdoor seating area to sip a beer and watch the people rushing around. I will definitely return.
author: Craig M.

description:
Went here with some co-workers for the first time and ended-up splitting a Lemongrass Pork and a Belly Bun with a hard boiled egg.  I enjoyed both, but definitely preferred the Belly Bun.  It was a bit more moist (mostly due to the fat on the pork belly), but the flavor was really good.  

The decor is cool and even though the line was fairly long, it moved really fast, which I thought was impressive.  The staff was friendly and we even found seats at 12:30pm, so we stayed to enjoy our Banh Mi sandwiches.
author: Lon H.

description:
I feel like the name and wallpaper alone are enough to make you come in.

If a hipster burrito bar mated with a Vietnamese restaraunt, this would be the offspring. Not sure why, but that's what it made me think of. Sort of a fusion menu with some non traditional stuff and some traditional stuff. The banh mi is what I was really craving. I grabbed a tofu one and some tofu spring rolls. It definitely hit the spot. Hard to say its better than any other that I've had before, but I will say it was really good and very consistent quality to some of my favorite Viet spots. 

Good location as there aren't a lot of easy bites around here(at least that I know about). Check it out fo yoself.
author: Sean M.

description: Bun Mee is an Americanized Vietnamese Modern casual restaurant that has such bomb vietnamese sandwiches. I always like to add some sweet potato fries on the side with their yummy sauce. The sandwiches are decent in price. I have never tried their rice bowls but they look scrumpcious as well. I have been to the Fillmore location as well and both are equally amazing. Definitely give this place a try y'all.
author: Stacey M.

description:
Tried the Bun Bowl with tofu.  As you will see from my reviews, I eat out every day, and this is the first time all year (and in a couple of years) when I returned my dish because it was so terrible.  Completely, utterly tasteless.  Now, the egg roll with pork was actually not bad, but there was only one of them, and soon after my bowl arrived, that egg roll was consumed.  And for $17 (the price of the bowl plus a bottle of Tiger beer), I was punched in the gut.

But kudos to the guy at the register yesterday who was cool with a very fair trade offer (at least, to the restaurant):  Take back the Bun Bowl and give me a small bowl of brown rice so I can at least leave here full.  And they obliged, and the bowl of rice was not bad once I added (smothered it with) sriracha sauce, so I left full.  And I got to sit on the patio on a reasonably warm day until it started to rain.

Can't come back, even if I lived here!!
author: Justin B.

description:
I've had Bun Mee a few times and was never too impressed, as it was an expensive and less authentic version of the real deal. However, after my experience today, I will most certainly never have it again.

My office ordered lunch today and so I chose the Bun Noodle Bowl with Tofu, as it sounded most appealing and was specifically labeled Vegan on their menu. When my order arrives, I've got the expected vermicelli noodles, tofu, etc. and a spring roll included. I didn't realize a spring roll was included, but didn't think much about it otherwise. Halfway through the bowl itself, I take my first bite into the spring roll and something is VERY off. I look into the partially eaten roll and see GROUND PORK. I was seriously disgusted and outraged that a menu item specifically labeled Vegan would have this included. I haven't eaten meat in over 15 years and knowing this kind of stupidity could have been avoided makes me even angrier.

So on top of mediocre food (at best), you can't even trust that an option labeled Vegan will not have meat?! No thanks - I will never set foot in either Bun Mee again and will warn my other vegan and veg friends to do the same.
author: Jon T.

description: It's ok. Not a big fan of their pork sandwiches - the pork is chewy and stuff in it that make chewing sorta unpleasant. The price is typical overpriced SF downtown. Generally prefer the chicken & catfish sandwiches.
author: Patrick F.

description:
I stumbled upon this little lunch gem on my way to shopping on Market Street. First of all, during a busy lunch rush I noticed how clean the dining area was.  Also, we were lucky enough to grab a table (and stools), so that was an added bonus. 

I wanted to have a light lunch so I settled on the pork/shrimp summer rolls and a mango salad.  The mango salad was a bit too citrusy, but the summer rolls were excellent.  The meal was a perfect light lunch.  My lunch buddy ordered the combination sandwich and salt n pepper garlic fries.  Both were excellent. We both noted that the fries weren't too garlicky, which was probably appreciated by the coworkers that we were later in a conference room with later that day.  

I took note of the bun and noodle bowl options on my way out and seriously went back the following day to try one.  The Bun Noodle Bowl is quite large (I had leftovers).  The chicken was grilled to perfection, the sauce was tasty, and the compliment of fresh veggies and vermicelli noodles creates an excellent dish.  

I will be back to try more entrees and for a special treat, I will try the house-made coconut cookie sandwich!
author: Andrea H.

description:
Every so often something transcends expectations. You go in thinking you know what's what and you're just stunned. An economy car is smooth and powerful. A BART passenger is courteous and moves to the side. A hipster looks good in skinny jeans.

These moments are so rare, that it's important to relish them and enjoy the moment.

So I duck into Bun Mee, as a long-time banh mi lover, I was skeptical. The place was too... nice. Clean. Well-lit. Decorated. Caucasian girl at the counter threw me off too. My typical banh mi experience is a server who's older than my grandmother, who knows as much English as I know Vietnamese, in a dingy place with a "B" rating from the board of health, that takes cash only, and has one flickering fluorescent light. They're cheap and they're no joke and they're AWESOME.

So I walked in with a raised eyebrow. Then I saw the fusion-esque offerings and the other one raised as well. Seriously? Sloppy Joe bahn mi? Someone someone Vietnamese is rolling over in their something. That's just sacrilegious.

A long-time fan of heresy too, I bit. Figuratively, then literally.

I'll be damned... (see, told you about heresy)... it was friggin' delicious. Inauthentic, unrealistic, completely invented in a test kitchen a week ago somewhere.

But Jeebus, that was a good sandwich. I'm going to wear a dark hat and sunglasses when I go back in case any of my Vietnamese/purist/foodie friends see me... but I WILL be going back to try the other varieties.

After living in LA I can speak openly and say that sometimes "fake", when done just right, is spectacular! O:-)
author: Sean B.

description: I had a delicious affordable Noodle bowl. The pork belly bahn that I had earlier was amazing too.
author: Benjamin T.

description:
The menu on Bun Mee read 'Five Spices Chicken Sandwich'. 

Five spices? That's 4 more spices than I'm used to! I buckled up my taste buds and prepared to take them for a joy ride.

A $7 sandwich came stuffed with carrots, pickles, a sneaky jalapeño, and of course, the 5 spices chicken. I hastily took a bite.

Hmm. Nothing. Bite number 2 then.

Nada. Uh oh. A chill ran down my spine. Did I lose my sense of taste? No. No. No. That's my 6th sense. I don't want to be the kid that goes,
"I see Bland people...all the time..."

I sat there looking like a nervous wreck with some seriously dry chicken in my mouth. Not a pretty sight. The other patron must have saw me, so he snapped at me to get my attention.

"Aye bro. It ain't you. This *beep*ing sandwich don't taste like *beep*. That's why I use this *beep* right herrrr."

The outspoken patron then proceeded to hose his sandwich down with a bottle of Sriracha that's conveniently provided at each table.

Phew. What a relief. My sense of taste is still in tact. But then I came to realized that I must now finish this overpriced and tasteless sandwich. That's $7 I could've spent at Chipotle....That's 500 calories I could've consumed at McDonalds....But instead, stupid ol' me came to Bun Mee.

A tear trickled down my cheek. This was literally a sad piece of sandwich. I would've asked for a side of Prozac, but knowing Bun Mee, it probably wouldn't taste like anything. No wonder they got bottles of sriracha everywhere.
author: Ringo M.

description:
Could I heave an audible sigh? Yes I can, and it can sound like Chris Christie after any recent press conference. That's the palpable sound of meh when I found myself waiting in line for what turned out to be faux banh mis. Yes, what the faux. That be Bun Mee. Oh yes, I've been to the other Bun Mee on Fillmore (review: http://bit.ly/1hknE5G), so there were no surprises offered here. But the lunchtime crowds were a bit ridiculous for what I view as overpriced sandwiches. You just have to travel two BART stations and make a right onto Larkin to get a better, more authentic banh mi for $4.50 less.

Despite a relative abundance of ingredients, the sandwiches at Bun Mee just don't have the soul of Saigon Sandwich to make the premium price worthwhile. When I finally got up to the register, I ended up ordering the $6.75 Bun Mee Combo, which offers layers of grilled lemongrass Kurobuta pork, paté de campagne, mortadella, garlic mayo, shaved onion, pickled carrot and daikon, cucumber, jalapenos and cilantro, all in a crusty, hollowed-out French baguette (photo: http://bit.ly/1jGCy6y). There are indeed quality ingredients, but it was frankly almost too packaged for my taste given the staff has to prepare for the massive lunch rush.

In a moment of weakness, I added an order of the $2.75 Salt 'n Pepper Garlic Fries with bits of sauteed red onions, garlic, and jalapenos and seasoned heavily (photo: http://bit.ly/1jGCy6y). The crowd here is an unsurprising mix of the young and hip which is a perfect match for the manga-like decor with a huge red mural of women in motorcycle helmets (photo: http://bit.ly/1jGCDqT). With its high ceilings, the renovated space on Market is much bigger than its progenitor on Fillmore, but I have to admit that it's not enough of a draw for me to come here very often. Give me the two Vietnamese ladies in their tiny prep area at Saigon Sandwich anytime.

FOOD - 3 stars...good fillings but not nearly as authentically soulful as the real banh mis in Little Saigon
AMBIANCE - 3.5 stars...spacious but still too crowded during the lunch hour
SERVICE - 3 stars...relatively fast back there but more assembly line than anything else
TOTAL - 3 stars...Bun Mee?...Well, Bun You!
author: Ed U.

description:
Excited that Bun Mee is so close to my work. I can come here even just to have their deadly chocolate coconut cookies. But it's a great quick lunch option.

You can sit  outdoors (much quieter than inside), but even indoors the atmosphere was winning: sociable, warm, community-minded. 

Grilled Lemongrass Pork Sandwich ~ freshly made, nicely spicy and generously portioned. My go to sandwich always delicious
Momma Tran's Crispy Egg Rolls ~ crunchy and flavorful I love this

Love the red curry mayo I smother my sandwich in it and dip the egg rolls in it too.

Great food with many vegetarian options. Their sandwiches have heat, fresh ingredients, crunch, and texture. Everything works. Cute decor, good service. Three stars!
author: Maria M.

description: Went in after a Run and got the 5 spice chicken with fried egg and there mixed greens salad to go. Best. Decision. Ever. Sandwich was really tasty and the salad was fresh and great. Would definitely recommend it. Extra jalapeños if you like spicy
author: Hector L.

description:
Convenient location on Market St. near FiDi area for a quick lunch. I've tried both the LEMONGRASS PORK and FIVE SPICE CHICKEN sandwiches and both were pretty tasty. There is a decent amount of meat and a huge load of pickled veggies on top. The bread was pretty fresh and crispy on the outside, with a slightly chewy center. They offer fusion sides like SWEET POTATO FRIES with RED CURRY MAYO that is pretty unique.

This can also be a convenient place to meet up with a few people for a quick sit-down lunch -- they have many small tables outside, and larger booths inside.

Things to note: 
- Can get crowded around prime lunch hours
- Prices are quite high compared to regular Vietnamese places (think ~$7-9 for a medium sandwich, ~$9-12 for a rice/salad/noodle bowl)

I like to come here once in awhile as a little "treat myself" lunch. But for authentic Vietnamese dishes that is more budget friendly in the area, I tend to go to Perilla or Du's Sandwich tent on Mission/1st.
author: Bonnie Z.

description: You could go to literally any other Vietnamese deli in the city and get way better bánh mì for half the cost. Like there are places in Chinatown where you can get two or even three for the price of one here!! And you KNOW their cha lua will be fresh
author: Calvin H.

description: Rude customer service from the lady working there. She constantly gave dirty looks and rude.  as I was waiting for 3 minutes and she looked and didn't say anything. Then she finally said "what do you want". Food was good though
author: Delila H.

description: I just tried to go there today and entered the restaurant while the doors were open and people were inside eating prior to 8 PM. The woman at the register asked me if I was picking up and I said no. She then told me they were closed, to which I said but it's not 8 o'clock yet. She then said yeah I know but we closed everything down anyway so... umm... really?? Annoying! And she was very unapologetic about it. I really like this place but that was extremely bad customer service.
author: Theresa R.

description:
There is always a lunch rush - but the food is worth it!

I've gotten their 5 spice chicken salad & the combo sandwich - both were super tasty. The chicken in the salad was SUPER flavorful and it's a pretty big salad lol one downside is that it gets so busy sometimes that they forget the dressing... so make sure you see a small container inside once you get it! The sandwich was also really good. It was full of flavor & the bread had a perfect crunch! 

Will be back to try more of their sandwiches/salads... but need to find the right time to go cause it literally takes 20 minutes out of my lunch break...
author: Carrie L.

description:
A delicious fusion Bánh mì shop popped into FiDi and it looks like they are here to stay.  What a smart move for them to find a location surrounding hungry-eyed lunch-seeking FiDi-ers, like myself!  And guess what?!  It tastes SOOOO GOOOOD!

Bun Mee, Bánh mì, Bun Mee, Bánh mì, Bun Mee.  However, you say it, the outcome is the same... TASTY!  I arrived at 12:45 PM and the line was 10 people deep, I waited 5 minutes to get to the register and ordered the combo sandwich and salt n' peppa garlic fries.  Then waited another 10 minutes for my order to come out.  It was a quick process, which is something I really appreciate since I usually grab lunch and run back to the office to chow down.

:) Combo Sandwich - it's main ingredients were grilled kurobuta pork and pâté.  First off, the french roll was warm, crunchy and perfect.  I was able to taste the pork with the pate along with all the other ingredients.  And I must say, it was a tasty treat to be able to eat one of these.  5 STARS

:) Salt and Pepper Garlic fries with Jalapenos - It wasn't the salt and pepper that I was expecting because usually there's a batter coating to go with salt and pepper fried food.  So, I wasn't impressed, perhaps the garlic and jalapenos made the fries soggy, I don't like soggy.  I still chomped all of them up but left all the jalapenos behind, those peppers gave it HEAT.  2.5 STARS

The decor definitely has that designers thoughtful touches that mimic's what a true Bánh mì street vendor may look like in the streets of Vietnam.  The shop looks modern and trendy with their gutted out high ceilings.  You can't help but notice the chaotic web of wires that floats on their ceilings and dangles with industrial lighting.  The red poster art on the wall bounces off a modernized vintage propaganda image but at the same time feels friendly communistic and playful.

Service was friendly and efficient.

Overall, I'm over the top infatuated by Bun Mee.  And I have plans to eat EVERYTHING that's listed on their menu.  Next up on the line-up...five spice chicken sandwich and ice coffee...  If these 2 items hit my palate the same way as the combo sandwich, I'll be theirs forever!

NOTES: Sandwiches are typical FiDi prices of $6.50 and above .  I've had other Bánh mì sandwiches at this price but does not taste as good as the ones at this place.
author: Jenny T.

description:
So, I love Bun Mee. I love their Fillmore shop as that's where I learned to love noodle bowls and nuoc cham sauce.  When I heard that they were opening up this spot on Market, I couldn't be more enthusiastic.  Time has gone by and it's only recently that I've found myself here twice (although once was via delivery).  On BOTH occasions, however, Bun Mee has messed up my order.  The order isn't hard: it's the 5 Spice Chicken Salad with the dressing on the side.  

Mishap #1 started on my delivery order where it was missing all the garnishments like crispy wontons, shallots, and peanuts.  Not a huge deal, but I definitely think those things add to deliciousness of the salad.

It wouldn't be awful, except that...there was another mishap.

Mishap #2 happened yesterday when I stopped in for a quick bite to eat (and incredibly grateful they were open).  Again, same salad order.  As my food was placed in front of me, I look at and realize that something's not right: it's missing chicken.  Yep. It was just a plain salad.  I walked my bowl back up to the counter and asked where the chicken was, and rather than apologizing, they took my bowl back, threw some chicken on AND was unnecessarily heavy-handed in the wonton strips on top of the chicken and then handed back to me.  The guy sort of laughed off the incident, but honestly, I didn't really find it funny.

In any case, I still love Bun Mee and I will continue to come back here because I love their 5 spice chicken so much.  But, if this stuff continues to happen, I'll definitely be forced to look elsewhere for my chicken salad option.
author: Lisa I.

description:
I've accepted the sticker price for a bahn mi sandwich if outside of Little Saigon.  It came as no surprise that my five spice chicken sandwich was close to $8.00 as this was in the FiDi district.

I thought the chicken thigh meat bordered on being on the dry side.  Good chunks of meat.  The pickled veggies could have been more vinegary.  Served on a crusty baguette.

Service was quick as I arrived at 11am when it just opened.  Took it to go, but ample seats.
author: Shirley N.

description:
I came in for a quick bite and ordered the fried catfish sandwich. I read some reviews before ordering, all warning me that the size of fish would be small. But I didn't realize it would be THAT small... Composition of sandwich was probably 1/5 catfish, 4/5 veggies. 

Overall, decent sandwich at best.
author: David Y.

description: Really bummed that we didn't enjoy this place more. The staff was super friendly so this review is based purely on the food. We ordered the caramel citrus rice bowl with chicken and the sloppy bun with a fried egg. All the ingredients seemed fresh except for the cilantro that was browning on the leaves. The thing that was missing was flavor. The meat was dry and not flavorful. Overall, not the worst meal I've had, but unfortunately not something I'll be craving.
author: Susan G.

description: It is a very lovely place to eat. Usually my workplace orders catering sandwiches and salad from them. They are tasty but not very special. They are using fresh meat for Vietnamese sandwich not like other places using preserved ones. Recently I found out their happy hour items are VERY COOL! The chili fries and fried catfish are surprising! And price is very cheap! 3 bucks for fries, 5 bucks for sandwich! It will be my new happy hour spot!
author: Nina H.

description: I tried this based on a recommendation from someone from work. I was going specifically for the happy hour prices and I was not disappointed; amazing happy hour prices and the food was terrific. The regular prices are not bad at all and the service was great. I would definitely recommend this place.
author: Angel V.

description: A sandwich for $5 during happy hour is a fantastic deal, especially in this area. The sandwiches are loading with lightly pickled carrots, so you get a couple servings of veggies in. The meat fillings are good, but the bread is definitely the star. My favorite option is the fried catfish. The grilled pork and chicken are fine too. I think the pork belly is too intense. It's basically salty thit kho aka caramelized fish sauce pork.
author: Huey N.

description:
Egg rolls and the corn on cob with siracha-based creamy sauce were both super tasty.  But the pork belly sandwich was only so-so.  We didn't even finish that.

Next time we will load up on more corn and egg rolls ...
author: Lewis C.

description: Decent Vietnamese food in Market St.  You will probably be wowed more by the décor than the actual food.  The whole restaurant is painted up in a revolutionary worker vibe with lots of big murals and a nice look.  What about the food?  It's good solid bahn mi - spicy lemongrass pork is good and so is the five spice chicken. I have had both the sandwiches and the Bun mee noodles and they are very good.  I think my only gripe is price: a bowl of noodles with pork and a lime soda (which was delicious!) set me back $17 for lunch.  Not exactly cheap.  You could probably do better at Freshroll or at a small Vietnamese restaurant.
author: David Z.

description: Lies, I tell you! Their board advertises that they have "happy hour" pricing for certain items M-F from 3-6pm, but I was charged regular prices anyway. #shady #fail
author: Vicente G.

description:
If you are gluten free beware. 

Ordered the Grilled Chicken Salad for pickup and the listed ingredients looked safe. Turns out they put some kind of fried wonton shavings on top of the salad but never listed it as an ingredient. 

All my coworkers love their food though and were very happy.
author: Elisabeth G.

description:
I am shocked to see bad reviews for this place.  My husband and I are very picky foodies and we both love Bun Mee -- we have only been there for dinner, so maybe at lunch with the business crowds things are busy and quality lapses.   

I love the sloppy beef sandwich and the sweet potato fries.   My husband has gotten the catfish many times (that tells you how good it is - he doesn't like to repeat order anything anywhere).  The chicken salad is also pretty good.   Additionally, delivery is really cheap for San Francisco.
author: Kelly M.

description: Excellent pork bahn mi sandwich. The bread was nicely toasted and the pork was the marinated grilled kind and not the sliced. Ingredients were all fresh and delicious. Wait time wasn't bad either. The only minus is the price. At 9$ for a sandwich it's not pricey compared to other places on market Street but usually bahn mi is very cheap.
author: Joe S.

description:
Bunno? Is it Mee yooou're eating forrr?
(dun duhduh duhdun)
'Cause I wonder hooow you taaaste!
And I wonder whaaat you cheeeew!
Are you somewhere spilling Sloppy,
(duhn dun dun)
Or is someone eating youuu?
(duh duh duh)
Tell me how to claim myyyy food,
For I haven't heeeeard my cuuue!
But let me start by orderiiiiiiing,
I Bun Yuu...
author: Dan B.

description:
This review is for Happy Hour (HH) only.  Draft beer is high quality and $3.  Lagunitas IPA, Firestone, and there was one more that I forgot.  Solid choices for a solid price.  I also got the HH fries with the meat and curry mayo sauce, SOLID for $3.  I took a seat by the window to people watch and relax.  I had some time to kill so I tried the catfish HH item they had and that was tasty as well.  $10 bones for a quality brew, a nice portion of meat covered fries, and a fried catfish appetizer = WIN.

I'm not a huge fan of Bun Mee and that is probably why I've never come here to eat at lunch.  I don't like fresh cilantro and am not huge on pickled veggies, so bun mee isn't really the type of food for mee. (sorry about the extra "e" but I had to...)

The interior is visually appealing and there is indoor and outdoor seating.  The indoor seating is sort of cramped when it is busy, but it wasn't busy when I stopped by on Friday after work.

Bun Mee isn't a happening place with any sort of scene for happy hour, but if you just want to chill and have a beer and a snack and you work downtown, definitely give it a try.
author: Ty C.

description:
Love this place. Plenty of veggie and vegan options. Good for pesatarin too. Also for meat eaters. 
Happy hour 3 pints. 5 buck sandwhiches. 
Nice staff
author: Shelby H.

description:
The sweet potatoes here are delicious! I love them and the sauce they come with. 

The sandwiches are mediocre. They're stuffed with a ton of veggies and only a couple pieces of meat. Bun Mee can't hold a candle to Saigon Sandwich, although not many places can. 

The service leaves much to be desired. I think I might have ordered from an expressionless robot, but I can't be sure. Some vending machines are nicer, they have happy flashing lights. 

I'd come back for the fries only.  I can't say my day was brightened by the sandwiches or service.
author: Nikki L.

description:
I have the option of ordering lunch from here every Wednesday through my work and have tried pretty much everything on their menu. I usually go with a bowl because with the sandwiches you tend to get a bite and a half of pure carrots+bread, a bite and a half of straight meat + bread, etc. 

I do like Bun Mee but only problem with them is that the quality of the meat is inconsistent. Sometimes the pork will be so flavorful and great cuts, other times you get stuck with bottom of the barrel pure fat wads in the bowl. The fries (both sweet potato and garlic) are alright but more times than not they'll come soggy/dripping with fat (which actually, suits me because I'm gross and love greasy food). I see other reviews claim the fries are crispy-maybe they're better if you dine in opposed to order take out?
author: Brieanna H.

description:
Good takeout lunch spot. Definitely better than the 3 stars it currently gets.

There was a huge line when I went but it moved quickly (was slightly out the door and took about 5 minutes to get to the front). Food came within a few minutes of ordering.

I got the juicy steak sandwich and it was great! The steak was plentiful and the bread was crusty and delicious. Plan to return and try the pork.
author: Sara M.

description:
Mixed experience for me.

My first reaction is "1/2 the flavor for 2x the price".

The fried egg rolls with fish sauce dip were excellent, nearly rivaling Tu Lan's version.  However the cost for two skinny rolls seemed too high.  These earned 3.5-4 stars.

The combo bahn mi (pate, grilled port, mortadella) was really bad, the roll was huge and tough, the meats were flavorless).  The pickled veggies were pretty good, though considering the huge sign on their wall that states "all sandwiches come with hot jalepenos unless you're a sissy" I was really let down to discover a few tiny slivers of de-seeded peppers in my sandwich.  The sandwich was one star for me.

This place was overflowing at lunch time when I visited, so people must like it pretty well.  The other menu options look good and the setting is very youthful and fun.  Perhaps if one is turned off by a dive Vietnamese place this is more one's speed.
author: Patrick S.

description: I found this place on Yelp and passed by this place a few times. They also have great vegetarian options so my friend wanted to try it it as well. I ordered the lychee strawberry drink, 5 spice chicken and shared the salt n pepper fries and sweet potato fries with my friends. The lychee strawberry drink was OK. Not as amazing as I thought it would be after hearing people raving about it on Yelp. It kinda tasted like strawberry lemonade. I didn't taste any lychee to it, other than the single piece of lychee fruit inside. The 5 spice chicken is pretty good - not bad but not amazing either. I've had better. The fries on the other hand, were pretty bomb! The sweet potato fries came with a red curry dipping sauce. The salt and pepper fries were nicely seasoned and they are very generous with their portions. However after awhile of eating the salt n pepper fries, I kind've got sick of the taste. It was nice to have some sweet potato fries in between - that, I did not get sick of. I do recommend it though, and I would order it again. I would like to try another item on the menu next time, or maybe I'll just order the fries..
author: Bailey L.

description:
I've tried Bun Mee at the Fillmore location was kinda meh, decided to try their new Fidi Location because it's convenient on Market near Montgomery Bart Station.

They got appetizers, rice, noodles, and the banh mi sandwiches.

I got Grilled pork bun mee w/ fried egg - it was just ok, made my stomach make funny rumbly noises after eating it so I don't know what was happening.  

B. got Pork w/ brown rice dish he seemed to like - it's Huge too.

He tried the salt & pepper fries $3 - he seemed to like them.

Charged it.  A bunch of seating, but probably not enough for the lunch crowd.

Hrs:
M-F 11-8
Sat 11:30-7
author: Ann L.

description: Very oily. Average quality. Nothing for everybody. The prices are okay. Especially during the happy hour from 3 till 6.
author: Marc B.

description: The blandest bahn mi I've tasted. Not god-awful, but really dialed low on flavor. The meats aren't seasoned enough, the picked carrot isn't sweet or bright enough, the cucumber just the same, and there was barely any cilantro. The whole magic of Vietnamese sandwiches are the brilliant contrast in very different flavors, these flavors are all muted. Plus they're way overpriced compared to actual Vietnamese-owned businesses. Go another few blocks towards the 'loin and get the real deal. Disappointing.
author: Andrew a.

description: I had the pork vermicelli bowl. The flavor was fine but the texture of the pork was mushy and gritty like clay and the noodles were undercooked and still hard. I couldn't finish it.
author: Chris C.

description: First time I visited this place I had their sandwiches.. I remember that I almost broke a tooth on chewing their beef.. the veggies were not fresh and the bun was so hard it almost hurt eating it. Today I decided to give this place another try. I choose the noodles dish. I thought that would be a safe choice, no Vietnamese had ever in my history of eating Vietnamese food, ever- EVER messed up this dish. I was flabbergasted. This place actually managed to. Again the meat was hard and had no flavor, the veggies tasted like they've been washed in dirty old water.. The noodles had absolutely no flavor whatsoever- the fishsauce was non-existent. To be perfectly honest, I have better things to do at the moment than write this ***** review. But when you mess with my food so bad that I have to throw the whole thing out, I will mess you up lol. DO NOT EAT HERE.
author: Kira U.

description: Wow!  This was the best meal I had while visiting San Francisco and I ate at some five star restaurants.  I came across this place on a whim while waking to the Ferry building. The line was out the door so I figured it had to be good. Decided to stop back the next day before the lunch rush and I was the only one in line.  I got the belly bun and sweet potatoes fries and boy was it good. The pork belly bun was so juicy and mouthwatering. The fries were great as well for a fast food joint. I was completely satisfied and would request that as my last meal
author: T W.

description:
Tofu sandwich was amazing. Yummmmm! 

The flavour and spice level was exactly what I like in a good sandwich. The bread was crisp. I want to eat this every single day. 

My work had this delivered to us, can't wait to go in person
author: Amanda M.

description:
Maybe any type of fusion just won't work for me....

Vietnamese food is a bit of a rare thing when you're in FiDi and don't want to march to Chinatown for it.  Fusion V food? Let's give it a try.

I ordered their Saigon peanut rice bowl for lunch. The line wasn't too long, not out the door and whatnot. The wait for the food wasn't too bad either. The place reminds me of Super Duper mixed in with Obey shirts. I didn't dine in, so can't tell you how long the wait for table would be and such. 

For $10 lunch, this better be decent. Nope, not for my taste. The idea is nice, has that healthy option we-the-people-who-sit-all-day-everyday would love. My bowl has the option for brown rice. Need that fiber. I would say the taste is just a bit lacking. I expected aromatic nutty smell of that peanut sauce as I would have gotten at a typical Vietnamese place. I drenched my dish with the sauce and just had soggy rice with veggies, just not much flavors. That $10 just wasn't worth my laziness. 

Perhaps I should have tried their sandwiches instead? Who knows. If I decide to step into the store in the future, I'll give it a try. As of right now, Vietnamese fusion is just not my thing.
author: Connie C.

description: Tastes pretty good to me, better than the "authentic" Vietnamese sandwiches. I think this is more flavorful. Can't speak to the price because I got this catered for my work. But strictly speaking taste wise, I like! Had thought it was over hyped, but now I don't think so.
author: Jennifer W.

description:
Here's the thing - I love bahn mi, and this place ain't it. I am actually not sure how they are making rent each month at their awesomely convenient location. Probably tourists, actually definitely tourists. Because they don't know any better.

The bread was good - but not good bahn mi bread. The veggies were fresh, but bland, not nearly enough pickling flavor.

The fries were meh - I really dont get the point of throwing raw sliced jalepenos on the fries. Maybe the grocer had a sale on jalepenos and bun mee had a surplus with nothing to do with them. Not enough salt or pepper.

The decor is extremely strange - why the cafe du monde tins? Like what does faux, terrible Vietnamese sandwiches have to do with New Orleans coffee? And why the wallpaper? 

The experience was so odd, but I could have let it slide if the sandwiches were good. I could have even forgiven the price - which is like double the price of what a bahn mi should be, if the sandwiches were good. But they weren't. So now I am here lamenting on yelp.
author: Meena Y.

description: A few months ago when I worked near Chinatown, I would grab a bahn mi every day for lunch because it was cheap ($3) and filling. When I came to Bun Mee, I was a bit surprised that the price of a sandwich was more than double of what I'm used to. I don't understand why so many food blogs rave that Bun Mee offers the best bahn mi in the city because it does not! It certainly is the most hipster looking location that offers a bahn mi, but it is definitely not the best. The catfish bahn mi is not something I've tried before, but it was quite tasty. Hard to go wrong with fried fish. Would I come here again for a bahn mi? Probably not. Was it a good experience? Not bad.
author: Austin W.

description: This place is so incredibly delicious. Happy hour wine is excellent and the food is just amazing. Highly recommend!
author: Peter M.

description: I don't know if they add MSG to the food or what, but my daughter and I both felt really ill almost immediately after eating here. The bun dish wasn't bad but I will not be returning here.
author: Steve K.

description:
I seriously was gonna reject this place when I saw the ratings, but because of my hungry friends and me, I gave this place a chance. I don't understand why there's such low and negative reviews on this place. The sandwich I had was really good! It was the combo sandwich, which consisted of pork and......pate (pat-tay)! It did look small, but it was stuffed with a decent amount of fillings! The veggies were fresh and the meat was so flavorful and appetizing. Not dry at all. It may look hard to eat, but it was nice and crunchy, but soft in the inside of the bread. 7-8 bucks for the sandwich, but it was so worth it to me. They also have options for vegetarians, Oh, and don't go without ordering sweet potato fries, which they give you a lot of for 3 bucks! Seasoned with salt and pepper with yummy savory sauce on the side.

As for the service......AWESOME. They bring your food to you if you eat in. The cashier  offered to bring my sandwich to the table we were about to go change our seat at. There's also someone who clears your food/trash right away once you're done! Such fast service! Definitely coming to this place again, if I crave for vietnamese sandwiches around this area, but probably not if there are other places that offer them for cheaper like they normally are.
author: Tina R.

description:
Juicy Steak and Salt 'n' Pepper Garlic Fries w/ Limonata! Sounds good yeah?! Actually the bread/roll was the best part (key to a good Bánh mì)
 Except the fries had been sitting . Were cold. Took 'em back. Had the feeling they just dumped 'em back in the oil...a little too quick and crispy. Beware the fries...first time not a good impression. 
Call me picky but when there's a breach of trust, however small, it just puts a damper on the experience.
Quite a few 20 something's working there and only one asked if the fries were OK (like "wonder if that old ******knows " the rest seemed like they couldn't really be involved...
Fix your front end Bun Mee.
author: Owen R.

description:
Not the worst bahn mi I've had, but definitely not the best, especially for the price. I had just finished drinks with my mom and her friend up the street at Rickhouse when I ran into my friend and we went to grab a quick dinner. We started walking toward the Westfield to check out the vast food court, but then I spotted Bun Mee and remembered I'd been wanting to try it.

Off the bat, it gave me the generic up-and-coming vibe that I have been getting from other Financial Dist eateries (360 Burrito Express, Mixt Greens, Verde, etc) so I was a little turned off. What ever happened to mom 'n pop shops? Rent, I suppose. The whole place feels a bit stale.

Anyhow, we both got the Five Spice Chicken bahn mi and an order of the Salt and Pepper Garlic Fries. It was around $18 for the whole meal, which I think is pricey for bahn mi, and I don't think you would disagree with me. The sandwiches were just OK, nothing special and the meat was honestly pretty gristly and lacking flavor. The "Garlic" Fries had more onions and jalepenos than I would think come on garlic fries. They were alright, nothing spesh, and odd that there was no garlic to be found.

A large red beam behind the cash register claims that every sandwich is served with jalepenos and if you don't eat them you're sissy (good one) but I asked for extra jalepenos, and was given maybe four slices on my whole sandwich. It's become customary for me to just ask no less than three times for extra jalepenos, which makes me feel like a dick, but whatevs. I will say I appreciate that they have a big bottle of Sriracha on every table so you don't have to run all over the place trying to obtain the spicy sauce.

Will I be back? Probabyl. I love bahn mi and maybe it was an off day for both of us.
author: Crystal C.

description: The music in your restaurant is ridiculously loud. See the awesome photo of the hot tea I ordered (I said it twice, in fact). It's the coldest hot tea I've ever had (due to the ice). Your cashier could't even hear me, and I had to ask her to repeat herself every time she said something and still could barely make out what she said. The sandwich was your typical overpriced bahn mi that you can buy down the street for less than half the price. You're so rock n' roll with your loud music and Shepard Fairey propaganda knockoff art. Truly edgy.
author: Jennifer W.

description:
I've been meaning to try this place and after a long day of work I figured I'd treat myself to a sando. Stopped in and instantly was drawn in by the decor; Awesome modern wallpaper and cool dangling lights. Also playing was some seriously funky hip hop and r&b, which got me in a great mood after being stuck at a cube all day. *insert sprinkler dance here*

They have happy hour from 3-6 and the prices are much more fair. I think regular prices are a little too high. I ordered a combo banh mi and chilli cheese fries.... 

The sandwich: $5 (happy hour price). decent sized. Really warm and toasty French bread. Usually French bread is really stiff but it was very easy to bite into. It came with ham, beef and pate. There was only two really thin slices of ham but it was overflowing with beef. The meat had a special kick that made it different from traditional viet sandos. It was kind of like a mix of BBQ beef and carne asada flavor. There was a perfect amount of pickled carrots and daikon so it didn't overpower the flavor of the meat. Overall, I give it a 4 out of 5.

The fries: $3 (happy hour price) crispy, every one of them. Normally a lot will be soggy after a while but these were great. The chilli was really interesting...pretty different from any I've tried before. I believe they add lemon grass in it. Sounds kind of weird but it was actually added a really cool kick. It also had tons of ground beef and jalapeños and the size was fair. I give it a 3 1/2 out of 5 because I still like traditional chili better.

The service: this has more of a fast food feel  but at least they bring your food to your table. The person who brought out the food had great customer service. He was very pleasant smiled a lot and thanked us when he brought the food and when he picked it up. I felt like a valued customer.

Id definitely eat here again during lunch or if I'm in need of something quick after work.
author: Graci B.

description:
No, thanks. 

Overpriced, under-portioned servings of what should be very affordable entrees coupled with way-too-long lines and bored, inattentive staff. My co-worker and I decided to try this place for a farewell lunch. I think I got the Caramel Caramel Citrus Rice Bowl, and it was a bland dish of white rice, some slices of random fruits and veggies, and about two pieces of tofu. I honestly can't remember any flavor beyond the inherent ones in the produce slices. We also tried the house-made kaffir limeade, which was basically lemonade marked up by $2.
author: Josephine L.

description: Back in January of this year, I decided to try Bun mee and grab a Lemongrass pork bahn mi ($6.75) with Pate (+$1). When I got back to the office and unwrapped the sandwich, I saw it had a good meat & veggie filling to bread ratio. It went downhill from there. When I bit into the sandwich I didn't get the nice pickled flavors from the veggies. Part of the deliciousness of a bahn mi for me is the savoriness of the meat and the creaminess of the pate contrasted with the crunchy pickled veggies and the spiciness of the jalapenos and sriracha I put on it. This was missing that. And for $8, I expected more.
author: Elena N.

description:
I always feel like somebody's watching me...

I feel ya, Rockwell.  Last night, two of my best girl friends and I, ended up sitting at the table right in between the menu on the right wall, and people lining up along the left wall to place their orders.  I happened to be facing the left wall, and so tried my best to quiet my super self-conscious inner tween.  "It's ok, Iona.  All these strangers are not judging you for stuffing five fries into your mouth at once.  No, they're not disgusted at the sight of half-masticated bits and pieces of lemongrass pork falling from your gaping pie-hole."  Vicious.

Self-talk aside, I enjoyed catching up with my friends over our $7 banh mis, and $4 shared side of salt 'n pepper garlic fries.  All of us knew that we were paying twice as much for the sandwiches, but this joint is right on Market Street in downtown SF.  Let's not even speculate on what they're paying for rent.

The bread does not scrape the roof of your mouth, the meat (lemongrass pork for me!) is flavorful, the jalapenos and cilantro come sprinkled on top of all the pickled carrots and daikon (do chua) so it's easy to brush off if you forgot to modify your order... but the do chua was just too sour for me.  Every other time I've gotten banh mi at some mom and pop, or at Lee's, the carrots and daikon had a better, in my opinion at least, sugar to vinegar ratio.  The veggies here gave me an experience on par with the first 10-seconds of a Warhead candy.  Bru-tal.  They really give you a thick layer of the stuff, so I just saved my face some fine-line creating moments and scraped most of it off.  (Note: If you order your banh mi to go, they give you much less do chua so that they can wrap it all nice and neat.  Yes, you are, in a sense, getting jipped... but that's probably the proper ratio of the sour stuff anywho.)

The man at the front who took my order gave me the option of going without jalapenos on my fries, but I was feeling daring so I told him to keep them in there.  Honestly, they didn't really impart much flavor or heat to the fries.  Moreover, I don't think the fries had much of a salt 'n pepper flava anyhow.  Totes not a memorable side dish.  I will probably skip this and save myself $4 next time around.

All in all, Bun Mee is a decent lunch and dinner option.  It's pretty fast, there's indoor and outdoor seating, and your meal should cost you between $8-15 depending on whether you just go with banh mi, or if you'd like sides, drinks, etc.  I really love the interior (the lighting especially!) and it was a pretty great spot to just sit and chill for dinner Tuesday night.
author: Iona C.

description:
Bunmee has fantastic sandwiches and I love to enjoy myself when I grab a sandwich for the road.

Unfortunately, I have had incidents of problematic allergic reactions when eating their food here. At first I thought it was reactions to the pickles veggies and daikon (which I had never eaten before this restaurant). But then it came to my realization that I might have been having severe reactions to avocado, which are in a handful of their sandwiches (but the chefs could cut the meat or bread with the same knives in between orders, resulting in not washed in between and said reactions).

To say that I risk my feeble life just for a quick bite is almost worth it, but I do hope that my reactions don't put me in the hospital in the near future because of these allergic reactions.
author: A. R. G.

description:
I know BunMee's from Hamburg. There is only one place, and i never heard about that before. It's operated by two germans that love vietnam. If you ever get there look out for a place called Nananamai. 

So but what to say about this place. Bun Mee is an awesome kind of Food. I really love it and so i also liked those they served here, but i got to say in comparison to the taste i get in Hamburg this was mediocre only. The meet was a bit dry and overall i missed the taste explosion in my mouth i am used to.
author: Dietmar K.

description:
Got the Lemongrass Pork Sandwich.  Pork was good and seasoned.  Definitely Jalepenos.  

Came with pickled carrots, cilantro and daikon radish. Also, pâté.  I added siracha and sat outside to watch all the weirdos and super-important people walk by.  

Expensive for a bahn mi, but still tasty, so
Four Stars
author: George P.

description:
I tend to be skeptical when it comes to trendy ethnic food places. I know, it's kinda unfair, but if I'm going to get, for example, a banh mi, my first thought wouldn't be to go to the financial district to look for a good banh mi spot. However, after being tempted by the very cheery facade time and again, I finally stopped in today to see what all the lines going out the door were all about.

Miraculously, during the lunch rush I managed to be second in line, which didn't give me much time to peruse the sizable menu (plus I wanted to see what noodles people around me were slurping up and making look very delicious), but I settled quickly on the 5 spice chicken banh mi with jalapeños, an order of the egg rolls, and an iced tea. It's extremely loud near the counter so the girl got my name wrong, which caused a bit of confusion during the pick-up process, but otherwise the very hectic atmosphere in here is more organized than it seems. 

Had I known the iced tea came with lemon slices in it I would've asked them to not put them in my tea before it gave my drink just a hint of that sour that you can feel in the back of your throat that I hate, but otherwise the iced tea has a great flavor that seems almost like it's got a hint of fruitiness. As for the banh mi? Wow. Just delicious. I didn't come here expecting what I've had in Vietnamese banh mi shops, but this was very tasty in it's own right. Not only is the amount of chicken generous, which I frankly wasn't expecting, but the sandwich is by no means skimpy in its size, and the mix of fresh veggies, jalapeño, and cilantro were right on point. But the star for me - and yes, I can't believe they outshone the sandwich itself - were the egg rolls. I couldn't get enough of them, and the fact that they're diagonally sliced into two pieces per roll makes eating them at your desk easier. I'm not saying the sandwich was at all bad, I just found myself wanting the egg rolls even more because they were that good.

I would love to eat here all the time. The problem was the price tag: over $15 for my meal. Granted, the size, freshness, and quality of everything can't be denied, but there's no way I'd spend that much for lunch on myself everyday. This is maybe a once to twice a week splurge, but as good as everything was I wouldn't want to pay that much every time. 

Really great food, fast service even despite the mass of people waiting for lunch, but the price tag for just one person knocks off a star for me - if I can get a quality, authentic, banh mi the same size, if not bigger, with even more meat for a fraction of the price in a hole in the wall, maybe Bun Mee can try, too. But overall, great.
author: Angela M.

description:
I was trying to decide between the lemongrass pork and the pork belly, ended up asking the 2 cashiers; 1 said pork belly, the other said lemongrass..that made my decision a whole lot easier..I ended up getting the lemongrass pork since it's their number 1 seller.

Twas was divine.  Bread was good, pickled veggies were good, meat was good, house mayo was bomb...it's all good.  Tip: add an egg and get more of that protein!

Staff was friendly, place is clean, and it's a good price for being in the city.
author: Emmeline C.

description:
I'm hooked. I love the 5 spice chicken sandwich, with avocado and a fried egg. Mmmmm. I have yet to try anything else, but I'm sure everything is delicious.

I've also tried the Fillmore location, and the food is just as tasty there. :)
author: Melissa S.

description:
Got the citrus bowl why tofu and no sauce to make it gluten free. Love the combination! Jalapeño, avocado, sprouts, plus orange and grapefruit sections on a bed of brown rice. SO good! Large portion, more than enough food for me. Took it to go as well. Pretty fast service. 

Good tasted great and felt like a really healthy and clean option. 

Didn't try any of their sandwiches but have heard good things.
author: Roya N.

description:
Good sized portions for the price. Pickled veggies just tasted like... veggies. Chicken was tasty, but the pickled veggies are the most important part of a Bahn Mi sandwich. Crispy tofu was not crispy and tasted like pretty much nothing. 

Sweet potato fries were decent, but quite salty.
author: Joshua C.

description:
I was pretty disappointed in this place. The bánh mì was mediocre - there were way too many shredded carrots and vegetables, not enough meat, and the cilantro and jalapeno pieces were relatively nonexistent. Yes, they ACTUALLY ask you if you want jalapeños on your bánh mì. 

I'd have to say, the best thing that I ordered was the strawberry lemonade lychee - it was deliciously refreshing, sweet, and just slightly tangy. 

Total price? For two sandwiches, two drinks, and one set of summer rolls, the total came $27+tip. *eye roll* Sorry Bun Mee, next time I'm heading over to Saigon Sandwiches in the TL. If SS is closed, Dinosaurs in the Castro is the next best option.
author: Peter C.

description:
I am shocked at how stale the bread is given that they opened recently, and bread is the primary component of their restaurant specialty. 

Bun Mee's claim to fame is their innovative combinations of Vietnamese sandwiches. As a local chain recently expanded to 3 (?) locations, I figured there must be something redeeming in their sandwiches. But the sandwich was poor in flavor, freshness, and value. I ordered the sloppy sandwich, which was a good idea (curry ground beef) poorly executed.  

The iced coffee is premixed and way too sweet - for the price (~$3.50) I could have purchased a much more delicious banh mi at Saigon Sandwiches. 

The lines get crazy at noon. The prices are high. The flavors are not unique and the sandwiches are not good. Sorry bun mee, but this has been one of the most disappointing meals I've had in San Francisco in as long as I can remember.
author: Jess C.

description: I really enjoyed my Belly Bun Sandwich w/ garlic salt & pepper fries.  The sandwich was crunchy, soft & oozing with goodness!  I didn't taste too much garlic in the fries, mostly salt & pepper though.  Since it's SF, i guess a $7 sandwich is ok.  Don't forget the Thai Ice tea..it comes in a can but soooo good with some ice.
author: Melanie N.

description:
My boyfriend led me here yesterday on our way to an event in the financial district.  I'm not really from around here or a fan of public transportation, but I thought it was really cool how this location is like right there when you get off the BART.  Convenient!!

We ordered a crispy tofu sandwich (for him, of course), a lemongrass pork sandwich + a $1 pate add on (a must try), and fries to share.  This came out to almost $20, which I thought was pretty expensive to begin with.  When these sandwiches were brought to our table, I remember thinking that this better be the BEST Vietnamese sandwich I've ever had in my life because it was TINY.  As a Vietnamese girl from San Jose, I didn't have very high hopes for this place, but it ended up really surprising me.  Don't get me wrong, it was unexpectedly delicious.  I just wish there had been more of it...  

So I'm writing this review to debunk the rumors that this place isn't authentic/good because it is, despite the Americanized setting, I promise! :)
author: Beverly T.

description:
STAY AWAY!  They have a VERY FLAWED order system. It's a disaster waiting to happen.

Loud music + yelling out first names for orders = MAJOR FAIL

Bun Mee takes orders and gives them out by first name and blast loud music on par with a club. Once you leave the restaurant, it's a day and night difference of noise level.

I ordered a combination sandwich with garlic fries. Waited over 20 minutes before I asked what was up with my order. Apparently, some guy with the same name took my order. THE RECEIPT HAS THE FOOD ORDER ON THERE! So... they offered me his pork sandwich order and added garlic fries to it. Quite pissed, I left with the sandwich.

Food-wise. The sandwich is quite small for ~$7. Got a grilled pork sandwich instead of combination sandwich. That's enough said about the sandwich. Garlic fries were the suck. Stringy fries. Small Portions. Where's the garlic? It's not worth the ~$3.

Overall: Trendy place with overpriced food.

P.S. Bun is noodles. /facepalm
author: Steven B.

description:
At times its hard to find a legit Vietnamese sandwich shop that has good food. This place isnt amazing but it is pretty good. First time i got  the 5 Spice Chicken sandwich and it was amazing however the past two times i got it it has been very very dry.

Their sweet potato fries are pretty good with the sauce.

Spring rolls are really good but pricey.
author: Nina M.

description:
I wasn't gonna say anything but this is the second time in a row I've gotten the Sloppy Bun and it appears to be entirely missing the red curry sauce that made it so delicious and sloppy. This is just slightly dry ground beef in a roll. The last time it happened I figured "hey, everyone makes mistakes" but since this has happened twice now I'm inclined to think that they've changed the recipe and removed the red curry that made these sandwiches so tasty. 
Sidenote: whenever I order "no jalapenos" I always get jalapenos but if I don't say anything I get jalapenos about half the time. Weird.
author: Skeptical Spee ..

description:
So I really liked this spot - until I started getting into my food. 

It has had a seriously good design done for it - very funky decor and overall look that pulled me in from the street, and a really well laid out interior.

The staff are super happy and friendly - again, a massive plus in my book (so much so, that this staff is really what I gave the three stars for.

Now the food. I ordered the chicken salad. It sounded amazing, with jalapeño peppers, fresh mint, roasted peanuts, lime vinaigrette, etc.

So, first a word on the chicken - while it wasn't that awful processed stuff that you get in a lot of places, it was pretty shoddy quality. Slimy in parts and gristly in others. Not pleasurable to chomp into; put it that way!  I didn't get a single jalapeño which was super sad times, I don't remember any mint being in there either, and very few peanuts. It was basically a fair amount of slimy chicken with lots and lots of grated carrots (not julienned) and lettuce. 

All in all, was disappointing, as I'd fully hoped to like it wayyyy more.
author: Emily C.

description:
I'm between 3 and 4 stars on this place, but I'm rounding down to 3 stars. But there aren't a ton of ethnic places in the area, so I welcome this new addition to the neighborhood.

A couple of negatives:
- The lines are long. I had an early lunch at 11:45 so the line was short and I was able to get a table. by the time it hit 12:15, the line was out the door.
- It's not cheap. Bun for $12? Can't do it. Banh mi for $7? Definitely the most expensive banh mi I've had...

All that being said, the sandwich was decent-sized and pretty tasty.
author: Wendy L.

description:
This place is always packed so I stumbled in today knowing I wouldn't have to wait long since everyone is out of town this week . . . 

On that note, the lemongrass pork sandwich with a dash of hot sriracha sauce on each half man oh man I didn't want this experience to end. The grilled pork was so delicious, the spice, the mayo and warm and crispy baguette . . . I will be back!!!!!
author: Jenny B.

description:
We had a mix of banh mi sandwiches: Hanoi-Style Crispy Catfish, Crispy Tofu, Grilled Five Spice Chicken, and Grilled Lemongrass Pork.  There was also an order of Mango Sesame Salad.  All the sandwiches looked great.  I personally had the pork, tofu and chicken.  

The ingredients were really fresh and had the right amount of spiciness from the jalapenos slices.  It was not overwhelming and allowed you to add sriracha if you needed more heat. The only downside was the bread.  It was a bit more soft and spongy compared to the typical banh mi sandwich bread.

I could have probably done without the mango salad.  Good banh mi sandwiches.
author: G M.

description: Love the concept of this place. Love the decor and atmosphere. Great location and food is good. Although I have had comparable banh mi for less in not so trendy restaurants in the city. But again ... I did like this place and scarfed down the banh mi I ordered - Bun Mee Combo. I'm a sucker for banh mi and always looking for a place wherever I travel. I'd come back and try another sandwich ... maybe the Belly Bun or Grilled Lemongrass Pork. My mouth is watering already.
author: Rovi D.

description: Unlike so many attempts to get food in a timely manner, this place actually arrived ON TIME, and the delivery dude was really nice.  Love when a restaurant does what they say they will!
author: Amber R.

description:
Bun Mee? Bun Yoo!! Bun yo self ...

While the interior design is visually impressive - functionally it leaves much to be desired. The menu is at a very non intuitive location - to the right and behind the customer - not behind the cashiers; this makes no sense.  The drinks cooler is also behind the customer.  The "bar" seats and bar space are rather uncomfortable due to bar length, width, and seat arrangement.

The food - to date i had 3 of their sandwiches - "the combo" an ok selection, the meat items were tasty, and veggie items were sweet, the baguette roll was very good however for the money id say the value is not there.

Second "the belly bun" - which - being a huge fan of pork belly i would not recommend at Bun Mee. The way its prepared - makes the magical pork belly at best "inoffensive". Forgettable pork belly is a fail, because this ingredient - is like bacon - has the potential to drastically improve every dish. Not here though.

Third - and the best - is the sloppy bun - a bahn mi version of sloppy joe. Savory delicious ground beef, works perfectly with peppers, cilantro and the fried egg. If you're not a vegetarian this is the item to get.

Staff looks a bit lost and spaced out, and did not strike me as interested in maximum efficiency and movement of customers during the lunch rush. Considering this is FiDi - if i ran a sandwich joint - id do everything i could to optimize the operations between hrs 11 and 2. Simple things like busing the tables is slow, and self busing is not really optimized. Having said that - its a brand new place so maybe they're still working out the processes. 

PS on subsequent visits when it was a bit less impacted the staff kept up with the flow better.
author: Oleg H.
