description: Bun Mee has good food and if I'm in a rush it's my go-to place for lunch. There's nothing overly special about it. The flavors are okay, but not amazing. I always end up covering it in sriracha, which is a bit disappointing. I feel like a dish should be able to stand on its own without any added sauces.
author: Ashley Q.

description:
I was traveling on business for Oracle Open World.  This is located across the street from the Palace Hotel, where a bunch of my sessions were held.  My box lunches were such a hassle and ordeal and just totally unappealing that I told myself I was going to treat myself to an awesome lunch to make up for it.  Bun Mee did not disappoint!

I ordered the lemongrass pork bun me and an order of garlic fries.  I was so looking forward to this meal.  There is seating in the restaurant, and even a few tables outside but it was in the direct sun and SF was having a freak heat wave.  I walked over towards Yerba Buena Gardens to find a better picnic spot.  I was going crazy because the smells were wafting and I could only manage a few fries so I just kept walking faster!

One interesting thing is that the jalepeno chilis were so powerful in the sandwich that I had to pick most of it off as my lips were on fire.  But the same chilis in the fries did nothing for the flavor.  The fries definitely could have used a kick.  I should have dropped the picked off chilis into the fries but gave up.  It was a very yummy meal!
author: Maria K.

description: It's a bit much for what it is, but the location and the space itself deserves an extra star. It's a good starter Bahn Mi for first timers, but there are others in the city that I prefer. But like I said, the space is nice and a good choice for a quick meal.
author: Theresa D.

description:
FIRST IMPRESSIONS
First off, their location and in-store design is great. They have a small outdoor seating area and an array of tables inside their brick and mortar for you to sit. It's a bit of a squeeze though, especially during the lunch hour when there are lots of patrons from the Financial district and people ordering to-go. It can be a little crowded, but the table turnover is pretty quick. 

FOOD
The menu isn't overly complicated, but offers plenty of options to customize your order with various add-ons like substituting your meat, adding an egg, etc. Each of these add-ons has a cost, and they can pile up pretty quick. Their menu is split between Sandwiches, Bowls, & Salads - and any sides you might want. While the menu variety is great, the food is only a little above average. They have the right idea, but are a little rough in the execution. Nothing is mind blowing, but it's all quality food. Having said that, I don't think it's worth the price you pay. Maybe I'm just not used to SF pricing yet (I'm from Austin, TX), but $13 for a B+ grade noodle bowl is a little excessive. Still though, I recommend getting the Belly Bun and the 

SERVICE
Not much to say about the service. If you order to-go, you just wait for them to call your name. They have a runner who brings your food if you decide to take a seat in the cramped quarters.

FINAL TAKE
Pretty expensive for what I considered to be fairly average Vietnamese food. Better off going somewhere else for lunch and saving your Vietnamese craving for a really good sit down meal.
author: Zi-on C.

description: This place is delicious and fantastic. I often make lunch and dinner meetings here because it's delicious but not too fancy.
author: Beau B.

description:
Great! Very fresh and packed with flavor. This place and the staff deserve FIVE STARS in my opinion. 
I recommend a fried egg with every sandwich and also avocado if you like more creamy goodness.

Enjoy!!!
author: Erran A.

description:
Love it! The fries are especially amazing.
I love the citrus bowl and Saigon peanut bowl!
author: Namrata J.

description: Absolutely amazing finger foods and so aesthetically perfect as well! Was perfect for catering our Branding Workshop in SF this February. Such a pleasure to work with this shop and we couldn't have been more happier (our tummies too).
author: Bloguettes B.

description:
Came here during a group team lunch in celebration of a new team member. I love Vietnamese sandwiches and this place is delicious, fresh, and delightful. I ordered the 5 spice chicken "Bun Mee" sandwich with a side of sweet potato fries. The sandwich was pretty good, the chicken on it's own was lacking a little of the "5 spice" i was expecting to taste. But the veggies were delicious and the sweet potato fries were amazing, especially with the sauce it came with. What i loved about the fries were that they were still crisp and delicious by the time they got cold. 

I'd like to come back and try the other stuff on their menu.
author: Rehana K.

description:
Best service, really good sandwiches. 
I messed up on my online order/deliver and they took care of it really quickly! 

Thank you guys!
author: Juliana P.

description:
This place, is, so, so, so loud.  And crowded.

Tasty vietnamese-ish sandwiches.  Delicious pork belly.  Messy fingers after.

TOO LOUD.  Not very good for groups.  If I came here again it would be for takeout.  

Also, my friend got the sloppy bun, which apparently does not come with the fixings like cucumber and carrot that you expect it to based on the menu on the side of the wall!  Luckily when he asked about it, they put it in for them, but they should have clearly stated that in the menu.
author: Esther S.

description:
I definitely have to agree with other Yelpers on this one. The place looks perfect from the outside-- the decor is simple and elegant, and the menu looks awesome. I couldn't decide what to order, and I ended up going with the "Five Spice" Chicken Sandwich and a Coconut Water. The employees were friendly at first, but it seemed like they were confused and discombobulated. 

The cashier brought my sandwich to the table. As I picked it up, I was excited to bite in. However, my expectations were squashed when I took my first bite. The so-called "Five Spices" were completely absent, and like other Yelpers mentioned, the overall quality of all the ingredients was low. There were sticks of herbs that were obviously old and brown (yuck!). The chicken was chewy and low quality. I ended up eating most of the sandwich since I was starving. 

I noticed about halfway through the meal that they had forgotten my coconut water. The employees seemed busy and occupied, and never came to check on me. As hard as it was, I decided to leave without even sampling the pricey coconut water.

Head elsewhere for lunch!
author: Jackson L.

description: This is definitely not my cup of tea. The design of the shop is very creative (hipster) which is cool. HOWEVER the sandwiches are overpriced and doesn't taste good. I would rather go to banh mi ba li in Oakland CA.
author: Master R.

description: I haven't had a banh mi, since the disappearance of the Nom Nom truck. I loved Nom Nom. This place caught my eye because of the clever name. I thought it was cute. The price are about the standard of any banh mi. I got excited at the fact that you can add avocado to your banh mi. I don't know if other spots offer this, but I love avocado on sandwiches. Upon first bite, I was impressed. Unfortunately, it didn't blow me away. It doesn't fill the void left by the Nom Nom truck. On the upside, I'll definitely be back, the next time I want a banh mi.
author: David C.

description:
Food was ok not anything to rave about . Vietnamese coffee  was way  too sweet.. Asked for  a bag to go and was told it was 10 cents of which I did not have because I paid with a card..the guy told me "well too bad it is what it is". Bad service
rude staff
author: Diana D.

description:
Overall: The place gets really crowded during lunch, so come early! They accept cards! They have seating inside (very noisy) and outside (patio setting). 

Food: I ordered the 5 spice chicken sandwich, salt and pepper fries, and house strawberry lychee drink.  The portions were satisfying.  I will try something else next time.
author: Stephanie Y.

description:
I really want to see a great banh mi place near union square. I've been here several times hoping that it would be good but won't return after this experience. Stale bread, a small amount of meat that was cooked a long time ago, and a rubbery over-easy egg with pieces of shell in it just slapped on the outside of the sandwich, causing the bread to get soggy. I get that there are lines out the door but for a $10 banh mi you really need to tighten up your process. I would have waited an extra 2 minutes if it meant my sandwich would have been prepared well.

Cool atmosphere, great location, but the food is just not there. 

Right after posting the review I was contemplating throwing away the sandwich or just sucking it up and eating it. When I was repositioning the egg to actually sit inside the sandwich I noticed that in my first few bites I had eaten a bunch of raw egg white. Awesome.
author: G R.

description:
Fresh ingredients, innovative banh mi sandwiches, great decor. This place is a hit for all the busy lunch-goers in FiDi. I loved their catfish sandwich. The light curry sauce really complimented the catfish, and the batter was light, not overly greesy. Not bad for an $8 lunch. 
If you want pho or bun, I would recommend heading few blocks west to any of the mom and pop Viet places, which are better and cheaper. As for bahn mi, you can't beat the quality and convenience of this place!
author: Nancy Z.

description: Ordered the combo bahn mi with egg and sweet potato fries for lunch. The sandwich was huge and a little hard to eat, but the yolky egg on top makes it get progressively more delicious. Next time I'm going to try the pork belly!
author: Allison D.

description:
I like that place cause I can order from my desk and pick up the food pretty quickly.

BUT there is often some mistake with what I ordered: forgot to put the water bottle or wrong sandwich.

The food is good tough, I love tofu and their sandwich are tasty. The only thing I would not recommend are the ramen: not tasty at all.
author: Tarek A.

description: Great selections. American fushion banh Mis. A bit pricey for banh mi but thus is SF. Nice and crispy French me and steak marinated meat blends well with the banh MI toppings.
author: thanh h.

description:
Very good alternative to something like subway or another "american" sandwich chain for lunch.

Prices for sandwiches range from $6-9 and they taste pretty darn good.

I had a combo sandwich for lunch and it was really good, but it had a faint liver aftertaste for those that are not into that type of thing be aware.

Overall I'd say it is a great place, that is likely no where near authentic because it actually tastes good.

Another tip the Market St location tends to get really crowded from 11.45-12.45pm so plan around that if you want to be in/out in less than 5min.
author: Max N.

description:
So went here for lunch and the line was out the door. So I asked one of the servers how long it would take to order. Will was his name, and he made a bet with me if I wasn't at the front within 10 minutes, he'd pay for my food. 

I thought "hey free lunch!" But long story short, I had to pay for my own lunch with about 2 minutes to spare. 

This place has great service! Friendly staff. Love the branding and design of the interior. The food is good too, only thing is that I wish it wasn't so pricey for banh mi.
author: Ashley N.

description:
I like Bun Mee, but I only ever get one thing anymore, which is the Belly Bun. Juicy Kurobuta pork, crisp, slightly picked carrots & daikon, with extra jalapeno.  Works for me.  And the price is fair for downtown (for this particular sandwich, in my opinion), although maybe its a little steep for a Vietnamese sandwich in general.  

I can see why some people complain.  The noodle bowls seem a little on the higher side when in comes to price (usually ends up somewhere around $13 based upon my lunch companions purchases).  Thats for noodles, when by comparison, I get a lot more pork in my sandwich for about 60% of the price.  Also, I had the combo sandwich once.  It was just ok (chewy meat, chewy bread, kind of hard to eat).  I'll pass on it from here on out. 

I have yet to try the happy hour, but it looks like a deal from the posted prices.  Would definitely come here to give it a try, unless there are a bunch of douche tech bros who end up crowding and ruining it, like they have everything else in this city.  Oh how I long for the days of 2007 - 2010, but I digress.

Anyway, Bun Mee gets high remarks from me, if only because I think they do one thing well.
author: T. G.

description: I love this place. Yea, it's a bit overpriced for what banmi is supposed to cost, but I think this place qualifies for gormet banmi if you will. If you're getting just regular banmi fixings it might not be worth it and you should just go down market a little more to get cheap good banmi from the mom and pops corner store "cafe Dolci" BUT, their sloppy joe banmi and their 5 spice chicken banmi makes the price very justifiable. You Have to get their jalapeño tossed fries for your side while you're ordering
author: Michelle D.

description: Quick to take your money but don't expect to get your food without reminded them you paid for something. Regular ma and la ban mi is so much better
author: Brian J.

description:
A disappointing bahn mi eatery in San Francisco? Found it. Didn't think some things could be true- like blobfish- but the world proves to be a strange place. Blargh. I hate to be writing about this place with my low experiences, because getting a bahn mi should also be enjoyable.

I've visited here three separate times, all with the hope that the previous low experience was just a fluke, and that a great sandwich experience was awaiting me! But no. No way. Just blobfish- I mean, average sandwiches. Here are my recaps of my visits- all done during the big lunchtime crowds...

First meal: The Bun Mee Combo. That can best be summed up with two words: dry bread. You'd need a healthy smothering of sauce (be it Sriracha, an aioli, or what have you) to revive the staleness of their sandwich bread. The paté was very tasty, thankfully, so it was worth it to chuck the bread and save all the other ingredients for what was, I guess, a carb-free meal.

Second meal: Grilled Five Spice Chicken. What spice? Is it in the caramel mayo? Nope. This was slightly better, since the bread was not stale, but overall another disappointing experience.

Third meal: Grilled Lemongrass Pork. It really wasn't any different/ better/ worse than other bahn mis I've had in SF, and those other ones are cheaper. No win for Bun Mee here.

I gave this place my best three attempts, but always came away feeling like I should have spent my money elsewhere, unfortunately, which is what I'll do from now on. Sad face.
author: Dominique F.

description: Nice cafe with good service and fast. The fish sandwich was yummy bosh was fried well and still soft and juicy. The pork belly sandwich was fatty goodness. Can't go wrong wit pork belly. The sandwiches are actually really thick and pretty big. 1 will definitely fill you up. Since I got 2 for myself, had some of the pork belly sandwich the next day and was still delicious. The pickled veggies can use a bit more tang and spice though. Overall great value.
author: Wanlan X.

description:
Okay to be totally honest, I was super skeptical about this place. I'm from San Jose so I've had some pretty amazing authentic "bun mi" I finally got to try this place on Saturday and I was surprised. I ordered the original combo with extra pate. Minus a star because it was a bit on the pricey side, especially for bun mi. 

One of my coworkers enjoyed the sloppy joe styled bun mi as well, it's essentially a sloppy joe with an Asian infused with curry flavor. And to top it all off you can add a sunny side up egg or avocado for only a dollar. Both sandwiches were fully loaded with pickled veggies and peppers, and toasted perfectly. They cut your sandwich in half for you and once you get it out of the bag the aroma just hits you, instant drool factor. 

Definitely ordering from here again, I have heard really amazing things about their french fries as well and I can't wait to try them!
author: Mindy T.

description:
This was sort of a disappointment especially because I love the original one in the Filmore. The location right on Market close enough for FiDi ppl or tourists is ideal. The decor closely resembles the filmore one it's just bigger. Very trendy and slightly his pier giving it quite the edge.

The good was just average. Myself and a friend had the bun mee sandwiches- one steak and one tofu and we both have had WAY better!! The bread was semi stale and it was just an average sandwich. I rarely eat carbs so it felt like a waste!

It was an extremely busy Friday but a place with suck quick meals and a good rep should have exceeded food expectations esp in SF. Their other dishes looked good an maybe it was bc it was such a busy lunch hour. Service and staff are uber nice and deserve a 5 star rating but food was sub-par.
author: Priya S.

description:
I live very close to the Fillmore Bun Mee, and have not yet visited.  Today met a pal for lunch and we walked over to give Bun Mee a try.  I was craving a Bahn Mi, instead I opted for my litmus test for any Vietnamese place, bun bowl/salad.  I ordered the lemongrass pork.  For what I am sure is a busy spot, they've got the service thing down well, the wait was not long for our to-go orders.  The salad looked attractive and was heavy in my hand.  We walked over to a spot to sit and eat and dug in.  The roll was packed tight with ground meet and no noodles that I could find.  Using regular egg roll wrapper rather than a rice wrapper, it was essentially flavorless.  The nuoc mam that accompanied the salad was really weak flavored.  The pork was generous, but, I tasted no hint of lemongrass. Vietnamese food is all about the freshness and strong flavors that make your mouth sing.  I got none of that.  The pork was not grilled, not that I could tell.  There was a big pile of rice noodle and some romaine lettuce (3 pieces of the stalk/root end, btw), the pickled veg were bland.  The rice noodle was very wet and oily (which was a surprise).   No herbs like mint/basil or cilantro that I could see or taste.  Again, this is my test for a decent Vietnamese place, I felt that this is what it would taste like if you bought a pre-packed salad at Safeway.  Watered-down and Americanized not in a good way.  

I will come back, I need to be fair and give them a shot with one of their Bahn mi sandwiches.
author: Donna H.

description: At the recommendation of a friend, I gave this place a try.  Thankfully it was after the lunch rush, so the service was fast and efficient.  I ordered the Pork sandwich and I thought it was "just o.k.".  Very dry, very little sauce and way too much carrot for the size of the sandwich.  I ended up getting a side of Mayo, a side of Lime Sauce and a side of another sauce to had some "juice" to an otherwise dry and not very interesting sandwich.  Plus the bread was "toasted" which I thought was odd, but maybe that's the norm these days.  Indeed the price was right at $7.25 but just not outstanding.  Even more odd, was rap music was kind of blaring in the background, which didn't add anything to the nice clean and peaceful decor.
author: Marla B.

description: Great food, I got the steak and rice also got salt and pepper fries it was delicious I really like the decorations inside it
author: Devan G.

description: I had such a wonderful time here with my family last weekend. The quality of the food was amazing! The workers were polite, it was just a great time, would love to come and eat here again.
author: Jadrian G.

description: Tried this place again and feel pretty disappointed with the same pork sandwich overall. This time they gave me jalapeños but just didn't live up to its steep price. Meh.
author: Jenny Y.

description:
Filmore location: 5 stars. Market location: 0

I only give it one extra star because I love Bun Mee Filmore. I've tried to go to this location 3 times now. They closed 10 minutes early one night and tonight I tried to call them 3 times during their new business hours and they wouldn't answer. Then I called the delivery line and still no answer. They finally answered on the 4th call to say they have no sandwiches. If you're so ridiculously busy why are you cutting your hours. The people that work there aren't very nice either. I live 2 blocks from this location and I will from now on be taking the 30 extra minutes on muni to only go to Filmore.
author: Liz F.

description:
Ate here for the first time today and I might return.  The banh mi combo that I had was fairly standard fare, but I added avocado for a buck and that was a nice twist. On the whole, though, Lee's Sandwiches and the other banh mi places in San Jose should have no fears. 

One odd thing was that salt and pepper garlic fries had no salt, no pepper, and no garlic.  They did have jalapenos and onions because I said "yes" when asked about them but, had I not said "yes," I wonder if I would have gotten completely naked fries.  In any event, the fries were at least okay and the portion was pretty huge.  

I also had a cup of "kaffir limeade."   This was fine limeade, if not a bit loaded with ice, but I sincerely doubt a kaffir lime was anywhere near this particular libation.

Finally, the place charges about 3% for the San Francisco Foodworkers' Health funding, but that does not appear anywhere on the posted menu.  I have no objection whatsoever to paying the surcharge for the benefit of my servers' access to healthcare, BUT I will ask, as I always do when a restaurant collects a surcharge:  Is this a business that keeps workers below 30 hours, doesn't actually provide any healthcare coverage, and then pockets the 3%?
author: Mike R.

description: My go to for easy Vietnamese. I wouldn't say it's amazing but it is good and does the trick. Everything is fresh which is good. It gets busy at lunch but the line moves pretty quickly and people are nice. Inside is cute.
author: Stephanie J.

description: Worth it for the price but wouldn't be my top choice for sandwiches. I had the lemongrass pork sandwich, the pork was really flavorful and nicely cooked. I added a fried egg (highly recommend you to do the same) which gave the sandwich more moisture. I also had the fries which was nicely seasoned but fries felt over fried and left out for a while. My friend had the chicken salad, again the meat was good but the salad itself was okay, not dressed enough.
author: Rohenne L.

description: Really great food! I ordered a catfish sandwich and the fish were fried just on point. The fresh coconut is nice too. The space gets a little crowded sometime though but it's not too big of a problem. Would definitely come back again if I ever swing by Union Square.
author: Terry C.

description:
I love banh mi but had never had a modern twist on it. So when I came across this shop, I knew I had to try it. 

I feel like the shop itself isn't really trying to appeal to the traditional taste buds, which is fine, but I honestly thought the sandwich lacked flavor. I got the combo sandwich. The pickled carrots and radishes weren't pickled for long enough and the grilled pork basically dominated all of the over flavors in the sandwich, but not in a good way. 

The vietnamese ice coffee was pretty weak and way sweeter than I would've liked. 

Not to mention I had to wait 15-20 minutes for my sandwich (maybe they lost the ticket? I received no apology or explanation for the long wait.)

TL;DR - bland and expensive. Go elsewhere for your banh mi and Vietnamese iced coffee fix
author: Mai N.

description:
Tasty sandwich shop and hits the spot right. Good bread and super hot french fried loaded with sauteed onions and jalapenos. Services is simple and prompt. 

They are located right on the Market street and it's easy to get to. Plenty of seating space. Cool interior design which is modern and bright. Good addition to Fi-Di San Francisco.
author: Xela H.

description:
Best sandwich! Great products, everything was super fresh!! We ordered the lemongrass pork sandwich & 5 spices chicken sandwich, both were awesome!
We're gonna be back for sure :)
author: Yael N.

description:
I like this place.

Of course, if you are used to pay $2.75 for banh mi, then you will get a sticker shock because yes, you can get it cheaper elsewhere where the rent is not as steep.

However, the location is great for me and the prices are reasonable because it is right smack dab in Market + Post. Anyone will tell you that it is prime location.

Lines are always long on lunch time. Go after 3 pm and there is special menu items - sandwiches for $3, etc.

More importantly, the food here tastes great. Sandwiches are good, bun is good, fries are good.... and they are fast. I just paid and not a minute later, my sandwich is ready. How awesome is that? Of course I usually go after lunch hours. :P
author: July N.

description:
I stopped by this place because I'd seen it a few times while walking down Market and it looked decent. I went around noon thirty, peak lunch hour, so as I expected, there was a line out the door past outdoor seating to the street. Somewhat annoying, but hopefully a good sign. The line moved at a reasonable pace, it was maybe 10 minutes until I ordered. The issue is that once I ordered my 5 spice chicken Bahn Mi and Vietnamese Iced Coffee, it took ~25 minutes to actually get the food.

In this time, I found myself packed in a corner of the restaurant with all the other people waiting for their food, a corner through which employees and patrons alike had to pass to pick up food, go to the rest room, etc. This experience was not dissimilar to a morning inter-bay Bart commute. 

Finally it was my turn to grab my food. The sandwich was smaller than expected, not terrible for $6.75 on Market, but still smaller than I'd hoped. As for the sandwich, it was fine, not very flavorful. I definitely didn't feel good that I'd waited 30+ minutes for it though. And to top it all off, the vietnamese coffee gave me gas and the runs all day. Probably will not be returning to Bun Mee.
author: Jonah S.

description:
I gotta say I love the hip vibe of the place. Downtown definitely needed a banh mi spot (because who doesn't love banh mi?) and even though this may not have the best food, it will do. 

Pretty pricey but the sandwich itself is pretty good. Love that they have sriracha everywhere. From the dozens of banh mi places I've tried, I would say this is not super authentic. Will do if you're just looking to grab a bite!
author: Michelle Y.

description: Delicious. 5 stars for taking something that's very basic and adding great sides like sweet potato fries and good quality meat. I'm a regular at Lee's Sandwiches and the Vietnamese sandwich spot on Larkin in SF. The sandwich bread was OK, what really did it for me was the meat.  When you order a combo anywhere else what you get deli style meat slices that you would find in a regular Sandwich. This limits the taste of a Vietnamese sandwich, making the pate stand out. Here my combo was well balanced, the pork had good seasoning and the carrots tasted fresh. The sweet potatoes fries with Red Curry Mayo is a WINNER in book. I can have this sauce with anything. I seriously went back and got more sauce so I can dip the fries and coat them with it. Who would have thought this these two would work so good together. Well done. I'll come back and bring my coworkers next week.
author: JJ S.

description: I work nearby and come here often. The food is consistently yummy (I have  had nearly everything) and the staff is always friendly and hard working!! Good job, guys!!
author: Rebekah N.

description:
Not your standard cheap banh mi sandwiches, but the Belly Bun (pork belly banh mi) is really tasty! The price is basically double the cost of authentic banh mi restaurants, but this place is in downtown San Francisco so you can't expect much cheaper. 

I've only had one small issue when I got takeout and ordered the sweet potato fries which is supposed to come with red curry mayo, but when I opened my order it wasn't inside.
author: Annaliese D.

description: Icky! They don't use gloves and I saw them touching their cellphones in the middle of making a sandwich! I waited in a long line but only saw these unsanitary practices when I got close and had to excuse myself and leave the restaurant. I just could not eat this!
author: Frekaleak F.

description: Okay I'm just waiting for the fries. Just one order of sweet potato, and garlic fries. The wait was a bit for something that just need to get a large bag and dump it down in grease. Overall the fries weren't so bad. Maybe too much salt and pepper though.
author: Vinson H.

description:
As someone who enjoys banh mi and ate it frequently when I lived in Vietnam, I really was rooting for Bun Mee. I appreciate that they allow you to add a hardboiled egg, but it is hard for me to give a more positive review of the food when they messed up my order. Even though I ordered the belly bun without cucumber or cilantro, which I said twice for confirmation, I got a sandwich with both. I understand that they can get busy at lunch time, but when the prices are 2x of other places offering the same thing... It was disappointing to discover I didn't get what I wanted once I was back at my desk. 

For reliable taste and cheaper prices, go to Saigon Sandwich in the Tenderloin.
author: Tony P.

description:
This is my new favorite lunch spot to go to when I'm at work. It's usually pretty crowded but it never ceases to amaze me how quickly the line moves and how quickly you get your food. I always get the saigon peanut rice bowl with chicken and it's sooo good. I've gotten the sandwich before too, but I'm obsess with the rice bowl.  

I'm that super annoying person that comes in and completely changes the meal from how it's listed on the menu. I get some stuff taken off and then add on other things essentially making a personalized rice bowl. The wait staff is always really nice and accommodating with my order, never giving me slack for my order. I've been here multiple times now and it's always good!
author: Lizzy U.

description:
I came here with a coworker who was visiting from Chicago after we had passed it the day before. It was a late lunch and we were both incredibly hangry by the time we ordered. 

The young lady at the counter was super friendly and helpful. We asked her what her favorite items on the menu were and we followed her suggestions. He had the 5 spice chicken sandwich and sweet potato fries and I had the 5 spice chicken salad.

It was good. I have no actual complaints about the food; it tasted good and filled us up. But at the same time I didn't find it anything special. Had we been less hungry and in less or a hurry I would have put more effort into finding another place, probably. But in a pinch and for the price I can't complain.
author: Daphne W.

description: I mean, it's SF, it's trendy, and the interior design and art is pretty badass. If you're not eating in, I wouldn't spend the extra bucks when you can get cheaper Viet sandwiches elsewhere. Don't get me wrong, the sandwiches and fries are good, but the price point is a bit high if you're not getting the full experience (the ambience, the artwork, etc)...and it's not super authentic, so if you're into that then maybe pass. Overall, it's still a good lunch place if you work in FiDi but it can be underwhelming if you're expecting the real deal.
author: Sara L.

description: I got the Saigon Peanut Bowl ($10.50). I didn't like it mostly because the vegetables on top were cold and everything else was luke warm. However, I do appreciate the simplicity of the meal. It wasn't oily or fried and seemed more healthy than a lot of other fast-casual options you could get elsewhere.
author: Jay B.

description:
What kind of clowns serve steak sandwiches to vegetarians? Ordered the tofu sandwich but that's not what I got. 

The service here is adequate at best- cooks walking around  shouting out finished items because there is no ticket system. But sometimes it's terrible. Today they got my name right but not my order. 

I won't be coming back to the Market St location. I can't take the chance that I'm walking out with something that will make me sick.

My refund was given to me in singles and nickels. Class act all around.
author: Steven Y.

description:
[context] I grew up with Vietnamese food and only in the last few days have I really started enjoying it. I've had amazing spring rolls and I just learned how to make them myself yesterday night from my mom. To be fair, this review is only for the Summer rolls.

I decided to get two orders of Summer rolls (Spring rolls with shrimp & pork) despite the negative reviews I saw on yelp about that item in particular. Shame on me. These were by far the worst spring rolls I've ever had. They should really call them carrot rolls because that's all that was inside. They charged $5.75 for two "large" summer rolls stuffed with lettuce and carrots and hardly any shrimp or pork. I'm seriously not exaggerating. I did not even bother finishing the other 2 rolls. I cannot believe I foolishly ordered two of these. Never again.
author: Sandy T.

description: Got my order wrong and burnt my egg roll black.  Not cool Bun Mee.  Not cool
author: Naveen S.

description: I am a big fan of this place but today was absolutely unacceptable.  Let me give you guys a hint... You have an open kitchen.  The forty people waiting for the orders they walked to your restaurant to place can see that you are only filling the catering and large carry out orders and completely ignoring their orders for over 30 minutes.  Get it a grip.  Your food is great but the service today was completely ridiculous.  Never again.
author: Rebecca R.

description: Omg my hacker bowl with roasted pork was beyond delicious. I am obsessed. The mix of textures and flavors was extremely appealing. And they gave me a UCSF discount Run don't walk. Swoon. (WHY DOES THIS SCORE SO LOW!?)
author: Andrew K.

description: Do yourself a huge favor and go down the street to Cafe Dolci for a Banh Mi... thank me later.. this place is wayyy over priced and unflavorful..
author: Tharolla S.

description:
This makes a great place for a work lunch or a fast stop. 

Venue: Modern and spacious with plenty of seating.

Combo Sandwich - The inside is flavorful and the bread is alright.

Catfish Sandwich - Not as good and flavorful as the Combo. Stick with the Combo.
author: Katrina L.

description:
Very yummy sandwich and very filling! I've tried two sandwiches here: Lemongrass Pork and Five Spice Chicken. The chicken was way better to me. I think it was the caramel sauce they put on it. It was more juicy and flavorful, but don't be thrown off by the mention of caramel (as I was the first time I came in); it's just a hint of sweetness which plays well with the pickled veggies and the jalapeños. The bread is awesome! Very crispy and soaks up the juices well. The Lemongrass Pork wasn't bad at all... just felt like it was missing something... Can't decide what, though. Tried their fries too, but those were just eh. Not worth it if you ask me. 

The one thing about these sandwiches is they need more KICK! I have to load up on the sriracha to get that heat I love. Maybe it's because their jalapeños are totally seedless... and maybe I'm a spice junkie. 

Beware, though... seating is very limited. Not great for large groups of people. Come earlier in the lunch hour and you can get a seat a little easier.
author: Kelly E.

description:
Bun Mee's sandwiches are not professionally prepared.  They are also more expensive than Cafe Bahn Mi's sandwiches, which is way better period.  You really have to go there and understand what I mean.

I ordered the pork and lemongrass sandwich, and watched the chefs prepare it from the waiting line.  They slap the veggies on top of the meat, and aren't cut short enough.  When I took a bite, the veggies fell out and they were sticking beyond my mouth because I couldn't fit that inside.

Please cut your veggies shorter!

The bread was fresh, yes, but it was also soft.  It's supposed to be crispy outside and soft on the inside for that special crunch.

The plus side is how the place looks hip and trendy with enough seating.

Final word:

Bun Mee is too expensive.  I've never heard of an $8 Vietnamese sandwich.  You would be chewed out in LA.  Cafe Bahn Mi is cheaper and better.  Get with the program.
author: Eddie P.

description: If I would have made the sandwich myself at home I would have been happy. But at an $8 price tag, not so blown away or satisfied for that matter.  Now, this was just for the crispy tofu sandwich. So other stuff with real deal flesh inside might be better.
author: Yvonne H.

description:
My 5th sandwich from Bun Mee was DISGUSTING. Something went wrong.
The flavorless pork was over-cooked with chunks of stringy fat in it. 
The bread was stale and mealie. I told the waitress it was bad, and her response was to blame me. So I left. I will go back, but I hope the owners read this to know they have a quality control problem. Contact me if you'd like.
author: Steve B.

description:
I love banh mi. Seriously, one of my favorites. 

But Bun Mee, definitely doesn't cut it for a banh mi. 

Ordered the combo banh mi because of the pate- I love pate!
The bread was tough and too french baguettey - it's suppose to be flaky on the outside and fluffy inside. 
The veggies weren't fully pickled. 
The meat, nothing bad here, pretty tasty quality for fancy pate and flavorful meats. 

I'm not saying this place is bad, the banh mi wasn't Vietnamese tasting as I was hoping a fusion place would make it. 

Can't expect much from a banh mi place that is in the FiDi. 
Really you're paying for the price of the location and convenience during lunch time.
7.50 (with taxes) for a single banh mi!?!? Oh jeez, welcome to SF. 
Any hole in the wall banh mi place would normally get 2-3 banh mis for that price.

I'm not hatin, just not the best banh mi I've ever tasted.

Just sayin, if you want banh mi, don't pay 7.50 for this place. 
I'd rather go to the Tenderloin and get better banh mi at a better price and taste, that's all.
author: Kim O.

description: I love the place, I like vegetarian option as well. Lunch times are very crowded so make sure to have it to go. Food is delicious and I'll recommend for everyone to atleast give a try.
author: Kash S.

description:
I like me a good vietnamese sammich.  Something about pickled veggies and jalapenos on a sandwich just makes sense to me.  (And mind you that in general - I hate carrots - unless they're pickled and on a vietnamese sammich)

I'd seen the line out the door in the newish Market street location, and went for lunch with an old coworker.  It's got a nice, modern decor about it - feels like a vietnamese chipotle aesthetic.  Fast casual, cool/hip, but not "fast food".

Got a 5 spice chicken sando with pate (I throw pate on any vietnamese sandwich), and my buddy got the lemongrass pork.  And we got some sweet potato fries - not sure why that's vietnamese, but f**k it - fries are fries - who's complaining.

The baguettes were crispy and light, meat flavorful and pickled veggies were as expected.  At $6-7, reasonably priced - yet semi expensive for a "vietnamese sando".  It was definitely a good sandwich.  Sooo much better than a generic banmee?  Not sure...  But it's definitely above average and worth a try fo sho.

I'll be back.
author: Arthur Y.

description:
I seriously love the sandwiches here and just recently ate at the Fillmore location. I had a sandwich here earlier this week and the day after convinced my team to order delivery for a lunch meeting.

I first want to say that the sandwiches are pretty awesome. We loved what we got. The fries, on the other hand, are not a good option for delivery. The ones I had at the restaurant location are crisp and hot, while these were lukewarm and soggy, probably a side-effect of delivery. I wouldn't recommend ordering them since there's so many other things that are good here. We had a range of sandwiches, as well as two types of spring roll wraps. Everything was pretty awesome.

Why only three stars though? Well, our order was screwed up. Not just one sandwich but at least four were incorrect. We had two crispy tofu sandwiches *without* jalapenos, while every other sandwich was standard. What we got were the tofu sandwiches with jalapenos and two of the other sandwiches were missing theirs. The stickers on the wrapper indicated exactly what we ordered, our order sheet said the same thing, but yet our sandwiches were definitely incorrect. While it's fixable by removing the jalapenos from the tofu sandwiches and passing them over to those who wanted them, it's still annoying and frustrating, as the flavour stuck on my sandwich. 

From a few other reviews, screwups seem to be in the norm for this location. C'mon people, it's bad enough when you're there at the restaurant, but for delivery it's really upsetting. I may return for a lunch during work hours, but I don't think I'll recommend for delivery again.
author: Cassandra J.

description:
This place is like the Chipotle of Vietnamese fast food, it's not authentic by any means, but I don't think it's trying to be. Either way, as long as it tastes good and I'm not looking for authentic than why not? 

I love banh mi and you can usually get these at a hole in the wall for half the price they sell them for here, but I guarantee the quality is a lot better here. Also, even though people complain about price in their reviews, it's still a lot cheaper than most other options in the area so I'll take it.

Overall, It's a great addition to the lunch spots in the area.
author: Melissa P.

description: VEGAN review: would be 5 stars if the service was slightly better. The food is amazing! I got the crispy tofu sandwich without jalapeños - the warm and crispy tofu against the cold and crunchy pickled carrots and daikon was to die for. Plus, the soy mayo was spicy so it added an extra kick. Would definitely come here for dinner/lunch again!
author: Dorothy T.

description:
I am officially addicted to this place.  Sure, they're not traditional banh mi sandwiches, but if I want one of those I'll head to Larkin Street.  This place has unusual sandwich fillings that are fresh & delicious.  My faves are the 5 spice chicken (juicy!) & the catfish (crunchy!).  The baguette is soft, the pickled veggies are awesome & I always add a generous squirt of sriracha before I head out.

The noodle/rice bowls sound yummy but they're pricey ($10-12).  I'll have to try one someday if I can ever tear myself away from those yummy sammies.

The place is LOUD so don't expect to have much of a conversation if you eat in.  The abundant staff are friendly & very quick.  I'm usually in & out of there in about 10 minutes, even if there is a line.
author: Erin S.

description:
Never bring a fried egg to a bun mee fight, unless of course you're putting the fried egg inside the sandwich.  Dropping a greasy, delicious fried egg into a mix of pickled vegetables, protein, and jalapeños all sandwiched between two halves of crunchy French bread... pure goodness!  Order any sandwich, add a fried egg for an extra dollar, and you're all set for lunch.  

At this point I don't think I need to say that this place is not authentic.  In fact I wouldn't even go so far as to call their sandwiches bahn mi, just tasty Vietnamese influenced sandwiches.  Also, their bowl dishes are overpriced and not that good.  The garlic fries are pretty tasty and come mixed with jalapeños, but at 3 dollars a pop, they're only worth it if you really need a heart attack in the future.  No, the right answer is to just order a sandwich and put an egg in it.  Four stars!

Arbitrary power ranking:

Fried eggs make everything taste better: 10/10
author: Allen C.

description:
Blehh. I wasn't expecting authentic Vietnamese sandwiches or anything...but the flavors are way off. The bread is not crispy at all and the pickled carrots and daikon are not good. Thumbs down.

I've had fusion banh mi before and it's way better than what I had here. Plus a crispy tofu banh mi will run you about $8 with tax here (wait what?).

Looking for a real banh mi in the area? Try tart to tart. Sorry bun mee...you have a good location and cool interior but lack some serious flavor.
author: Stine H.

description:
This place might not live up to the expectations of "authenticity nazis", but it satisfies the fundamental requirement of a restaurant: delicious food. That's good enough for me. Isn't that what really matters? This SE Asian approves it. 

Bun Mee is fast food without being bad food. It's delicious and pretty close to the real thing. If you have an itch for banh mi, this will definitely scratch it.
author: Yoeun P.

description: I HATE Vietnamese Sandwiches. Hate them. I've tried many times, at many places because my friends and coworkers consistently rave about how good they are... With no success for me. I find them bland or overly spicy, with borning bread. Flash forward to today, and one last ditch shot at this Vietnamese sandwich business... And BOOM. Yes. Now this was delicious! I tried the catfish sandwich, and I am officially a fan! Great flavor, crispy bread and all around delicious. Will definitely be back soon!
author: maria K.

description:
Bun Mee has several other locations so they must be doing something right. I decided to go for one of their entree rice bowls since I already had a sandwich earlier. I picked their Saigon Peanut Rice Bowl that comes with: Papaya, pickled carrots and daikon, jalapenos, bean sprouts, spicy cucumbers, topped with roasted peanuts and peanut sauce over garlic or brown rice and your choice of grilled pork, chicken, or steak.

When it comes to authenticity, I could care less. Just make the food taste good. Chipotle isn't authentic Mexican, but the burritos and tacos are decent enough. Bun Mee isn't authentic AND it doesn't taste good. The garlic rice was really mushy and reminded me of mashed potatoes. After I ate the dish my mouth had a dull numbness that you get after eating under cooked garlic. The balance of flavors was totally out of whack. It's like a four year old threw together this flavor combination. After a few bites everything is indiscernible. This same amount of ingredients at a typical Vietnamese shop wouldn't be a problem.

Everything tasted stale as if it had been prepped many hours beforehand. For instance the limes that are added so you can squeeze fresh lime juice are completely dry. I got maybe three droplets of lime juice. Added to the fact that my dish wasn't anywhere close to warm, my meal was less than appetizing.

The one highlight of the meal was that the branding and interior is very well done. It's an attractive addition to the downtown area. It will undoubtedly catch some eyes. Unfortunately Bun Mee will not please your mouth.
author: Michael H.

description:
I'm the biggest fan of vietnamese sandwiches so obvi I was too excited when I heard the office was getting Bun Mee catered! The first time I had the chicken sandwich and it was delish! The bread is like a baguette but not too tough where you will scratch the roof of your mouth. The chicken was delicious and the pickled daikons and carrots were great! My only complaint is I loooove pickled daikon and carrots so the next time I go, I'm going to ask for extra! 

The second time we had Bun Mee catered I reached for the Sloppy Joe! Not entirely sure what is in it but it was super good. I'll stick to my usual of chicken next time though.
author: Jo L.

description:
Very conveniently located place with decent, clean food. The veggies are fresh, and your food is served to you quickly.
They have sandwiches and rice and noodle bowl options. The sandwiches are priced from  7 dollars for the smokey eggplant to $8.49 for steak.
 The smokey eggplant was just ok. The five spice chicken was better, but the Hanoi style catfish was the best choice in my opinion.The sandwiches come with onion,pickled carrot'daikon,cucumber and cilantro. I like that they include jalapenos in the sandwich, and they ask you if you want it, for folks that can't handle a little heat. The chicken and the catfish sandwiches were 7 dollars.
I have also eaten the caramel citrus bowl, which was very tasty, and much more filling than the sandwiches.My bowl had brown rice (you could also have garlic rice),mango,orange,avocado,jalapenos,sprouts,and your choice of chicken, shrimp,tofu or steak. It was priced at $11.00. If you are real hungry, then definitely go with the bowl.
They have a nice selection of beverages. I ordered the coconut water for 3 bucks. 
They have some good music playing, and service was courteous.
They are open from 11:00 a.m. to 8:00 pm and consistently close early; so don't try to eat there after 7:30.
author: David B.

description:
I'm more Asian than the Bahn Mi...and that's saying something! 
Lacking in flavor and size (i'm a hippo). Better off getting legit Bahn Mi in non franchised restaurants.
author: Cristelle J.

description:
It's a bummer when service makes what would otherwise be a 5-star experience 2-stars.

Strike 1
I walked up and the fella at the reg had his head down, eyes on the screen, closing receipts/adding tips. So I stood there for a bit, after a while he said it would just be a moment. After a spell he put his closed receipts down, and took my order. 

Strike 2
He recommended the Sloppy Bun, asked if I wanted jalapeños, I asked for them on the side. Jalapeños came on the sammie, strike 2. Only figured it out when I took my first bite. 

Strike 3
I got up to place a to go order. After fella told me he couldn't take a to go order from me at a table (I had Sloppy sando everywhere, a purse, a laptop bag, I thought I would at least try...) Fella is sitting a the counter on his phone. I know this place is casual... but really?

On to the food (which was really good):

+ The Sloppy Bun was really good, especially with a sunny side up egg. But it is really messy.

+ The salt n' pepper garlic fries were great.

+ Strawberry Lychee drink was wonderful

- Skip the crispy egg rolls, they're not worth it.
author: Lani N.

description:
Overall I think this place is worth a try. Honestly, I feel like the "traditional" flavors falls a little short of Viet sandwiches. I ordered both the Combo and the Catfish sandwich. The pickled veggies were just ok but could be better. I've had some homemade ones that were much better. It could also use a bit more pate in my opinion.

Secondly, the decor of the place was really nicely done and I do like the vibe. I also loved how they have so many of the coffee cans of Cafe Du Monde, I see so many places that make vietnamese coffee use this. Got to try the coffee next time. Also the sandwiches are interesting since they are a slight spin-off from traditional Viet sandwiches. The catfish one though was delicious, you can never really go wrong with fish. 

Overall, the experience and food was not bad, but for the price, it is overpriced. But it is something convenient to grab on the go. I've heard so much about this place but I think it got a little too hyped up when it first opened.
author: Mark L.

description:
This place does a nice American-zed version of the banh mi. You can get fried cod (which I really like!) and vermicelli noodle salads (decent). Their sweet potato fries are pretty tasty :-), esp. when you dip them in this aioli/thousand island sauce.

Best part: you can order online for pick up, and not have to wait in line to order/for food.
author: Christina C.

description:
Bun Mee. I really wanted to like you, I did. From the moment I walked in to the hip decor and heard the sounds of Michael Jackson, I just knew it was going to be a great experience. 

I ordered the fish and chips, which wasn't on the menu board, but is on the website for this location. I sit down with my number, watch the people walk by on Market, and within about 10 minutes, the order shows up at my table. It is a bowl full of sweet potato fries, with three small, chicken finger-sized pieces of battered fish on top. I am immediately underwhelmed. I go back to the counter to pick up the red curry aioli that was supposed to come with the fish and chips and wasn't given to me initially. On my way back to the seat, I glance at the menu again.

The board says that a basket of sweet potato fries is $2.75, but the fish and chips is $10.00.. so you mean to tell me that those three tiny pieces of fish are $7.25?? No ma'am. 

The red curry aioli was delicious (bumps this up by a star), and a nice dipping sauce for both the fries and the fish, but if there is a next time, I'll just get the fries and aioli to go and get something more substantive elsewhere. As I sat there stewing over my fries, I reminded myself that this isn't the first time I've been bamboozled by overhyped hipster chic cuisine in San Francisco, and most likely won't be the last.
author: Josh J.

description: I just love this place..never seems to disappoint! We love the belly bun (with extra meat!) and the catfish! The mango side salad is really refreshing and the sweet potato fries with the awesome aioli is what I always look forward to.
author: Maricar F.

description: Note- the Cityguide magazine 2015 gives this place a $$$ price range but is not even close , a sandwich is under $7 and an entree bowl is less than $12. So sure it's more than a banh mi in Chinatown but you come here for the energy, creativity, fries and of course coconut cookies. :) looking for authentic? Try somewhere else next time, after you give this local place a try.
author: Megan M.

description:
Wait, what?  I have visited the Pac Heights location so many times, what happened?

First, there are two people running the registers, no line.  They are chatting away at each other, glance at me, chat some more, and finally, "Next customer"

I order a strawberry lychee drink, and the crispy catfish.

After waiting 15 minutes, my name is finally called.  I have to request my drink after having been handed my sandwich and sent on my way.

I just sat down at my desk.  I have an eggplant sandwich.  Last I checked, eggplant and catfish are not the same thing.

I am experiencing a serious case of the hanger right now.
author: Allen T.

description:
Cons: This place needs new management.  Staff don't know what's going on with phone orders.  Called on the 1st day, said there would be phone orders the next day; needless to say, there were no phone orders the next day either, made me come in to order.  Furthermore, their drinks are not in a covered container, just open to the "winds".  Ceiling lights flash, so no go if you're epileptic.  Limeade is too sweet.  Strawberry agua fresca was too sweet 

Pros: funny signs, aesthetically pleasing light bulbs, order took about 2mins to make from ordering, so that's pretty fast

We got:

Pork belly:  good, bread is chewy, pork belly is soft and flavorful

Bun mee combo:  bread is hard, meat was overly peppered, too much "salad" sauce, not enough jalapeños, if you ask me for jalapeños, don't just give me two tiny pieces

Salt and pepper fries with jalapeños: redeeming dish, jalapeños give the fries a spicy complexity, tastes like salt and pepper shrimp a la Cantonese style.
author: Paul C.

description:
5 Spice Chicken Sandwich week over week for 8 weeks now. I'm hooked. I love that they have sri-racha to go in those tiny little packets. Just makes eating the sandwich in the park all the more easier. 

They can totally improve on the waiting experience. The lines are always way too long for a sandwich place. They need to learn a thing or two from Chipotle. It doesn't really matter if you have 3 payment counters but just one single line for building sandwiches. Totally got to parallel process (maybe a separate line for online orders?) 

A nice hack is to ordering online for pick-up. These orders usually arrive as faxes and then you show up in front and just check on your order. The folks there usually just pick the fax up and start working on it right away. Huge time saver.
author: Partha S.

description:
Meh describes this sandwich. It's pretty boring. When choosing my Bahn Mi in the future I'll go to Little Vietnam Cafe or another one of the smaller spots. It was unexciting and totally forgettable. Also, it comes with a "mango sesame salad" which is basically some chopped up mango on cabbage with some sesame seeds on top..the dressing did not compliment this and I could barely eat two bites before tossing it.
Double Meh.

Won't be going back.
author: Melanie L.

description:
I'd say a strong-ish 3 stars, rounded up.

Bun Mee on Market is a bit of a cluster at lunch rush. The noise level within the restaurant makes ordering a bit of a screaming match with the cashier and there is sort of an awkward crowd of people waiting for their order once that's done. However the service is lightning fast and the guys and gals working the line are pushing out sammiches at a frenetic pace so the line moves quickly.

Tastewise, it's great. I wouldn't really classify these as vietnames sandwiches - they're wholly different and a bit heavier. The bread isn't the same sort of crusty, airy baguette that  Bánh mì usually come in, and the fillings aren't your standard pho joint fare - ranging from meatballs to sloppy joes to catfish po'boys. The fries are a little bit on the limp and greasy side, so opt for a roll or salad if you want a side dish. I haven't tried the salads or bowls yet.
author: Mori Y.

description:
The good: location, interior, and customer service. That's pretty much it. I feel pretty generous with the three stars. 

Food: I've tried three of their sandwiches: eggplant, combo, and belly. 

The eggplant was a bit difficult to eat. Eggplant skin is tough to separate, so with one bite, you end up taking the entire "meat" of the sandwich. The flavor was decent enough. I would probably order this again. 

The combo: not special at all. All the different flavor a we're competing with each other. It honestly was pretty bland considering it had mortadella in it. 

The Belly Bun on the other hand, was a greasy salt sandwich. The entire thing was so greasy it soaked through the bread. Then it was so salty, I downed an entire glass of water after a few bites. I took the other half home and ate it with rice. The fat to meat ratio was also very disappointing. It was mostly meat, not much fat at all. 

I would be a lot forgiving if the fillings and bread were better quality. The bread wasn't crispy on the outside, nor was it soft on the inside. It was just stale-ish. The do chua (daikon and carrots) was also bland. It wasn't sour enough. I recommend either pickling it longer, or using a smaller cut. 

Price: $7 for crappy sandwich? No thank you. I'd rather get something delicious from nearby places like LaBoulange, Specialties, or The Sentinel. 

Would I come back? Only if I had a craving. They're just too many better choices.
author: Lisa L.

description:
The Financial District can feel like a good-food desert sometimes, so I was excited to see that this place was opening not far from my office. Thinking I'd beat the rush, I headed over at 11:30 to find the place swarmed. Not one to be deterred by crowds, which I take as an indicator I'm someplace good, I ventured in. 

The interior is modern and trendy; it feels like a fun place. There was a bit of a line, so I got to peruse what other diners were eating. Everything looked fantastic. I decided on the lemongrass pork sandwich and a strawberry lychee agua fresca, and both were fantastic. 

The wait was a little long, but the staff gave people waiting complimentary french fries, which I wish I'd had an entire order of.

I'll definitely be back!
author: Julie K.

description: Picked up a tofu banh mi for lunch, I would not go back. It had a thin strip of grilled tofu with tons of shredded carrots and a few jalapeños. The sandwich had no flavor and needed cilantro to liven it up. The bread was too thick and dense. I've had a lot better banh mi's from other restaurants.
author: Jenifer A.

description:
Just had a banh mi and spring rolls from Bun Mee today.  Being that I'm from San Jose and I'm vietnamese, its probably not fair for me to judge this place.  But knowing that this place is an americanized version of Viet food, I wont be as picky.  I got the Hanoi style catfish banh mi with a fried egg on top.  It came uncut and super greasy and messy.  The veggies weren't pickled enough and the bread is a disgrace to vietnamese sandwiches.  It was hard on the edges and soggy all over.  Its suppose to be crunchy and flakey.  Oh well, that being said.... the flavor wasn't bad.  As for the spring rolls, I've never had oily peanut sauce before.  It literally had a top layer of oil when I opened the container.  It basically made grease spots all over the table.  

All in all, its not bad.  The flavor is pretty decent.  Great place in fidi when you have a craving and dont feel like trekking over to the TL.  I'd come back and give it another try with something else... like their vermicelli bowl or something.  =) 

With the sandwich and springrolls, I spent a little under $16.  Not bad for FiDi.
author: Vicky T.

description: I've been here several times because it is near my office.  I usually get the tofu or catfish Bahn Mi.  The food here is fine, but nothing to write home about.  I kept coming back because 1. it is close by and 2. it was cheap. Unfortunately, they recently upped their prices by about $1.50 per sandwich, shifting the cost to quality ratio into the category of "not worth it".  I don't know about their other items, but I assume those prices were also raised by a similar margin.
author: Melanie K.

description:
I don't get it! Why are so many people into this place? I've tried 3 things in two visits: the Belly  Bun sandwich, the salt and pepper garlic fries and the Bun Noodle Bowl. The Belly Bun was too salty. It comes with a salted radish relish but it was overpowering. I ordered the recommended hard boil egg but they gave me a fried egg, which may have contributed to the saltiness. I ate the whole sandwich but was fully dissatisfied. The fries were meh. Where is the garlic? but it came with plenty of jalapenos. The Bun Noodle Bowl was so-so, definitely not worth the $13 I paid and they forgot to include my requested jalapenos.

Overpriced. Overrated.
author: Elsie M.

description: Great decoration, a bit too loud to hold a conversation. The prices are a bit higher than other stores. The food tasted average, cantina style dining self serve water and etc.. the menu is on the right side which is kind of weird as you have to go thru the line sideways to decide what you want.
author: Harold W.

description: I got the lemongrass pork which is supposedly there most popular sandwich. I agree with another reviewer below, the meat was kind of bland. There was way too much carrots and the mayo spread was pretty typical. All in all the sandwich lacked some real flavor that traditional banh mi's would have.
author: Julia W.

description:
I've been here 3 times, each time getting exponentially worse.

1st time: Saigon peanut rice bowl - the rice was overcooked and the peanut sauce was too thick, but it was edible.

2nd time: Grilled five spice chicken sandwich - The caramel mayo sauce was overpoweringly sweet and made the sandwich almost inedible.

3rd time: Crispy tofu sandwich - The tofu was fried so hard that it was hard as a rock. My jaw hurt after trying to eat it. Completely inedible. As we were leaving, a waitress asked how the food was. When we told her the truth, her response was "It's really busy right now." Protip: If someone tells you your food is inedible (because it actually is), don't make excuses.

This place is all looks and no substance. NEVER again.
author: Thuy L.

description:
There are so many other places with better bahn mi, but since this is the only one in the neighborhood, it will have to do. Except, I will probably never come back. 

It's too bad and I almost regret paying $7.27 for a five-spice chicken sandwich, but it is what it is. 

Though the bread was fresh and toasty on the outside and soft on the inside, the meat was dry and the sandwich on a whole was dry. 

This place makes me want to hike over to the Tenderloin and get a sandwich done right.
author: NickJess S.

description:
Don't understand why Bun Mee doesn't have at least an overall 4 rating! On my way to eat somewhere else when I saw that there was standing room only and, prior to Yelp, that was the standard! 

Like:
The peanut bowl w/garlic rice!
Ambiance - Vietnamese fusion...people were enjoying the place
Service - pleasant & personal

Wish:
We had one in Riverside
author: Hector M.

description: Always a great choice for a quick lunch sandwich.  Order online and pick up in store so you do not have to wait in line!
author: Cassie Y.

description: eating there "porkbelly" tasted like spaghetti sauce and ground beef... Cafe Bunn Mi is WAY better in that regard. I'll probably try this spot one more time to give them a chance to redeem themselves though.
author: Aaron C.

description: Note to self: do not carry to go food items in a paper bag when it is raining.  One of the rice bowls I was carefully carrying home fell and went splat on the street when I was crossing.  The container was almost in tact so I picked it up and took it home anyway.  It was still edible.  The rice bowls were a-ok, not mind-blowing.  I need to go back and try their sandwiches next.
author: Maile N.

description:
the sandwiches at this particular Bun Mee location are the worst banh mi sandwiches ive ever had. I'm actually angry that i went there and that i had to spend 12 bucks for parking, and that i spent 76 dollars on 3 banh mi sandwiches, 2 bowls, 1 salad, 1 spring roll, and 3 fountain drinks that i could only choose either coke or diet coke from. 

having been to the first location on filmore before, i knew in advance that the new fidi location would be crazy busy and that the prices would be the same...overpriced...literally double to triple the price of a "traditional" banh mi sandwich...this was all fine with me because there is a degree of paying for better quality ingredients that i am fully aware of AND i was pleasantly surprised that the sandwiches were pretty tasty when i first tried them at the filmore spot. 

the new fidi location is a madhouse (at lunch of course) and whether we went and the cooks were understaffed and forgot to put "flavor" into the food or used really old bread...the sandwiches were all a total fail...the salad was just veggies with nuoc mam...im not vietnamese, but in my defense, having lived in san jose and being around a heavily concentrated vietnamese community...ive had my fair share of banh mi sando's and this place makes Lee's Sandwiches look like The French Laundry. 

maybe well give it another shot either super early or really late to avoid the lunchtime madness, but then again it really can't get worse.
author: Kyu L.

description:
For a sandwich it was ok for a Bahn mi it was terrible. 

I had the combination which is supposed to be ham, Headcheese and pate, while the pate was good the use of Mortadella along with the grilled pork was horrible. The grilled pork tasted fine but the contrast of textures was very off putting, i know what they are trying to accomplish but it simply does not work. 

What makes a Bahn mi so amazing is the contrast of the bread the meat and the pickled veggies in this case the bread is so-so and the pickled veggies were crap. They are not sweet at all like they should be and are instead just vinegary as hell and ruin the entire sandwich. Even if the meat and bread were top notch the carrots and daikon would ruin the sandwich, I had to remove all of it before i could eat it.  Overall this is probably the worst version of a vietnamese sandwich i have ever had. 

Rice Bowl: 
Bad, the Daikon mixture ruined this dish, the meat was good, the rice was ok but that Daikon crap they dare to throw in the food ruins it all.

I actually really like the decor and the music, the fries were good even though they weren't spicy in anyway. 

Overall this is a poor excuse for a viet sandwich not only is it not as good as the original version it is also way overpriced.  The best Bahn Mi i have ever had costs around 3.25.  If you want a bad viet sandwich and want to overpay for it go eat a Bun Mee.
author: Charles W.

description:
4 stars for quick service. 1 star for flavor.

Do not expect authentic Vietnamese food here. Bun Mee caters to an "americanized" palette. Additionally, I paid $13.03 (including tax) for a Vermicelli bowl that was so bland, I'm immediately regretting my purchase. 

I'm slightly disappointed with the non-existent flavor, but then again, they aren't catering to us that enjoy the Oakland China-town Bunh Mi or Tenderloin Vietnamese food.  

If you want to try Vietnamese-inspired food, I say start here. For you experienced eaters - stay away, you're likely to be disappointed. Sorry Bun Mee. I really wanted to like you guys!
author: Jill G.

description: Great Bahn Mi spot along Market Street! A little expensive, but decently priced for the size of the sandwich. All the ingredients were fresh in my Hanoi-Style Crispy Catfish, but then again, anything with cilantro gets marked down as an A in my book. Definitely get some siracha though, to turn this one up a notch. I'll be back soon to try others!
author: Jane K.

description:
Food is decent, but CHECK YOUR ORDER CAREFULLY! 

Ordered delivery through seamless, but Bun Mee forgot to include some items. Tried to call them but they never pick up. Finally had to call Seamless who were able to reach them and Seamless agreed to refund for the missing items. Was told that I would be contacted by Bun Mee since missing items on deliveries is common. Guess what? Never contacted.
author: Oliver L.

description:
I've walked pass bun mee plenty of times and have been curious to know what type of Vietnamese fusion foreshadowed.

My friend said it was good and we decided to have it for dinner. I ordered the pork combo that came with pate and decide to order a fried egg in addition for a dollar. 

The decorations were hip. Wooden benches with tin canisters filed with napkins and chopsticks. 

My sandwich arrived and it was a monstrosity. It was piled high with daikon, carrots, with some cilantro and peppers. With initial bites, it was a bit hard to decide how to go about eating the sandwich due to the size. It didn't really help that the baguette was hard and my egg kept falling off my sandwich. Overall, the sandwich was missing that tasty umpf.

I think I will be heading back to the traditional Vietnamese restaurant for my banh mi fix.
author: Becky Q.

description: Not sure why bun mee only has three stars. They have such good food. Try the crispy tofu sandwich with a side of sweet potato fries. Mind blown!
author: makenna n.

description:
I really wanted to be blown away by Bun Mee, but its an OK place to go for lunch. I went during lunch time so it was a bit crowded, but finally a seat opened up! 

I tried the pork bahn mi and garlic fries. I added an egg too, which I thought made it better. The sandwich was decent and I thought it was a pretty good size. I mean while its an Americanized version of a bahn mi, it was ok. 

I did not really like the garlic fries, as the ones on the bottom were super soggy and I didn't want to finish the rest. I would come back if I was in the area, but I wouldn't go out of my way.
author: Leah F.

description: I had the Belly Bun sandwich and it was amazing. Meat was ridiculously tender and plentiful for a Bahn Mi style sandwich. Will definitely me coming here again. Could use a little less turmeric on the sweet potato fries though.
author: Brent D.

description: This place is pretty good.  It is a nice blend of authentic, but with fresher higher end ingredients then you would get at a typical Viet Dive place.  If you are looking for straight up authentic is is not for you, but if you want transitional flavors with an interesting twist this place is for you.
author: John F.

description:
Came here before the lunch rush while waiting for the bus. I like Vietnamese sandwiches and this place looks very cool, so why not. I like the solid and modern look to the restaurant and I really enjoy the contrasting materials and colors.

I ordered a combo sandwich with garlic fries. Me and another guy who ordered the sweet potato fries waited for 15 minutes with little progress on our meals, when people who ordered after us were coming and leaving. Eventually, the head kitchen guy noticed we were waiting and checked on the orders. One of the employees said they're waiting on the fries, but lo and behold, the fries were actually just waiting in the fries area for a good 10 minutes. The head kitchen guy was not happy about that and was very apologetic and gave me a free San Pellegrino for the wait, which was really nice of him. I wasn't in a rush and no harm done, so I took my bag of the fries and sandwich and a San Pellegrino and took the bus home.

Got home and discovered that I got the wrong sandwich. It was still delicious, but it wasn't the one I ordered. I liked the crunchy bread and the pickled vegetables were plentiful with a good helping of the meat as well. The fries were okay, didn't really taste garlicky, but perhaps they taste much better when it's fresh.

I'll give this place another try. People make mistakes. But I appreciated the fact that the guy was sincerely sorry for the wait and gave me a free soda to apologize. Because it wasn't his fault that the fries were forgotten, but did his best to do something about it for the sake of the restaurant and staff and I think that's good service.
author: Momo C.

description:
Fascinating atmosphere, really good food, nothing I would make for myself at home so it's a nice treat!
The inside is really cool I love the decorations and the lighting, look up while you're in there and appreciate the fixtures above you.
The food was delicious and like I said it's very different than stuff that I normally eat so it was quite a treat. It's on my way to work and I pass it every day to and from work so now it's going to be a hard spot to avoid. 
I had the peanut bowl and sweet potato fries.  Very very fresh!
author: Kellianne R.

description: We were in town for pride and stumbled across this place for lunch.  I had the combo sandwich and although the seasoning was good, the bread was a bit soggy.  I'm used to the baguette being very crispy like how I get at the other Vietnamese restaurants.  I probably won't come back cause of that reason.
author: Nyla K.

description:
I love this place, but it's sort of declining in quality.

Banh mi is awesome in general, so that's good. The decor is good and the staff is nice.

Bread - Tastes a bit stale. Nice and crispy on the outside, but not chewy/fresh enough on the inside. It does stand up to the meat well though.
Pork - Tasty, well seasoned, but they really don't put enough in. Spicekit puts way more meat in their version of fusion banh mi.
Pickled veggies - Nice pickling, not too sweet
Mayo - Pretty bland, a little sweet, and they put too much on by default. Ask for light mayo.
Pate - I get this as an extra every time, but it's very lightly flavored so sometimes overwhelmed by the mayo

Recommendation for the restaurant: Get better bread, put more meat in, and cool it on the mayo, and you'll shoot back to 5 stars!
author: Adam W.

description: Their bread is so good! Chewy and crunchy. I got the five spice chicken sandwich - one thing, lacked flavor on the meat so was a little bland. Besides that, good and clean!
author: Jane C.

description: I like their happy hour specials. Dragon claw is my favorite .. Fried catfish pieces can easily share with two or be filled. Trying their belly sandwich today and it's pretty great. Great sauce , fresh tasting picked veggies, soft and moist meat with hunks of fat.. I've never been one to enjoy thugs of fat... But I'll allow it here eevery once in awhile. Quick ordering, clean bathrooms, indoor N outdoor seating, free wifi and chic interior . I like
author: Alexander T.

description: I recommend the garlic fries to along with any of the tasty sandwiches here. The sandwich bread is warm and toasty adding extra flavor to an already great sandwich!
author: Eric L.

description:
Sandwiches are pretty good, 5 spice chicken is alright but I prefer the lemongrass pork. 

The only thing I dont like is none of the Bun Mee locations will deliver to me in nob hill/lower nob hill. Sadness.
author: Kristan B.

description:
Best Banh Mi sandwich and fries with jalapeños ever! 
Lemongrass pork and salt & pepper garlic fries!

Spicy! 
Clean! 
Excellent!

Best Banh Mi sandwich and fries with jalapeños ever! 
Lemongrass pork and salt & pepper garlic fries!

Spicy! 
Clean! 
Excellent!
author: Emma Y.

description:
Great graphics but the food doesn't hold excellent expectations. Customer service from a cashier who is Asian was great, the server was kind of upset and not nice. I had the Hawker bowl with steak. It wasn't special, nothing extraordinary. But I had a huge serving of it. It didn't taste authentic or extraordinary either. It tasted so ordinary, and there wasn't unique and special to the dish. The steak was grilled but it was chewy, of course I had a fork and knife to cut the steak into smaller pieces.
Not worth going here again.
I had the kafir lemonade which is right, but wondered if they had any sugar in packets.
This restaurant is a joke in my standards, but the marketing and graphics are on point.
author: Jade M.

description:
Expensive. Nearly 7 dollars for *just* the sandwich. Only things I remember about it was that there wasn't a huge amount of veggies and the bread was super hard, possibly stale and reheated. The strawberry lychee drink was good. The music was obnoxiously LOUD. 

Yeah, I won't be back. The rent's too high SF to spend this much moolah on a single banh mi sandwich. Saigon Sandwich is worth the walk for me.
author: Miffy Y.

description:
I was just walking by on Saturday and didn't know they opened a second location. I always wanted to try the other location but never was able to. I was hungry, my girlfriend was hungry, we both always wanted to try it, the stars aligned!

I read some of the other reviews and it must have been during opening week it seems like.  I didn't have any of these issues.  It's a busy, fun environment.  It fits the location. I found the ordering system easy and the same as most restaurants in the city.

Food was DELICIOUS! Can't believe I waited this long to try it.
I had the Grilled Five Spice Chicken and my Girlfriend had the Juicy Steak. We kept swapping back and forth and saying YOU HAVE TO TRY THIS! 

I was sad when our food was gone. Need to come back asap!
author: Nick S.

description:
Possibly. Wait, undoubtedly the worst bun mi I've ever had. How can bun no be bad?!!! The bread was hard and not fresh. Everything was just- not good. I was so excited to try this place too. I'm sorrrrrry. 

Had to repost from 1 to 2. The staff here is really awesome.
author: Shirley S.
