description: I ordered online went to the shop for pickup and was ignored for 10mins. When I finally got the attention of someone I was told my order wasn't ready. Finally 20 mins later I got my order. Open the box of egg rolls to find then burnt.  Between the poor service and burnt food I say skip it.
author: Dionne M.

description:
Came here today for lunch with a friend and will definitely be back. Had the Juicy Steak but subbed out the lime pepper mayo for the garlic mayo and that was an excellent decision. The sandwich was fairly large so I only ate half- it was overflowing with meat, jalapenos, onions, etc. Super tasty and filled me up. I also got the salt & pepper garlic fries and they were delicious. Clearly the theme of this place is jalapenos because they're in practically every dish, which I'm not complaining about. If you like a little kick, on top of well developed flavors, this is worth checking out. 

Word to the wise: 12p-1p is crazy busy, yet when we were walking out just after 1p, the line had cleared out and it was less hectic. I'd recommend going for a late(r) lunch, if possible. Pricing: sandwich and fries cost just under $13.
author: Lisa L.

description:
We order Bun Mee a lot on seamless as an office and the biggest complaint is the pickled vegetables. I personally like the pickled daikon and pickled carrots, but it's definitely an acquired taste. 

Highly recommend the hawker bowl (only bowl with fried egg) as well as the chicken sandwich (yummy pâté)
author: Jennifer J.

description:
The food's not bad, but the restaurant is beyond awkward.

For their vegetarian option, they went with a pressed tofu steak. My sandwich was underseasoned, but probably because I declined jalapeños--which, according to the giant red I-beam behind the counter, indicates that I am a "sissy". So they are clearly not bucking for any GLAAD awards.

Speaking of the unwelcoming physical space, trying to order involved continuously looking over my shoulder at the menu while shouting over the music at the cashier. Waiting to pick up my order was a game of human Tetris, since very little thought was given to having a waiting area.

It's worth a second visit, with some advance planning, but they've a long way to go to beat the half dozen other banh mi options in the area.
author: Brian W.

description:
Had a chance to stop by Friday for lunch. I have always liked the Fillmore location, but it's too tough for me to get to most times. So when I saw they had opened downtown, I was excited that I could get my banh mi fix on my lunch break. First off, the inside is super cool, with awesome graffiti art and these funky wires and light bulbs dangling in the space and great music! Totally different from Fillmore, but seems right for the energy of Market St. 

I was there kinda late for lunch, about 1:45-2, and while there was a bit of a line, it moved fast--encouraging, because I know how long the waits at some of the other restaurants nearby can be. The staff was really friendly and helpful too--they even thanked me by name when they brought me my lunch. Nice touch.

I went outside of my normal order  (belly bun w/ egg) and got the catfish roll, fries and a strawberry lychee drink. My banh mi was damn near perfect--you have to have the right bread, and the right ratio of stuff to that bread, and Bun Mee nailed it--plus the fried catfish was crisp but not greasy. Only knock was that I asked for extra jalapeños, but if they were there, I couldn't taste them, so I stole a couple off my fries and remedied the situation! 

Since I was dining alone, I "may" have eavesdropped on the table next to me talking about a secret menu. How did I not know this? ? Must find out what this entails! Well, I can add it to my list of  reasons to come back! 

All in all a great experience, and I am excited to have them downtown.
author: John R.

description:
I always pass by the location on Fillmore, and since this one is within 2 minutes of my office I decided to give it a try. I decided to try the lemongrass pork sandwich which was ok but not great. All of the meat was on one side, with the veggies on the other side which made getting a bite with both impossible. I had to put tons of sriracha on it to add flavor because there was much more bread than meat or filling. The flavor of the pork was actually really good but there wasn't a whole lot on the sandwich which was disappointing. I ended up having the butts of the sandwich completely filling-less, which made the already small-ish sandwich seem not very satisfying.

I would try this place again but maybe opt for one of the bowls to get a good second meal out of it. Overall, I like the atmosphere and interior but the food itself isn't anything exciting.
author: Jane B.

description: I feel like this is an American Viet type of restaurant. They use a mix of traditional ingredients along with a little twist and flare. Never seen Catfish used in Banh Mi before but I realized how diverse the food is after looking over the menu. The bread has a good chew texture to it that stays traditional. One thing I don't like is the amount of sauce liquids that go into it. Makes the bread kind of soggy after a while. They even have some tasty Jalepeno Garlic Fries which is fiya; not to mention the attractive woman at the counter too; I'm thinking she's the owner. I'd come back just to see her again. Not sure if she's Viet or Latino cus she's got a mix of both if you know what I'm saying...Bun Mee's got BUNS for sure.
author: Alex K.

description:
HAVE AGAIN: The bread was fantastic! I would definitely have sandwiches again. Five stars!
NOT HAVE AGAIN: The belly bun's kurobuta belly was 2/3 fat and very much undercooked. Guess I am not a bacon lover who wants to eat almost raw pork fat. If I'd known the pork belly was so undercooked, I would not have ordered one. No stars!
author: Keith R.

description: Just OK if you need a quick lunch. Sandwiches are stronger than other offerings, which you'd expect. Rice bowl was a mess, with way too much spicy Mayo and muddled flavors.
author: mark r.

description: Prices rise but food quality goes low. You'll loose one more faithful customer, Bun mee.
author: Dan X.

description:
Fan of the Fillmore St location, which this seems to be a trimmed down version of - disappointingly so.  Gave it 4 instead of 3 (deserved) stars because I'm assuming it's week one and there's a lot of kinks to work out.

Food: good flavors, seems like fresh ingredients.  Most important to me about a Bunh Mi is that the bread is nicely toasted, yet doesn't destroy the inside of my mouth (I'm looking at you, Dutch Crunch).  This was spot-on.

Menu: Too small - only a few options, and none of the exciting ones from the other location.

Price: sandwiches are priced right ($6-7), but everything else felt pricey.

Service: Counter - quick and friendly.

Ambiance: Good, but music WAY TOO LOUD.  Yes, I'm shout-typing that because of the massively blaring DJ music that I never ever need when trying to enjoy a sandwich. Ever.

Will go back, but if menu doesn't improve, music doesn't turn down, and lines remain ridiculous, will drop to 3 or 2 stars...
author: Jeremy T.

description:
My hair salon is directly above this place, and their exhaust is literally right outside my window. This is what I have to smell everyday. Not pleasant. At least the food taste better than the smell. 

Today was the first day of being open so I know things will change... The music.. Come on. I tried to eat quick so I can leave the club. I'm eating lunch in the FiDi, not in a club. Turn it down a bit. 

The food was good. It was edible. I'm sure I will be back, since it's right downstairs. 

Price- a bit steep for just a rice bowl, and soda- $16.00
author: Cameron H.

description: Had the chef's special shrimp banh mi and it was excellent. At first I was worried when I saw the size of the bread and expected it to be on the dry side. But with shrimp, sauce, and loads of pickled vegetables, it came out terrific. And it was generally pretty efficient. This place is the kind you might go to if you're looking for a quick bite in the area.
author: Kal R.

description: Great Vietnamese sandwich. I came here with my friend josh, and I had the pork.  It was delicious, although a tad pricy.  My friend got one with fried egg which looked delicious.  Hope to come here again soon.
author: Matt N.

description:
This is a good place for the squeamish and uninitiated to try a viet sandwich for over $7.
Once you're hardcore, then instead, jump into the Montgomery station and ride to Civic Center.  Walk up Larkin and get a better banh mi for $3.75.  Get one for a friend too, and return to FiDi for less than $10.
author: rb l.

description: Love this place. Too busy at lunch times but the food is great. Bug fan of the Fillmore branch also.
author: Stefan S.

description: Awesome Vietnamese coffee. If they were to sell this coffee in the mornings, I'd think they would make a killing.  Especially when there's nothing like it around this neighborhood.  Five spice chicken salad taste great!  Employees always have a friendly smile, how inviting.  Outside seating and well places inside tables for relaxing leg room.  Bun Mee can't go wrong!!!
author: Jeff H.

description: Generous amount of meat In the bun bowl. Taste fresh and flavorful. Banh mi with red ground beef and fried egg just like Ba le sandwich in east oakland. Nice addition to market street. Service is fast and friendly.
author: James W.

description:
Bland food. The bread quality is also not good. 

I got the tofu sandwich and it was flavorless. They were good when they had just opened but have gone completely down hill from there.
author: Revant K.

description: Hurray for bun mee!!!! I love it. The sandwiches are bomb and the 5 spice chicken salad is crazy addictive. I had it 3 times in one week.  This spot gets a HUGE lunch crowd but you can either call in your order or arrive early. When it's crowded it's a bit uncomfortable to wait for your order as there's no designated waiting area and people fill in where they can, including in front of the registers, soda machine, restroom and kitchen entrance.
author: Shondra G.

description:
I so wanted to like this place, it looks like the Super Duper of Vietnamese food. So I ordered a pork sandwich - to me that's the true measure of a bahn mi place, the kind of thing that Spice Kit hits out of the park. But no, alas, no. Good crispy bread, check. Good pickled veggies, check. Not much spice there. Pork a little lacking in flavor, tastes vaguely like...catfish? Maybe it's prepared on the same grill as the fish or something?

Well, I tried it, but I can't say I'm a huge fan. I think I'll stick with Spice Kit.
author: Marco C.

description:
I think this is one of favourites for Banh Mi - I'm a vegetarian and their Crispy Tofu option is great; tasty and filling. But the one thing that makes me want to come back again and again is their Garlic Fries (with Jalapeños) - these must be some of the best fries in the city! Whatever else you get definitely get these. 

Their service and spacing is great also. Just beware that during rush times there can be a 15-20 min queue to order and then a slight wait for your order to be prepared.
author: Pulkit A.

description:
Grabbed a quick lunch to go here yesterday as I was running errands. 

The set up is like super duper, you order first then wait for your food. The place was pretty crowded but it was really quick to place my order. I really didn't feel like a sandwich so I decided on a rice bowl. I got the one with peanut sauce with pork and brown rice. The rice bowl was about $11 to $12. 

The rice bowl consisted of rice, pickled carrots and veggies, beansprout, jalapenos, meat (pork) and peanut sauce. Mix it all together and it was pretty good. Next time I would like to try it with the garlic rice and I should probably try their claim to fame - the banh mi. 

Overall, it's a little expensive for vietnamese food then I'm used to but there are not that many options for good viet food in the downtown area so it's nice i can get my fix from here. :)
author: Christine W.

description:
First thing is seen when I walked into this place was the ambiance.  I really like the mix of colors in this place.

Next was the menu!
So many different choices to pick. Was like any other places ive been. 

I tried the 5 Spice Chicken w/ a Side of Salt & Pepper Garlic Fries. 

I say its one place I'd go to invite a friend. Or even pick up. Great Concept!
author: Carmichael G.

description:
I found a cockroach crawling around on my tray after my order was delivered to my table.  Thankfully I hadn't eaten any of the food yet.  I promptly got up and handed the tray back, pointing out the cockroach.

The staff was apologetic and offered to re-do my order.  I declined, and just asked for a refund.  They did give me some money back and insisted I take a free cookie and drink as I left.

After I had left, though, I realized that they had only refunded me for part of my order.  I emailed them that night, explained the situation, and asked if there was a way to just get the rest of my refund.  No response within 24 hours.  I contacted them (via their website) again the next day.  Again, no response in the past 3 days.

I'm a bit peeved that they won't even respond to my inquiry.  Although I think the staff on duty handled the situation as best they could, the situation itself and the non-response from the company made me want to warn others away with the one-star review.
author: Liz S.

description: Definitely a typical sandwich joint in the city! Not real Vietnamese food and expensive. Not much seating area so not good for groups either.
author: Nikki K.

description:
The Chinese five spice fusion sandwich is the amazing. 

Also have some fantastic salads and drink options but the sandwiches are where it's at. And don't be thrown off by the jalapeños, they're perfectly fine and perhaps only a little on the hot side. 

The line at this place can be unbearable at lunch hour so aim to go at 12 or after 130.
author: Fredrina B.

description:
This p;ace is awesome - spicy, but excellent.

I have ben there a couple of times and gone with the catfish sandwich both times. Once with sweet potato fries.

Clean, cheap and friendly. The sandwich is full of fresh ingredients and VERY tasty
author: John G.

description: I like the place. Another yelper described it well when he said it is to Vietnamese food what chipotle is to burrito. I tend to recommend the 5 wpice chicken.
author: Sol V.

description: Had the crispy tofu sandwich. It was kind of bland. The bread was too hard & not enough tofu for fill in. Line was short for lunchtime. Maybe next time I will try the entree bowls.
author: Rey B.

description: This place is very busy at lunch. Probably need to wait in line to place an order and probably have to wait for another 10-15 mins to get your order. Also you need some luck to get a seat there since it's limited in compare to the high traffic it gets. Overall I think the sandwich is very good and tasty. I ordered a pork belly Banh mi sandwich. It uses Braised Kurobuta pork belly, which is very rich and tasty. It was little bit too fat for me. I think I was good with just half the sandwich since it was so rich and fatty. I probably will try the lemongrass pork or tofu banh mi next time. Also remember to wear clothes you can wash in machine instead of dry clean because you will definitely smell like onions and all those tasty ingredients used when you leave the restaurants. Definitely worth to try!!
author: Becky K.

description: Great for a quick meal - solid selection of freshly made Vietnamese sandwiches.  During happy hour the beer is reasonable and the chili fry's are super yummy.  This is a fast casual dining concept - you order/pay at the counter they give you a number and the food is delivered to your table.
author: Jonathan G.

description:
Tasty Vietnamese sandwiches (ask them to include the jalapeño) and crisy egg rolls.

Their cookies are good also but I try not to get them every visit. 

Good customer service as well.
author: D L.

description:
The good: I do quite enjoy the crispy tofu sandwich. I'm not a *huge* fan of tofu but here it's well prepared and actually tastes of something. Which can be rare with tofu.

The bad: the apparent amnesia they suffer from. They 'forgot' my lunch order today - took 25 minutes to sort out. No apologies given. They also 'forgot' our office catering order we'd put in for a celebration. Again, no real apologies just, "Meh, these things happen!".

So, yeah, 2 stars - must try harder.
author: Max S.

description:
This place sounds great in theory, however...

I ordered the tofu sandwich a few different times and each time it was so full of oil that the sandwich just fell apart.  Also, it's not an authentic Vietnamese sandwich, which is fine, but if you're going for unconventional, it has to be done well and this wasn't.  I only went back because I try to support places that serve organic food and really did want to like this place. That was a few months back. 

Fast forward to today.  I wanted summer rolls for lunch and thought I would try this place again.  I called after 1pm to avoid the lunch rush and get asked to hold.  Five minutes later of being on hold, I hang up.  Try again a few minutes later, no answer.  I try one more time a few minutes later, same result.  So I went there in person.  The woman at the counter was typing something into terminal and said she would be right with me.  Understood, she's in the middle of a task.  Well she keeps at it and after two minutes of standing there, being completely ignored by this woman, waiting to be helped, with no other employees jumping in to assist me, I told her not to worry about it and left.  What's worse is that she looked like she could have been a manager.  They really didn't want to sell anything to me today. 

Back at my office, I just tossed their takeout menu in the recycling bin.  I've tried to like this place and give it a chance, but there are much better options in the neighborhood.  Avoid.
author: Michael A.

description:
What a treat! Fusion Vietnamese Bahn Mi done right with a toasty French baguette and fresh, crunchy veggies...wow! Fast food done fresh. Also, there are rice bowls and noodle bowls for those of u who want a more hardy meal. And if u just want something light the summer rolls will impress, tofu or pork and shrimp with peanut dipping sauce mmmm.

The decor is inviting and outside seating is a major plus. Even with the line out the door I still got my food within ten minutes. Can't beat that.

Price is comparable to most places down in the Financial district for lunch. Enjoy!!...I know I did.
author: Andrew B.

description: I've had a few banh mi or bun mi (however you spell it) and I have to say the pork belly was very juicy, succulent, and tasty than I had ever had. The bread was toasted very nicely and they actually ripped out a little of the inside so you can enjoy the taste of the pork rather than all bread. They could have added more flavor to the pork, but it was still good enough without.  I added a little sriracha to mine which made it better and gulp down it down with blood orange san pellegrino water. Delish and refreshing! The atmosphere and restaurant setup was much like Shophouse in Dupont Circle in Washington, DC. They both serve banh mi coincidentally.  Quick, clean, and great service.
author: Olivia C.

description:
I've been here twice.  Each time, got the same thing: chicken bun (vermicelli) bowl.  First time was pretty good -- the fish sauce was a little less than most tasty, but it was overall OK (given the price, but hey, consider the location).

Second time, they seemed to have forgotten how to make the dam' thing.  The vermicelli wasn't .... vermicelli, but some other, thicker sort of rice noodle.  The verggies were chopped too coarsely, and ... well, overall, it sure wasn't worth $15 (with a coke).  No way, no how.

Not goin' back.
author: Chet M.

description: I really want to like this place. And maybe I'm picky about my meat. But to me, both the pork and the beef taste a bit off. I'm much happier with the $4 BBQ pork sandwich from Du's Sandwich truck/tent on Mission.
author: Karla R.

description: I got food poisoning from Bun Mee and was throwing up for hours on Friday night. Will avoid moving forward at all costs.
author: Sarah R.

description: I go to lunch here pretty often. The foods a mix of Vietnamese style sandwiches and bowls, I've tried both and thought they were pretty good. Their lemongrass pork and spicy chicken banh mi sandwiches are terrific and filling for one lunch break. They have a large assortment of drinks and sodas as well as vegetarian options as well. I will admit their food is more modern than a banh mi you might pick up from a traditional Vietnamese place, but if you're craving Vietnamese sandwiches I recommend giving this place a try.
author: Shahin K.

description: Great quick eats.  Hanoi-style catfish is excellent.
author: Nick O.

description: Not your regular authentic vietnamese sandwich shop but for sure an americanized vietnamese sandwich shop. I mean who has an option to throw an egg into your bun mee (not a bad idea but just not your typical bun mee lol) Theres not many vietnamese sandwitch options around the downtown area so this place will get your fix. Very modern style and a few beer selection on tap.
author: Michael L.

description: Five Spice Chicken was dry & flavor was not that great - maybe just an off night?. Place does have a cool vibe but wish food tasted a little better.
author: maria t.

description:
The main location at Fillmore set a high standard for a decent banh mi sandwich so I walked into the Market Street location on week 1 and week 2 with high hopes.  

Week one of the opening, I had the Five Spice Pork sandwich and my husband had the Sloppy Bun.  He enjoyed the Sloppy Bun and described it as savory and a nice blend of flavors. My Five Spice Pork on the other hand came in a very hard toasted bun and lacked any flavor.  It was hard to eat and crumbled with every bite.  

Week two, I ordered the Steak sandwich and asked for the bun to be less toasted.  The sandwich lacked any individuality and wasn't very tasty.  It needed to be marinated longer and the vegetables that accompanied it could have been smaller.

I will wait a few months before they figure out how to make another well made sandwich and try it again.  

The location will draw in the crowds, but please work on keeping the crowds.

Also, please DONT have your expeditor YELL out customers names especially when there is a line of people waiting for their order within ear shot.  It makes for a loud experience and is not necessary.
author: Ana W.

description:
How long of a line is one supposed to wait in, just to place an order?  While waiting in line, a group of four and a separate group of 2 said, "forget this", and left.  In the span of 2 minutes, including myself, that's 7 people that realized this place is not worth a ridiculous wait like that.

Tell you what - save yourself your half hour lunch break and a dollar, walk down to Market and Grant and order a bahn mi from Café Dolce.  You'll get a great sandwich from a super friendly couple, and you won't have to wait a half hour to place your order and then eventually, receive your sandwich.
author: JimJim M.

description:
Bun Mee is a great addition to the Financial District!  There're not many cool eateries  with tasty food yet reasonably priced in the area.  Bun Mee fills that void.  

Though I live in Seattle, I visit the Bay Area very often.  I've been a huge fan of Bun Mee since it opened its first location on Pac Heights.  I go there every time I'm in San Fran!  Just can't get enough of those yummy Mama Tran egg rolls and sloppy buns.  :)
 
I'm pleased to see that the new Bun Mee kept a lot of its cool original design elements as well as all the popular dishes.  Can't wait to come back again during my next visit!
author: Jiawen S.

description: Awesome bun mi place lines are long during lunch so try to come before or after lunch. I got the chicken bun mi. It was good for the price walked over to Yerba Buena garden to eat it.
author: Victoria N.

description: Ehh. I expected more food for the price I paid. Portion size is small. I got the sloppy which is pretty much sloppy Joe and cilantro inside a baguette. It was 8$. Nothing especial.
author: Adnan K.

description:
Disappointing. Never had a banh mi I didn't enjoy until I tried this place. It's not trying to imitate the dozens of more traditional bahn mi places, but in attempting to build a hybrid sandwich I think they've missed the mark. 

I got the "Belly Bun". The "pork belly" was just shredded pork with maybe a little more fat than average. Not the "sink your teeth in to thick fat" pork belly that I know and love and expect when something is billed as "pork belly". The bun was way off, tasting and feeling mostly like a hot dog bun and not like the more traditional french roll. If there was mayo, or sauce of any kind, I could not taste it. Though the bun was wet with what could easily have been water, given the flavor. They must de-seed their jalapenos because there was barely this slightest hint of spiciness, which is just a terrible thing to do, especially for an optional topping. 

If you want a Vietnamese sandwich, look elsewhere, as this taste nothing like what you're accustomed to. If you're looking for just a good sandwich in general, you can easily find one in the area that provides more flavor.
author: Phil D.

description: cute little bun mee shop that's a bit fusion at the same time.  I'd come here if i was working around here. very delicious vietnamese sandwiches and combo plates as well!
author: Stephanie C.

description: I was craving spring rolls and felt too lazy to walk back to Fresh Roll at the Metreon.  Serves me right, I should have just walked the few extra blocks.  Bun Mee's spring rolls were mediocre, pre-made, and their peanut sauce was really more like a scoop of peanut butter that I couldn't dip my food into.  Oh well, I can't get too upset about it, it was just lunch.
author: Natalie C.

description: I've been here twice now, the first time I got a pork bowl. I found it overall to be quite lacklustre, it didn't have the flavours that I was looking for, nor was there a great quantity of food in the bowl. The second time around I got a sandwich (chicken), and added extra meat to it. The sandwich was a much better experience compared with the bowl. I think the extra meat really helped to enhance the sandwich, as a few other that I went with noted that there wasn't enough meat in their sandwiches without the extra meat. Overall, if you are looking for something quick and are in the area, perhaps give Bun Mee a try but there are definitely better alternatives in the area.
author: David C.

description: I'm going to guess that this is going to be a staple for the lunching workers around here. We can feign that we only dig legit banh mi from the likes of Saigon Sandwich, but this more refined space + business is an impressive update on the classic cheaper-than-you-can-believe sandwich. Let's face it, we like when where we eat is clean. The Bun Mee brand represents just this: modern, open spaces, an open kitchen. The quality of the product is high. If you can't justify paying $6 or so for banh mi, order the bowl. It's delicious and hefty. It's almost like whomever chose to create this place just loves Viet culture and wanted to bring it to a different part of SF, and they're doing it in successful fashion. Is it Saigon or Dinosaurs? It's not. It's for people with tucked in shirts, not much time, and wanting something trustworthy.
author: Jon A.

description: They never get my order right! I always order the same thing and every single time I check they forget the avocado or grapefruit in the citrus bowl. It is called a citrus bowl, how do you forget the grapefruit?! Also they put one Kabob of shrimp when I pay for 2. It is very inconvenient to check to make sure my order is right every single time. Food is okay but the 2 stars is for the lack of service. Train your people to put in the right order! I have gotten the citrus bowl 8 times in the last few months and 6 out of the 8 times it was wrong.  Makes me wonder how many times do they mess up others order. Hopefully they see this Yelp review and fix the problem.
author: Rachel J.

description:
iWas walking on Market St looking for a 7-11 so iCould buy a fresh tin of Copenhagen Wintergreen. iLooked to my right, one eyeball on a text iWas writing and the other eyeball started twitching with horniness (re: excitement) - there was a Vietnemese Sandwich joint! iWasnt even hungry, but iYolo'd.

Forgot the name of my order but it essentially was a Vietnemese Sloppy Joe. The MON who took my order asked if I wanted an egg on it. iResponded with "shuuuuuure" (re: yolo).  iSat, proceeded to text a cupcake my dudes and my freaking eyes got all horny again! They had Cafe Du Monde cans laying around and yea, iGot that guy.  Went back to the MON and asked for one and he said it was on the house. Tis the f-ing season iGuess!

Feeling super satisfied iForgot why iWas walking around in the first place. But then I saw the 7-11 and bought a nice tin of the long stuff. Sorry mom :(

Excellent sandwich! Thank you.

Dunn
author: Jack C.

description: I am Vietnamese so I had the sandwiches plenty of time. BUT...this place is hella over priced. $7 for a sandwich. It is almost triple (maybe double the price for SF), of regular Vietnamese sandwich spots. Size is probably 1/4 smaller than regular. The only thing I can say good about this is...the meat is seasoned very well. But they also give you hella daikon, carrots, cilantro and peppers. Most Vietnamese spots have like 60% meat in the sandwich. But the sandwich seems to be less than half meat. I give it 3 just because the meat was good if youre into that.
author: Elvis D.

description:
I cannot understand why the reviews aren't that great.  The five spice chicken is absolutely delicious.
Though...the egg rolls are meh.
author: Cathy L.

description:
Update: Switching my rating from 1 to 5 stars. Got a moderate response from the GM, but the staff are amazing. I've been back and haven't experienced the same problem. Even better, the staff remembered me and thanked me for coming back in. The food is really good and the staff couldn't be nicer. 

Original review:
Meat in vegan food, twice in one month!

Fool me twice, shame on me, I guess. A few weeks ago, there was ham in my vegan takeout springrolls. I emailed the manager, who apologized but didn't give me a refund.

The food here is great and the people are really sweet, so I tried twice more and it was fine, until tonight. Two chunks of different meat in my vegan tofu bahn mi. Great customer service and apologies, and my food was refunded this time. Front of house workers are great, but the kitchen can't keep meat out of vegan food, and the managers don't refund or follow-up adequately. One star until they contact me and explain what's being done to fix this long-term, and refund my first contaminated order.
author: Jeff M.

description: Don't let the long lines scare you. This is a great spot for lunch near FiDi and Market St.   Vietnamese sandwiches and noodles bowls will satisfy our mid morning carvings and the vietnamese cofee will stave off the afternoon coma but don't expect fine linens at this fast casual spot.
author: Sandeep C.

description:
An absolute disappointment.  I was really looking forward to this place as my coworker just told me she thought it was pretty good. Craved it all day. I leave my house early and head over before work. Luckily there is nobody there and i order right away. I order the bun bowl. I wait about five minutes before they tell me they have no noodles and it will be 20 minutes. I have not twenty minutes to wait so they refunded me and I left. Hungry, with no time to eat before work. I get hangry at work and convince my manager to let me break before they close at 8. I go back. Again nobody is there. I walk to the register and am not acknowledged by either of the two people behind the counter for moments ling enough to make me mad. Finally the girl looks at me and then at the guy counting the register @ 730. So I speak up and tell them I'm back and want to try them again and they tell me they have no noodles still. No apology, nothing.
I will not try again.
author: Sarah J.

description:
I used to come here often because the food was pretty decent for lunch during the week. My last visit, emphasis on last, I ordered double meat on my sandwich and I got barely two slices. My business colleagues who joined me were shocked at the small portion. When I brought it up to the counter the girl simply shrugged and said that's double meat. I used to get much more every other time I've been there. Same price half the meat...rip off. At least my lunch guests got a good chuckle and a story to share about double meat. 

I'm so glad there are other choices in the city, I can give my lunch business to other establishments.
author: Malbec S.

description: This is the second time I have tried this place. The first time I bought the spring rolls and fries which were delicious. Today I tried the 5 Spice Chicken Salad and the chicken was barely cooked. So disappointed since this is one of there popular dishes.
author: Karen S.

description:
This is a great addition to the area-- my notes on the experience: 

-The Sloppy Bun was tasty-- all of the ingredients were fresh, just the right amount of spice to cater to most.   
-For the crazy line that I walked into, the service was quick and the turn around was just as quick.  The service team was extremely friendly and understood the urgency of most people who are eating on their lunch break 

Definitely on my list of go to spots for lunch in the FIDI!
author: Alicia B.

description: It is good for the area and fills you up. The pork belly sandwich is most tasty. The hawker bowl is great for hungry individual . Very American not authentic but clean and modern. Expensive for vietnamese food but comparable to American sandwich shops.
author: Alison W.

description: This place just opened not too long ago across the street from one of our offices.  My coworkers wanted to check it out for lunch so I went with them.  The place was crazy busy as expected for lunch in this area.   I asked the cashier which mayos had fish oil as I am allergic to fish oil and can't have it.  She replied with all but the soy one which is on the vegetarian sandwich.  I'm not vegetarian, just allergic to the fish oil, so I ordered the spice chicken sandwich with soy mayo instead of what it normally comes with.  I got back to the office and took my first bite and it was good but the second bite I reached the mayo and immediately got sick. :-(  I know they were incredibly busy and that I altered the order but getting it right was incredibly important to me.  I really wanted to have the sandwich but I couldn't and ended up having to throw away a $9 lunch and going somewhere else to grab something real quick.  I probably won't chance it again.  Not worth losing $9 and having to purchase a second lunch instead.
author: Amanda K.

description: Modern and trendy Vietnamese fusion sandwich shop, but I still prefer the little hole in the walls where sandwiches are under $4 and just as tasty. Long lines at lunch but it goes pretty fast. Still, I enjoyed the pork belly sandwich and the location is very central. Sweet potato fries were meh.
author: Melissa Y.

description: Nah bro. I hate people who rate a business one star without actually trying it, but a Banh Mi place that runs out of bread at six in the evening needs to re-evaluate their suppliers, priorities, or both. I'll be back to give them a fair shake, but for now it's a solid No-Go.
author: Thomas J.

description: This place is just okay. I had the 5 spice chicken sandwich. The meat was good quality but the marinade was sort of bland and they didn't put anywhere near enough jalapenos on the sandwich. I've had far better Vietnamese sandwiches just a few blocks away in Chinatown and for much cheaper. At $7 a sandwich (certain Vietnamese sandwich places in Chinatown have $4 ones that are much better) it was disappointing.
author: Grace P.

description:
I ended up getting my food about 30 minutes later after having to go up and ask about my order. Turns out they didnt even start making it because they forgot. All they did was offer me a free cookie for the poor service. 

As far as food, it was pretty basic. Nothing special. Flavors seemed new and modern but were pretty bland.
author: Julie P.

description: Very disappointing. It was overpriced, not all that great, but worst of all, they gave me a meat-filled egg roll with my vegetarian Bun Bowl! Completely unacceptable to offer supposedly vegetarian/vegan options only to serve meat items mixed in.
author: Teresa K.

description: If you want an Americanized bahn mi then please go. However, everything else about the sandwich was mediocre. The pickled carrots and radish were really thick and not flavored the same way as ma and pa shops. The meat was DELISH though and the bread is a baguette. What more can be said?
author: Diana L.

description: This place is a zoo and the wait can be long. But the food is really good. I like the eggrolls and the lemongrass pork sandwich. More expensive than your typical Bahn Mi place.
author: Adrienne G.

description: I am not into hipster type places. So that is why I will give this a 3 because it was just "A-ok." The 5 spice chicken Vietnamese sandwich was very flavorful. The chicken was real good. This place is in the financial district, it got real packed quickly so try and go early. The workers were nice, small place and seems clean.  Yes, I would go here again, but only if I am in the area. I can get an authentic Vietnamese sandwich for $3.50 in the TL and not pay techie hipster prices of 7.50 a sandwich :-)
author: X X.

description: Wow, I expected a lot more from this place but the photos are deceiving. The spring rolls were sweet and sour. Totally not to my liking. Don't think I will revisit
author: Ann L.

description: We ordered three meals for take out through grubhub. I got a chicken rice bowl, which had good flavor but I took off most of the toppings that were pickled or too spicy. My coworkers also said that it was good, average food. I would not order take out from them again.
author: Tori B.

description:
Love Bun Mee's newest location. Perfect for those in FiDi but more importantly, folks who are shopping and walking between Union Sq and the Westfield shopping area, like moi. 

The space is city cool. I like the art mural and lighting and the great big window looking out on Market Street. I like to people watch so this is very fitting.

We had the sloppy and the pork belly sandwich. We loved both of them - they are not traditional as other yelpers mentioned but that's what I like about them. Flavors are fresh. The meat to bread ratio is right on - I don't like sandwiches that are jammed with meat (no Italian sammies for me).  Their sweet potato fries are super yummy (I have a weakness for fries). :P

Great energy! Thanks for filling my belly Bun Mee.
author: Ling L.

description: Yes, it's pricey for a bahn mi, but it's the FiDi. I've tried the crispy tofu and the lemongrass pork bahn mi. Both were good. The egg rolls weren't that great to me. I like how they have cute little Sriracha packets to go.
author: Karen H.

description: If you're 21, work in IT, and you frequent Ritual in the Mission, you'll love this place. It's trendy, overpriced, and sells impressively forgettable Vietnamese sandwiches. We showed up at noon and basically spent 20 minutes waiting for an order given to another customer. The 'combo' sandwich is definitely not worth paying $7 for. Seriously, they're part of the problem and not part of the solution... OMG, srsly?
author: Jonathan C.

description: Very tasty considering that it's an Americanized chain selling Vietnamese sandwiches. The lemongrass pork sandwich was just what I was looking for and the spicy salt and pepper French fries had a great flavor and heat! Will have to bring back the husband as he's half Vietnamese for an official verdict.
author: Brian W.

description:
First time in a Bun Mee. Popped in around 11am and ordered 2 sandwiches to go.

No line (lucky enough to beat the lunch rush), very nice gal took my order, complimented by bike helmet (which is quite cool . . .) and took my order. Very friendly and quick. Waited about 7 minutes for food, there were 3 other people waiting for food ahead of me and it looked like they were preparing a large to go order as well.
Decor is awesome, love the naked Edison bulbs and the typographic centric artwork. 

First one: Grilled five spice chicken with caramel mayo, shaved onion, pickled carrot & daikon, cucumber, jalapeños, and cilantro ($6.25). 
Ate 10 minutes after receiving. Sweetness of the caramel mayo was a nice addition in theory but not enough to make a noticeable impact overall. Chicken itself was under seasoned. 

Second one: Belly Bun: Braised Kurobuta pork belly, salted radish relish, shaved onion, pickled carrot and daikon, cucumber, jalapeños, cilantro. ($6.75)
Ate 5 hours later for dinner. Integrity of the sandwich held up hours later. The salted radish relish is delicious, just enough salty goodness to compliment but not overwhelm the pork belly, which was nicely cooked. I would definitely order this again!

Ingredients were fresh and good quality. Good bread to meat to fix in' ratio. Smaller and more expensive than your traditional banh mi, but delicious nonetheless. I am interested to try their other sandwiches, like Bun Mee Combo (grilled lemongrass Kurobuta pork, paté de campagne, mortadella, garlic mayo, shaved onion, pickled carrot & daikon, cucumber, jalapeños, cilantro. $6.75) and Salt n Pepper Garlic Fries (Idaho potato fries tossed with sautéed red onions, garlic, and jalapeños topped with our salt n pepper seasonings. $2.75).

Good FiDi lunch spot but still will be visiting my tried and true ol' skool banh mi spot in Little Saigon for a good deal.
author: Julsies F.

description: As good as the one by my house. I always get the salad with chicken and a side of Pate, that way I can get the Bahn mi taste without the bread. Love it.
author: Nilu r.

description: I get why some folks are just not into this place: if you're expecting something more "authentic", perhaps you should go to Little Saigon. I, for one, enjoyed the five spice chicken sandwich (bigger than your average banh mi), with the added fried egg, and crispy egg rolls on the side. Sure, it's pricey, but it's FiDi, after all. Love the graphics and decor here, but the (take out waiting) area near the bathroom was clearly not thought out (and dangerous to hang out in that area--beware of the bathroom door flying open).
author: Maximillian M.

description: I order this fried catfish sandwich and I just have to say, its delicious. The red curry wasn"t that spicy but it gave it a nice flavor. I was disappointed on the "Salt n Pepper fries" on the menu it states theres salt , pepper, onion, jalapenos n garlic. I do see the jalapenos and onions but no pepper. I like how it taste like spicy fries but no garlic flavor. Compare it to Super Duper Garlic fries, there's a big diff. I also notice the fries on the middle towards the bottom were soaked with oily. I would only get sandwiches from now on.
author: Miri L.

description: Had to try it, just had to.  Couldn't bring myself to buy a sandwich (most likely because their spin on the name, "bun mee" is rediculously incorrect.  Bun translates to noodles, and there is only one noodle dish if you can call it that).  I bought the garlic rice dish, cause you can't go wrong with garlic rice right?  Wrong, so so wrong.  Come here if you want below average expensive fusion food.
author: Tony N.

description: The hottest new place in the FiDi! We rented out the whole restaurant for our company party and our guests loved it! The food was delicious and easy to pass around. Austin took care of the menu and everything else very professionally. The space is ultra hip with gorgeous murals and modern lighting. The location is an easy walk from Moscone too. We'll definitely be coming back to do more events at Bun Mee on Market.
author: Marisa F.

description: Polite and courteous service with a smile.  A slightly longer wait than expected was rewarded with freshly prepared food made just right. I love the Vietnamese sandwich theme, it reminds me of that spot in Brooklyn's Prospect Heights.  Very fresh ingredients.
author: Anthony H.

description: Soo good! My friend and I wanted to check out new lunch places and Bun Mee was recommended to us. We came on a really hot day in SF. I got the Spicy Chicken Sandwich and she got the Pork. We each got fries but we totally could have shared. Vietnamese iced coffee was so refreshing too. Ambience was cool but definitely gets crowded at lunch time on a week day.
author: Heather H.

description: Ok this place is basically the Starbucks of bahn mi places and typically I'd rather support my neighborhood mom and pop vietnamese haunts....But that crispy catfish sandwich keeps bringing me back! Since these bahn mi's cost twice as much as typical viet places I'd give them 3 stars.  But wait...now they have multiple $5 beer on tap! Add another star!
author: tim s.

description: One of my lunch hour staples: tofu sandwich with the salt and pepper fries. Don't despair if you see a long line because it moves quite quickly. Very efficient service. My only complaint is sometimes the fries are a bit soggy.
author: Shannon D.

description: Went to Bun Mee for the first time today and had the Sloppy Bun.  Loved it.  As for the other reviews who complain that this place isn't an authentic banh mi restaurant, I don't think it's even claiming to be.  Their website even phrases it, "banh mi-inspired."
author: Addie B.

description:
A+ for customer service. 

Ordered grubhub delivery, received wrong order, no big deal. I called them to see if the delivery guy was still nearby, maybe switched my order with someone else's. They told me to keep the food I had (I was starving!) and they would deliver the correct food shortly. They came within 20 minutes with my original order, plus extras. They went out of their way to get me what I wanted and I had enough food for 3+ meals. 

Thanks!
author: H g.

description: I've never been to this location but I took my friend out for lunch at around 11:30am and no lines! She ordered the crispy tofu banh mi and I ordered the crispy catfish sandwich with red mango curry sauce topped with an egg. We forgot to order fries and ice coffee but definitely a must buy to pair. Their strawberry lychee drink is also refreshing and light to pair with everything. This location is bigger than the Fillmore store and a lot more tables to enjoy your food. They also have sriracha sauce onevery table which definitely makes me love this place even more! Come for a banh mi and let your mouth do all the reviewing!
author: Jennifer D.

description: Just checked this spot out the other day. There was a long line around 12:15 but it did move fairly quickly. My coworker and I got our food to go because it was crowded and the music was super loud. Our sandwiches were decent I enjoyed mine with the fried fish. The portion of filling was not bad but the bread could use some improvement. It was slight toasted but not very soft or fluffy in the middle. Got a side of the salt and pepper fries and they were tasty although a bit soggy. The jalapenos on top are a nice touch though.
author: Alice J.

description: This is my favorite place to dine downtown when I'm just shopping around.  Market fresh Vietnamese scooter food at its most delicious.  My favorite is the 5-spice chicken sandwich.  The bun is crisp on the outside and soft on the inside, as a good bun should be.  It's swiped with special house mayo, unlike your jarred mayo, and stuffed with warm fragrant grilled 5-spice chicken, cool shredded carrots, jicama, and cucumbers, teased by a bit of fresh cilantro, and kissed by the heat of jalapeño slices.  It's the perfect marriage of crisp, soft, cool, sweet, fragrant, heat.  The fragrant spices will stay in your nose and mouth all afternoon, causing great pleasure.  Avoid at lunch as it's a crazy madhouse.  2 pm is the perfect time to settle in for a great dining experience.
author: Teri L.

description: OK bahn-mee.  Has crispy cat fish, which I don't find elsewhere, so it will be good for people who like something that reminds them of fish taco fillings.  Service is nice -- since you get numbers and they bring you the dish.  Decor has a rustic feel.
author: Dan C.

description: The dishes are very bland and generic and over priced. Won't be back again. Bamboo Asian around the corner is better and cheaper.
author: Ladywolf M.

description: Food is good, very tasty.  I've had better service here before but today was a joke.  Completely ignored by staff in an almost empty restaurant, not cool.
author: Mr S.

description: I literally have now come here 6 days in a row. Their service is nice, it's fast, it's fresh it's tastes good. I get the Saigon peanut bowl when I want rice and the bun bowl when I feel like noodles. Add steak ! It's tender. Decor is super hip and for a market restaurant it's not so crowded that you want to kill yourself. I'm a fan.
author: Sandy B.

description: Best sandwiches!! But the chef with the buck teeth is a fuckin RUDE as muthafucka!! Thats why this location only gets 3 stars!!! BEST believe I ALWAYS have good judgement when it comes to customer service...I work with patients & their health needs everyday!
author: Jing M.

description: Ordered Hanoi -style crispy catfish, salt n pepper garlic fries, Ice coffee and this has been one of the most disappointing meals today.
author: Sitha S.

description:
I've been going to Bun Mee on Fillmore since it opened so I was so happy to hear that they were opening up a new location in FiDi (a testament to how popular the original Bun Mee is).  The five spice chicken sandwich, Mama Tran's egg rolls, and the sweet potato fries are my favorite.  I can't get enough of that sweet curry mayo sauce that the fries come with.  Mmmmmmm.  I wish I could replicate it at home.

I had a chance to go to the FiDi location, right when it opened, and the food is consistent with the original Bun Mee.  LOVE the new decor and the ambiance!  I love it when hip places open up in locations like the financial district because it really adds new/fun energy.  You can tell that the owner really put a lot of thought into this place.  

I'm a picky eater so when I find a place I like, I go back obsessively and Bun Mee has been one of those places.  If you sit near the window, it's a perfect place to people watch while eating too.

I had a chance to meet Mama Tran the other day and she is SO cute!!  I wonder if I can get her to tell me what goes inside the curry mayo sauce. ;)
author: Juliette K.

description: Bun Meh.  Expensive sandwiches.  Rolls are not crispy enough.  In any Vietnamese neighborhood, I can get a better sandwich for less than half the $8.39 I paid for my five spice chicken with extra meat Bahn Mi.  You are paying a lot for a Vietnamese gimmick on Market Street.
author: Wayne Q.

description: Avoid this sorry attempt at Vietnamese fast food. They can't assemble a summer roll. The rice paper was broken and can't hold the contents. The vermicelli was over soaked and turned into slime paste. No flavor. My banh mi overloaded with pickled carrots. I would give this place 0 stars if I could. When I asked the staff if my summer roll is normal to be sloppy and slimy and she said yes.
author: Barry K.

description:
After reading all the reviews.... I have one question, you hungry.. or nah? 
I don't ever, ever expect authenticity from any Asian place that looks remotely fusion. And I'm not a huge fan of most Vietnamese cuisine (even though I'm part Vietnamese, imagine that) but I LOVE a good bahn mi. And while I wasn't expecting a super authentic sandwhich, I was expecting something that at least tasted good. I didn't look at the reviews before I went. I just knew it was right next door to  my work and I was extremely hungry. When you walk in there's a sign that says something about jalapenos and if you don't get them on your sandwich then you're a sissy. which was funny because there were no jalapenos on my sandwich. And since I can eat spicy....I really wanted them. I got the belly sandwich or something, and I had to add pate for an extra dollar....fine. But when I pay for something...I expect it to have it. So 13 bucks later and I finished my soggy sandwich filled with pretty everything (and by everthing I mean pickled veggies...so really is was just really just sour-y, vinegar-y bread) but what I ordered. I'm confused about how I feel because, I think I'm still hungry...but my stomach feels like its full. Whatever feeling it is, I'm definitely  not satisfied..
author: Asia W.

description: When I'm looking for a quick fix in the 'hood I'll come here to grab a Vietnamese sandwich.  I'm going down the list of trying different ones but so far the Lemongrass Pork, Combination, and the Meatball.  All are good and packed w/ flavor but prices are on the high end of what a normal sandwich would cost in the Tenderloin - beware.  I've also tried the noodle bowl which was just ok.
author: Meredith K.

description: This place is always crowded at lunch...and for good reason! If you can spare the time it takes to wait in line, you gotta try the pork belly sandwich and definitely add the hard boiled egg option. Pretty much blew my mind, I was hooked
author: Ross I.

description: Very nice ambient but the food isn't on par with the decors. It's expensive for a Vietnamese sandwich place and the portion is timid. The flavors aren't impressive given the price tag. As a Vietnamese, I'd pass.
author: Hung H.

description: Catfish is very important to me and this was... a-MAZ-ing!  Bread was perfect and not soaked with grease or sauce.  Sweet potato fries are very tasty and the curry mayo really adds some dimension to the starch.  Egg rolls are delicious esp. with this sweet vinegar for dipping.
author: Jennifer R.

description: Amazing food for a quick lunch ... authentic Viet food in the heart of San Fran... great, quick service at lunchtime.. would definitely go back :)
author: Miss C H.

description: Ban mi's should be quick and easy. I stepped into Bun Me for a quick pit stop and waited 20 minutes for my mediocre sandwich.
author: Ro-el C.

description: This location just opened a a couple of months ago on market.  Saw it on my way home on the bus.  It's a pretty good lunch spot.  The cashiers are pretty quick.  Got the grilled pork sandwich.   It tasted really fresh!
author: Sara Z.

description:
Well that was hands down the WORST Vietnamese sandwich I have ever had in my life.  I ordered the pork belly sandwich and it was 95% fat (seriously, no exaggeration).  I want a little fat with pork belly, but after a couple bites with ONLY fat, I pulled the sandwich apart to remove the fat and found I was left with only the tiniest morsel of non-fat pork on a large sandwich.  The roll was stale and chewy too.  No real flavor in the other ingredients, even the jalapenos were bland.

This place is shiny and new so if that's all you care about, you may well like it.  But in my experience, the food sucked out loud.  I would rather eat garbage than eat here again.
author: Robert P.

description:
Welcome to FiDi Bun Mee! My co-workers and I were so excited to see a 2nd Bun Mee open up close to our office. This is definitely our new favorite place in FiDi, and I just love their attention to detail with their fresh ingredients, reasonable prices and beautiful new space. Have you seen the mural and those lights? Very wicked. 

My husband and I are major foodies. We can't tolerate low quality ingredients and spaces with rude staff and bad energy. Bun Mee is definitely a top notch casual restaurant and they have everything going for them from fresh ingredients, to friendly staff, to reasonable prices, and an amazing menu to select from. 

There are times when I actually crave their sloppy bun and sweet potato fries. Simply delicious. And its amazing that they have their own fresh take on the Oreo cookie - just heavenly. 

Bun Mee, you did it again!!!! Thank you for delighting the taste buds of the real foodies of San Francisco. We love you guys!!!! :)
author: Niki D.

description: Went here for lunch and the place was packed. Service was quick and friendly. I ordered a Vietnamese sandwich. Unfortunately I have to say that I've  had much better a few blocks away up in Chinatown and for less money. I might give it one more try but so far not too impressed.
author: Michael S.

description: love the big red helmet mural.  love the hanging lights too.  great food.  great decor and ambiance.  they were really nice and let us order 10min before they were officially closed.  and then they let us stay in there during the 20min after they officially closed to eat our yummy foods.
author: Dae Y.

description: Beyond disappointed.  I eat a lot of Bahn MI sandwiches.  Had their combo sandwich. Perhaps the most bland sandwich I've ever had. Even the ghetto coffee shop next to my office crushes them,  and they use a microwave to heat the meat... And perhaps the most expensive one I've had too. How hard is it to use ingredients that have flavor?
author: reza n.

description: I tried a bunch of the bun mee sandwiches...I like the beef and catfish the most. the others were good but nothing special. I have a hard time paying that much for the noodle dishes. The lychee strawberry drink is too sweet (according to my friend). Given it's location, i would come here for my vietnamese sandwich fix.
author: Musetta S.

description: Despite the name Bun Mee, it's all about the Caramel Citrus Bowl.  You won't regret it, I swear.
author: Cin S.

description: This place hits the spot when you want Vietnamese food and you're in downtown. It's over price but what do you expect? I've tried everything but the bun mee, so this review shall exclude that for the time being.
author: jasmin t.

description: When lunch time rolls around, this place is hopping. The line tends to move quick though. Their crispy tofu sandwich is prettyyy good though. The chocolate coconut cookies are so yummy!
author: Katherine D.

description: I was already a devoted fan of Vietnamese sandwiches so I was excited to see Bun Mee scheduled to cater our office lunch.  The sandwiches did not disappoint me!  I think the bread was actually the best that I had ever had on a Vietnamese sandwich.  I was soft, whereas sometimes I find that the bread used for these sandwiches is dangerously hard.  Anyways, I tried half of the pork belly sandwich and half of the chicken sandwich.  I'm not usually a pork type of girl, but the pork belly was amazing and seemed to also be favored by others in my office.  Don't get me wrong, the chicken was great too.  I hear that Bun Mee has a more "Americanized" take on the sandwiches, but I was still very satisfied with this meal.
author: Kristen F.

description: Wowwzers! What a great place!  I was in the fidi neighborhood and saw this cool glowing red light across the street and a place called bun Mee.  Fantastic! I ate a scrumptious pork belly sando and was in heaven. What a great find! Cool art. Good prices and not pretentios, korabuta pork at a cheap price, bun Mee me please
author: Kim S.

description: The food is good and I love the atmosphere, the staff is usually friendly buy very disorganized.  Make sure you keep your receipt and pay attention to whose name is being called or someone else will take your sandwich and you'll end up waiting an extra 15 minutes :/.
author: Caelin B.

description: The place looks like it would be awesome...and it's not bad, the bowls that I've gotten a couple of times taste good but are just heavy. It would be better if the food was a little lighter/healthier. Maybe that's just how Vietnamese food is...I don't know for sure. I haven't tried their sandwiches, but they're supposed to be pretty good. Overall it's good and make sure to get there early to beat the lunch rush as the line can grow pretty quickly
author: George M.

description:
If you expense with AMEX, avoid this place. You're only allowed to use AMEX if the bill's over $30. I was like whaaattt??? This place isn't fancy. It seems extremely arbitrary and bad business sense to have that policy in the FINANCIAL DISTRICT (where finance people expense dinners with AMEX).

I had the 5 Spice Chicken Salad. It was good, but the pickles didn't taste as authentic as most Vietnamese places. I didn't pour all of the dressing since you can't taste the real flavors with too much of it on there. Others mentioned it's overpriced, and it is. In any case, I'm never going back... There are plenty of other places with better food and don't have ridiculous credit card policies.
author: Sam R.

description: Pretty solid place to go for lunch. Try to go early or for a late lunch like past 1 to avoid the long lines. Both types of fries are a must. I've only tried the sloppy bun sandwich, but I may go back. I've never been a sloppy joe fan so I probably shouldn't have gotten that one, but with a fried egg I couldn't resist.
author: Erin T.

description: $6.72 for a shrimp and pork spring roll cut in 4 pieces. literally one piece of small shrimp cut in half per piece and where is the pork?  filled with dried looking lettuce, carotts and sprout, where is the noodle?  suppose to be premade. totally crazy...don't bother.
author: Food Is L.

description: ADD EGGS!!! it was my first time here. My boyfriend and I got lemongrass, combo and 5 spice. They were all good... and I honestly couldn't tell difference lol
author: Yumi K.

description: Awesome place, and has turned into my go-to spot for lunch.  The bun noodle bowl is filling and super tasty, maybe even healthy too.  The fries are a must even though they may not be healthy, but fries are never on the doctors recommended list.  The atmosphere is fun, and they are quick and consistent every time I've been so 5 stars it is!
author: Brendan W.

description: The food is average. if you like good vietnamese food, try 'mau' on valencia in the Mission district.
author: Rashmi V.

description:
If you're a meat lover, these overpriced vietnamese sandwiches are not worth it; you can get better at a hole in the wall. But for the tofu sandwich (which is outstanding: crisp and packed with flavor) the price seems about right. 

Pro: The tofu is bomb, and weirdly, the fries are really awesome, if thin and crispy is your style.

Con: The pickled stuff on the ban mhi is not as punchy as  I'm used to. And most upsetting of all, no hoisin sauce!

Get the tofu sandwich and bring your own hoisin.
author: Alice C.

description: With crispy bread and full of fresh flavor, the crispy tofu sandwich is great. And friendly, helpful service.
author: Clynton T.

description: Went with my mother and we split what we ordered. I got diarrhea after eating their noodle bowl and a sandwich, Sandwich and noodle bowl were so small. Honestly I would rather take the 30 or 45 out to Chinatown to get some authentic and more delicious Vietnamese cuisine. Ordered the sandwich w/o jalapenos but still got them and tried to remove them and the seeds were stuck inside and it wasn't pleasant. Both items were absolutely tasteless. Noodle bowl wasn't disclosed to have peanuts in it, so I almost had an allergic reaction and gave most of my half to my mom.  Total was around $23 and never coming back.
author: Aria Y.

description: The line can be a bit long at lunch, and the prices are pretty high for banh mi (6-8$), but the food is pretty freakin good.
author: Ivan M.

description:
The first time I ordered at very crowded lunchtime at the counter, and they gave me the wrong order to go. A week later I ordered at 4:15pm, online, and picked it up 15 minutes later from the nearly empty store - this time I got the correct order. However, the fried eggrolls, which I was hoping would be great. are horrible. They taste like frozen fried aged rolls filled with mushy beef rather than pork and they had absolutely no herbal flavor or tender noodle texture inside. 
The mango salad was wilted and bland - just shredded napa cabbage and a few mango diced pieces - wheres the basil and cilantro? The sesame? Not nearly enough to call this Vietnamese. 
I really wanted to like this place but the mushy dark pork and the lack of lighter herbal flavors make it taste unlike Vietnamese food at all. More like frozen supermarket food or old cafeteria food. 
The hallmark of Vietnamese food is lightness from fresh aromatic herbs as well as moisture from pickled condiments in the banh mi and in the salads. Even Vietnamese beef jerky is a mixture of sweet and salty without a heaviness. It is a difficult cuisine to pull of for this reason - it has got to be fresh and light, including the fried food. 
Unfortunately this food is way off the mark. Back to Freshroll!
author: Nan L.

description: It's ok.  Think overrated.  Can basically get similar stuff at some hole-in-the-wall Vietnamese places but without the hype.
author: Adrian H.

description:
Growing up in an Asian-American household, banh mi was a staple food item, especially since it's part of my mother's heritage. 

The place was very central - located on Market Street and all that, and the decor inside is very contemporary (in my opinion).

What I got:
Combo Banh Mi sandwich - This has marinated pork pieces (some skin included), mortadella, pate, a combination of carrots/radishes, jalapenos, and cilantro all served on a baguette. They ask if you want to add an egg in this sandwich, but I opted out. This is smaller banh mi then what you would get at a normal Vietnamese restuarant, however, for the price you pay it is still a pretty good deal. I didn't really taste the pate when I ate this sandwich, but all in all it was decently tasty - 3 stars, because it was good, but nothing mind-blowing.

Shrimp/Pork Spring Rolls - Comes served in a thicker rice paper, which was nice and chewy and the sauce it came with was tasty. I didn't expect the pineapple pieces to be in there which made the spring roll a little wetter then expected - 3 stars.


This place puts an American fusion spin to Vietnamese classics. 

Handy Tip: All their sandwiches come spicy (aka - there's jalapenos in the sandwich) - if you are not a spicy-loving person, make sure you tell them to make your sandwich mild/not-spicy!
author: Melissa L.

description: Bread was hard and tasted more like a German roll than a French one. Veggies were tasteless. Meat was decent (combo) but still jacked personality. The (seasonal) corn on the cob was good but $3.50.
author: barnaby r.

description: I was expecting this place to be my new go -to place for lunch. The place has a good vibe and was very busy. I liked the atmosphere and the menu looked good. I ordered the 5 spice chicken salad and hated it! The chicken had an awful flavor that was overwhelming. The dressing was not good either. I liked the carrots and the jalapeños but was so disappointed in the food. My coworker, who is Vietnamese, and knows good food, joined me and ordered the combo sandwich. She was also disappointed in the flavor of the meat and won't be back.
author: Reina S.

description:
Fabulous! Love the first location and the second is just great. Prices are reasonable and the staff is super friendly. Also - love the decor and lighting as well. A nice edgy place for lunch, just when you're craving something great!

The sloppy, vegetarian, and pork bun mees are my favorite. Happy eating!
author: Busta B.

description: Very attractive place, I was looking forward to trying it on my lunch break. I got the beef bahn mi and it wasn't brilliant. Clearly not working with the best meat in the world, but I didn't expect too much from a bahn mi. It was decent, but nothing made the sandwich stand out in my mind. I don't regret going, but I'll look for something else next time I forget to bring lunch to work.
author: Sam R.

description:
Don't come here if you're looking for an authentic bahn mi sandwich. Bun Mee is to Vietnamese sandwiches what Chevy's is to Mexican - but all in all, it's decent.

Had the crispy catfish sandwich - I would slather that red curry mayo on EVERYTHING. It's pretty good on the salt and pepper jalapeno fries AND the sweet potato fries. 

The belly bun is good too - the pork is really flavorful, but there was entirely too much fat on the cut of pork belly we got. I'd skip Momma Tran's egg rolls (apparently she's losing her sense of taste)..
author: Candy C.

description: I loved the crispy tofu sandwich when Bun Mee first opened. The last two sandwiches I ordered were almost could have been called gross. The soy mayonnaise seems to no longer be a part of the sandwich, the tofu is not crispy - just soggy, and the slaw is now overpowering in taste  Overall, it's just funky tasting. Oh, and now the sandwich seems to come cold instead of hot. Disappointing. Why did you change this sandwich? It was so good.  ;(
author: M F.

description: Ordered the peanut chicken bowl with garlic rice. I'm not sure what makes it garlic rice since it wasn't very garlic-y. The chicken was dark meat which I prefer but it could have been cooked a little more. It was still really fatty. The peanut sauce was pretty good. Probably won't go back.
author: Will M.

description:
I wanted to like this place because I like a good banh mi sandwich and it's in a great location.  And I am totally one of those people who are taken in by slick marketing and logos and all that jazz.  This place is beautiful and the designers and the money people behind it should pat themselves on the back.  

But, I've been there three times and I was disappointed all three times.  

There's a big sign that says something about being a "pussy" if you don't like your sandwich spicy, which is just sort of eye roll inducing.  But then the sandwiches really aren't spicy.  So, it's both offensive and not true.  The vegetables aren't really all that pickled and the jalapenos are on the weaker side.  Both times I ordered sandwiches it seemed to take ten or more minutes for the order to be ready.  The rice bowl was out super quick, but when I got it the rice was both undercooked and burnt.  Yup.  Undercooked AND burnt.  

Maybe it was an off day for rice.  Maybe this place just isn't my thing.  Fair enough.  But if you are looking for a good banh mi, there are plenty of other places in the city.  

I should say the bread on both sandwiches was very good, but that doesn't really matter if the insides aren't that great.
author: Claire R.

description: Bun Meeeee!!! I was excited to see the second one open in FiDi. I love the the design & vibe of this place as I do w/ the other location on Fillmore, it puts me in a happy mood. I ordered the sloppy bun w/ fried egg, salt & pepper garlic fries, & an iced coffee. The place was really busy & I had a lil wait, but to be expected when it's their grand opening. I devoured my tasty lunch, the quality of the food continue to not disappoint, & left there still in a happy mood.
author: Cat S.

description: This new Vietnamese sandwich shop looks very trendy from outside, and always lines outside during lunch hours. But the sandwiches are so mediocre, nothing special. My friend and I both tried juicy steak, it was not that juicy, just plain.
author: Emmy P.

description: Other than its cute name and decorative interior, there isn't much going for this place.  The food is average, and the prices are inflated given its prime location.  I would look elsewhere unless you are absolutely starving and craving (modified takes on) banh mi sandwiches and standing directly in front of the store.
author: Josh Q.

description:
Wow!!  Had such a fabulous experience! I definitely recommend this place! The ambiance is gorgeous and has a very inviting feel to it! The location is prime which drew me right in and the menu is filled with great choices for all.  I love he Catfish Sandwich-  AMAZING!!!  Not to mention the friendly staff and really cool decor- You must check it out.  I can't wait to go back and try more food. YAY!!!!!

FYI- don't forgot to try the mouthwatering coconut chocolate cookies!!! Mmmm:-)
author: Anu S.

description: Pass .  If I were craving pho or Bahn MI  I would  suck it up n wait til I could get to a decent place.  I wouldn't just go there for a fix bc it wouldn't do the trick.  The flavors aren't quite right.   Sorry.
author: Price L.

description: The food was good but the service was TERRIBLE.  First off, I placed an online order, even receiving a confirmation of my order.  I go to pick up my order 2 hours later and it was downhill from there.  The lady at the register was beyond rude, accusing me of not placing an order with them, perhaps I was suppose to pick up at their other location, perhaps my card was declined.  Nope, all was good on my end.  It was their system that failed.  Finally, after shoving my email confirmation in her face, she makes my order (taking her freaking time).  30 minutes later, I finally had my food.  To add insult to injury, you lose my order, take 30 minutes to make a coupla sandwiches (which were good, but definitely over-priced, and not served with any kind of graciousness), and then charge me for a bigger bag.  All in all, I will be taking my business elsewhere.  There are plenty of banh mi joints in the city that will feed me great food, while not treating me like shit.
author: Steve L.

description: How in the hell this place still in business. I guess when you're living in the city, you just gonna be a bunch of sheeps and eat whatever they toss at you and say it delicious. This place is seriously over priced, taste nothing like a banh mi and please have some respect for the language . It's spelled "banh mi" don't trying to change it so it'll be easier for people to read it. That's messed up.
author: Jeff P.

description: Wicked good vegan options. Crispy tofu is the fave, but sometimes I do the eggplant and sub vegenaise. Reasonably priced for the hood, and quick service. Also: sweet fries. Sweet. Fries. Hot damn.
author: M.K. C.

description: The server who took my order didn't recommend anything, ask if I've ever been there or if I needed anything to drink.  Way to up-sell!  I ordered the Hanoi-Style Crispy Catfish Bun Mee and the Jalapeno garlic french fries and was hungry and excited to try a new place near my work.  For starters, the Hanoi-Style Crispy Catfish bun mee didn't taste like it had the red curry mayo.   the only flavor that came out of the bun mee was the mildly sweet pickled veggies and onions.  They probably should have added extra jalapenos so I could blame that on the lack of flavor.  The fries became soggy at the bottom of their to-go box, but had much flavor from the garlic and jalapenos.  Overall, I should have stuck with ordering the traditional bun mee.  I believe in second chances so I will try this spot out again when I have nothing else to eat in the FIDI.  Until next time, I'll leave my two stars and hope for a third next time.
author: Tiffany B.

description: This place is certainly worth checking out if you're in the area. I got the 5 spice chicken sandwich and garlic fries. The sandwich was pretty good. I would have liked the chicken to have a little more kick to it, but the veggies were fresh and as a whole it was really enjoyable. The garlic fries have jalapenos mixed in which make for a really great flavor. What really stood out about this place for me though was the service. The staff were super friendly, and the woman who took my order even remembered my name when checking back to make sure we were enjoying our meal. I'll be adding this to my list of weekday lunch stops.
author: Cameron P.

description: Clearly fusion vietnamese.  Very tall, thin space which makes for a lot of noise inside.  I feel sorry for the people who have to work here.  Line for lunch was almost out the door and it's tight because there is only one way in and out.  But Line moved fast and food came fast.  I had the grilled pork bun bowl with a limeade.  Food looked appetizing, fresh and colorful.  Rice noodles not as thin as I like them and definitely not as plentiful as every other place, which might be a plus for someone trying to avoid carbs.  Cut to the chase.  Taste was lacking.  Just wasn't there.  And I missed the ground peanuts that normally come on this dish at virtually every other restaurant I've gotten it at.  Worst of all, there was chicken bits in with the pork.  At first the only reason I noticed is because the texture was different, which tells you just how tasteless it was.  Then I looked closer and realized there were a few bits of grilled chicken mixed in with my pork.  And then I realized there was something funny about the texture of the chicken.  Don't know what that was about, didn't care since I wanted to be eating tasty grilled pork.  Also had the limeade.  Was way too sweet and tasted quite a bit like they squeezed it out of one of those green plastic limes from the grocery store.  Also note that if you want to go someplace and sit down to eat, likely it won't be here because seating is minimal.  Don't know why anyone would tarry long here anyway with the noise level. Won't be coming back here unless every other Vietnamese restaurant within walking distance of my office is close and then I will go to Lee's anyway.
author: Tonia C.

description: Was looking forward to Bun Mee on Market Street as I enjoy the one on Fillmore. What a pleasant surprise. Love the decor as it is eye popping and original.  The food is consistent with Fillmore and friendly service.  Love their sloppy bun, garlic fries and the egg rolls. They are getting their kinks out but you will enjoy their quality sandwiches and their lovely ambience.
author: Ina K.

description: Big plus = Very interesting and tasty food. Big minus = music is too loud so it's hard to order your food/hear your name when your order's ready while space is limited when waiting for your food so you're standing on top of each other. If they would lower the music, use a microphone and re-arrange space...everything would be great for 5 stars.
author: Robyn R.

description: We ordered this for delivery for our office and after much confusion (their website said they didn't deliver to our office, but the office next door JUST had it delivered that morning), I called and asked about delivery. She said "oh we don't have your food, it must have gone out." "No, I haven't ordered yet, I wanted to make sure you deliver to our area first before placing my order." "Yes, we deliver to your office." "Oh, do you want our address first, so you can check?" She finally said yes and then told us it would be easier to order online. I went online to order and when I finished up our order, it told me it couldn't process it because they didn't deliver to our address. Awesome.
